★★★☆☆I loved Borderlands 1 and 2. Borderlands 2 is one of my favorite game. I played it when it came out and I bought it on xbox 360, PS vita and on PC, on xbox I have all DLCs and Played the game with all characters (6).I was really optimistic when I bought Pre-Sequel with two of my mates.Lets get into the pros and cons:Easy part, the negative stuff:- Boreing story.- S?#t map design.- No interesting playable characteras.- Me and my friends hate the "low gravity jumping puzzle" aspect (fun but to much).- yoyo missions (go somewhere then back go there come back do stuff) they tried to add length to the game.- Its rare to go back "home" for opening crates or sell/buy stuff.- Weapon vendors are useless.- voice acting is just irritateing.- forgetable characters (like the girl at the 2nd mission).- Hard to find competent gear. Like really hard. (Played last mission w/ LV. 14 SMG vs. Lv. 26 Boss).- Really bad car handleing experience.- Rare fast travel points.- No creative skills. base skill is useful but you cant evolve it.- Rare boss fights.- Boring sidequests.- No motivation for any sidequests or echo tapes.- Same graphics. (Borderlands 2 (2012)- Game chrash or freeze in every 3-4 hours (i5-6600K / GTX 970 Srix / 16GB DDR4 / SSD)- Boring conversations.- Few funny jokes.- Same enemy types. (like br2)- Laser weapons has no point.- Vertical map is not fun at all.- Beginning is caotic.AVG things like:- Low price at 3rd party sites. (6 eur)- Same gameplay.- Same  gunplay.- Game lenght is not so bad compared to the price range.- HUD could be updated.Positives:- Grinder (throw in 3 same grade weapons and you get a sort of better one)- Fast loading time.- "Floating car" called stingray is a lot of fun.- Moxxi's booster drinks ar useful but its rare to go to the base.- Oxigen mask is cool.- Slam is useful. (smash into the groung)- Boost jump or double jump is a great element.- Ice elemental is kinda cool.(really struggleing to gather some positive aspects)I played a lot of games in the past 12 years, its rare but I must say that this game is really disappointing for me and my friends. If you inspect it as a standalone game without other borderlands games its not that bad.On the other hand If you compare it with BR2 u can clearly see that the game is made by an other team and its just terrible. You can see there is 24 cons and 13 average and pros together and I was sweating to get some pros. (as you can se there is a lot of irrelevant positivities).Verdict:If you really like the borderlands series and played the first two games you CAN buy it when the price is low. But if you dont want to spend money to ruin your love towards the Borderlands series just read the story at the internet.If you are new to the series go and buy the Borderlands 2 instead. More content for 10 bucks (Game of The Year edition), fun characters, interesting story, well designed map and great missions.In my opinion this game is a: WEAK ★★★☆☆ (2,6/5) I really cant recommend it.Thank you for reading my review! I hope it was helpful.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Ok, i want to say, i REALLY wanted to like this game. I even spent a long time trying to convince myself it was good, or worth the 60 dollars. But it's just not. It's worth 20-30 dollars, not 60. Here's why. It's a bit of a rant, but I think its' better than the "OMG BORDERLANDS OMG GUNS BUY" reviews with 1,4 hours played.The graphics and guns are exactly the same as borderlands 2. No improvements at all. The gameplay is basically the same too, except they added "oxygen," a new consumable resource. Instead of being fun, however, this basically turns into you standing on top of a vent once every 2 minutes for a few seconds. That's it. Basically, you just have to arbitrarily run to the nearest one to recharge, then go back to what you were doing. It doesnt ADD anything from a gameplay standpoint, it just makes you have to do a pointless backtrack.The maps are at best poorly designed. I've never fallen off a map to my death so many times. And it's not because it's challenging or fun. It's because the damn things were obviously not gameplay tested. Ive gone off lifts that just killed me. You can't control anything when you're on a lift, but i still got thrown to my death. I've gone off ramps 4-5 times before i successfully completed the jump. This isn't fun, its brain damage.Similarly, the AI is terrible, and the balancing is way off. They all stand around like morons, but when they actually do shoot you, you die nearly instantly. The boss fights are forced, and don't fit in with the storyline (which IS good.)Finally, I've yet to find a single weapon that's fun to use. Either it sucks, or it burns through tons of ammo and you're constantly out of ammo. No legends, no "cool" effects. Just balancing going out of ammo with doing damage.And worst of all is the bugs and the lack of save points and fast travel stations. I include this in one paragraph because they all group together to just be FRUSTRATING. So, at least 3 times i've had to reload because i just had a bug. One time, i couldn't move. I had to restart my computer. Another time, my special attack glitched and my crosshairs got stuck on the bottom left of my screen (wtf??). Another time my gladiator shield just stayed up forever so i couldn't see. This kind of thing is extremely common. I've been caught in invisible walls at least 3 times, and just had to reload. This is already annoying. But there's NO DAMN SAVE POINTS. frequently, my having to reload means i have to do the ENTIRE LEVEL OVER. and since there's no fast travel stations (so far, i have THREE) you have to WALK the entire way. Accross that map, which - guess what? - TENDS TO HAVE YOU FALLING OFF. Here's an example which happened to me. I got the end of a level, it took about an hour. it was a very long level. In this level, i fell off the map twice. whatever. I finally reach the room before the boss level. This is full of vague descriptions like "shut off the valve" This room has 4-5 levels, and the objective is not clearly marked. After about 15 minutes of frustratingly running in circles, i realize its ABOVE me, even though there's no reason for it to be there - there's not even a floor there, etc. And it's tiny, and it blends in. Whatever. I try to jump up there -- and get stuck inside an invisible wall. Reload the map, have to do the ENTIRE LEVEL over. all the enemies have respawned. Another hour, another 3 deaths falling off the map. This game isn't fun, its frustrating.All in all, this game just isn't worth the 60 dollars. It's worth 20 dollars on sale, sure. You can have fun playing it. You can play with friends. And hey, if you like borderlands 2, you'll probably like this game too! Buuuuut...it's just not worth 60 dollars. Wait until it goes on sale for 20-30 dollars, then try it. Maybe by then they'll patch some bugs, too.

Teal DeerDevelopers: 2K Austrilia, Gearbox Software, AspyrPublishers: 2K, AspyrInitial release: Oct 2014Genre: RPG, FPS#Worth/NotWorth: #NotWorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationI haven't been able to drag myself back into this. I tried and tried even using multiple characters trying things I don't normally do. This game just feels like a chore. Its almost lifeless. I played the previous Borderlands games incessantly making multiple characters playing the same missions going to the same locations over and over while listening to podcasts and music and I loved it. I even bought multiple packs of DLC because I just couldn't get enough. What happened Gearbox?I should mention I've only ever played co-op once. I'm sort of the proverbial lone wolf in games like this as well as MMO's. Really anywhere I guess. So if you're super into anything co-op this does that.But lets get to the crux shall weThe game feels inherently different than previous iterations. Its slower, but somehow manages to not be as methodical as the two ideas typically go hand in hand skipping down the street all the way up to the moonbase of Hyperion. Its just as chaotic as Borderlands has ever been but you move slower and have more meters to manage as being on the moon.. oxygen is helpful to our species well being. Because you're constantly monitoring your oxygen, while easy to refill, you to still HAVE to do it. Which makes exploring things outside on the surface this thing that now takes effort instead of just having the joy of discovering things. The characters are all sort of what you expect from borderlands style of humor but somehow, maybe its the location, they manage to be completely innocuous, uninspired and uninteresting. Just keep playing Borderlands 2 instead.Follow my curation for more

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Not what I expected or hoped for.  It's gone from bazzilions of guns to about 5 from each manufacturer of each type, Pistols, Assault Rifles etc.  Alot of your guns will roll with identical stats if they are the same make/level/type.  The new mobs to fight are terribly underwhelming.  The ability of mobs to jump clear across the map and land behind you is just stupid.  Even unsuspecting foes will walk behind cover and stay there if you put your crosshairs on them.  Laser weapon are just a joke, your firing a beam weapon.  This is a ray of light.  Lasers produce NO kick, but these lasers kick like a bloody mule.  You can't hold your crosshairs on a target and incinerate them.  Pull the trigger and your weapon jumps 6 feet up to the right. 90% of the weapons in game are recycled weapons from Borderlands 2.  Only weapons that I can honestly say were new were the laser weapons, and they are pretty much useless.  Your most powerful weapons in the game are still the Torgue weapons with added explosive damage.  They rip and shred the end boss faster than any other weapons in the game by about 75% faster kills.  Torgue weapons are cool and all, but try taking out the end bosses with a fire/cold/electric/corrosion set of guns and you are headed for one place.  OUT OF AMMO! Take in one Torgue Assault Rifle loaded with ammo and you will wipe the end bosses all six phases with one gun.The quests are terribly tiresome.  Go here, get this, bring it back.  Or it's go here, kill this, come back.  That and the fact that many of the zones don't even allow you to ride the new vehicles.  You have to walk.  Many of the quests send you through areas where you have to dismount and walk (Pickle quests in particular).  That and the fact you can't speed the dialogue up.  You are forced to sit there and listen to there useless rants until they are done.  On my second playthrough, I found myself trying to headshot many of my allies, just because their dialogues were so lengthy and stupid.This game is no borderlands 2 remake, it is a shadow of BL2.  Definately not worth the $60.  Playing it I kept wondering when it was going to get exciting, it never did.  The only fun quest really is the race event, that one is a hoot.  Then you get to off the punks Dad every time you revisit the zone.  That's fun.  He's an idiot, but it's still fun removing his♥♥♥♥♥♥from the future gene pool.Legendary drop rate appears to be about 2 to 3 every 1,000 kills.  Don't expect a huge range of legendaries to choose from, there's only like 50 or 60 guns, and 1 to 2 Class mods, maybe 10 shields (some of which you never want to use because they will kill you faster than any mobs ever will)  add in a couple of "oz" legendaries and that's all you are going to see.   Endgame is totally underwhelming, the secret boss Iwajira is a bit of a joke.  Explosive weapons chew him to shreds in mere seconds.  3 to 4 clips from your Torgue assault rifle and he's worm bait.  If he does spawn a couple of little runts you have to kill them off fast or they climb the wall and go above world where you cannot hit them and thus the only way out will not spawn.  Your only option then is to reload.  Even killing "Raid Bosses" is no guarentee of a good loot drop.  You may have to kill them a dozen times or more to even see a legendary and even then theres a 70% chance it will be a stupid grenade mod.As it sits now, there's maybe 200 to 300 guns in the game that get new affixes and damage as a player levels.  It's still the same gun, same model, same maker, just with level rated stats and maybe a new affix.  BL2's guns were nuts.  TONS of different guns.  Not so in this offering.Grinder is pointless really. It's cost to moonstone grind are just ridiculous.  Grind 3 greens to make a blue and get charged 70+ moonstones.  Save up your useless junk legendaries and grind 2 of them into 1 legendary of your gun class for 130 Moonstones.  Chances are, you will get a tediore weapon  with low damage and a elemental effect.  Get used to your bullet passing through an enemy and doing no damage.  That and enemies all want to run/jump behind you.  (The jumping clear across the map gets old very fast.  So much for sniping.  Sure you'll get one, but the rest of his buddies instantly dive for cover or jump clear across the map and butt slam you taking out your shields)  As a sniper you may get the benefit of one shot from an amp shield, then mobs are set to jump at you and keep your shield from ever getting back to 100% untill they are all dead.  Get a shield that boosts explosive damage and use that.  Amp shields are pretty much a waste of time.Melee is a bit of a joke unless you use a frost based weapon.  Turn them into an ice cube and shatter them.  Mobs run in, take a couple of swings then run away and dodge behind cover.  Don't look for a Brick type toe to toe slug fest, you will be disappointed.  Many of the mobs will NEVER melee, they just keep back peddling faster than you can move and shooting your♥♥♥♥♥all the while.  That and while in combat mobs seem to have a sixth sense about when to dodge.  Pull the trigger on them at point blank range, but before the shot goes off miraculously they dodge out of the way, THEN the shot goes off.  This effect will happen several times every fight.  Between this and having mobs jumping 1,000 yards, bullets passing through enemies with no damage, gets annoying very fast.Once again, this is not BL2, it's not even a good DLC for BL2.  It's bland, boring, unimaginative, characters lack all depth, story line is pointless and simple.  There's little or no comedy value.  It's just a "go nowhere do nothing" title.  Terribly terribly boring and monotonous. Almost no replayability, with the quests the way they are, it's more like work than fun.

number of helpful: 86 of 137 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												The content of a Borderlands 2 DLC being marketed and sold as a separate game.  It may be worth half the price, but that is still only half the asking price!  In addition, they intend to sell DLC on top of this DLC, making it a clear cash cow.  Perhaps it would be worth the money if this future DLC were a part of the package, but it is not.Several issues from Borderlands 2 are addressed, others left as-is, and new issue are introduced.  The content is nice, but not terribly deep --- similar to the Torgue or Tiny Tina DLCs.  The maps are, franky, proorly organised and oftentimes frustratingly buggy, with invisible walls more prevalent than past Borderlands experiences.  The side-quests are also horridly arranged, often having to reclear an area to get the mission, return to a second area you need to reclear to undertake the mission, then back fo the first location to, yup, reclear it again to turn in the mission!Cryo replacing Slag makes for a more interesting mechanic and Lasers are an interesting new weapon, though I could take or leave them personally.  The new vault hunters are interesting and seem well designed.  The plot fills a few gaps from Borderlands 2 and has a few laughs, though the humour is definitely worse than Borderlands 2.  The voice acting makes refernce to different Australian and English peoples, though most gamers will not get these references and many will find the dialogue incomprehensible.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												So I'm about 4 hours in and it's pretty clear how rushed this game was. Quest items flying away, cars randomly flipping, getting thrown around for no reason, even that inventory glitch from the last game where it would highlight the item on the other side of the screen is here now. They made your characters actually talk to the NPCs now which is nice but it seems like they just kind of added it later in the development as an afterthought. Athena especially has really unnatural dialog. Oh and there's tons of lol funny memes XD XD.A lot of people are saying that the game just feels like an expansion. It definitely feels like a stand alone given the work they had to do to make the new world and dialog and everything but the reused assets are pretty glaring. We once again get the same old buggy with a reskin, though thankfully the turrets are new this time. The Hyperion ammo boxes from the last game are practically the only ones you'll see. The generic human enemy types are still the same with a reskin. Even the jokes are reused, like the medical vending machine run by someone else says "don't die you good for business." There's lots of other examples I can't think of off the top of my head.The most obnoxuous part of the game is what the social justice warriors have done with it. Midgets have been renamed to "Lil people", Characters have to clarify that their jokes were sexist and that that's horrible. Hell the game has a profanity filter. Every curse word has to be bleeped out. If they were going for a T rating they might have an excuse for that but they got an M so there's no reason to filter out profanity like we're children. Oh and they ruined Moxxi.Overall if you're a die hard Borderlands fan and you're really, really desperate for new content then you'd probably like this but otherwise save your money and let Gearbox learn a lesson from this.

												This game was such a step down from previous Borderlands titles. It didn't even feel like a genuine Borderlands game, there was just so much wrong with it…The writing was terrible, the story created even more plot holes, 90% of the Legendary weapons are reused and tweaked from BL2 (and the tweaks aren't even good, they suck), nothing is farmable (mini-bosses that drop Legendaries don’t respawn), the loot system is very bad (you make too little money and can’t sell weapons for crap), all of the areas look pretty much the same, the unholy amount of side missions overwhelm the main campaign, the awful job of “representation” in the characters is disgusting, there are too many memes, etc.  This game is NOT worth its price. What little content it has is trash. The only good thing about it was Moxxi, but her alone is not enough to reclaim what sorry excuse for a Borderlands game this was.

												This game gets a lot of hate, mainly because people complain that it "doesn't have as much content as borderlands 2". Cool. This game still gives you hours upon hours of content. I'm coming up on 100 hours in this game and I've only played one character, and I'm not even done.PROS:If you're a completionist, like me, you'll spend a lot of time doing every mission and killling every enemy. All the characters actually have personalities (believe it or not). I've seen a lot of reviews slamming Janey Springs, but who else echos you and asks how you're doing? Hello? Some people complain about the legendary drop rate. I don't get why, I've seen 4 legendaries in the vending machines and I've picked up around 5 from bosses. Claptastic Voyage is one of the best DLC's ever. I mean, come on, your inside Claptrap. I've yet to play either DLC character, but I haven't heard anything bad about them yet.The game, unlike BL2, has a lot more skill points that you can use if you're playing in a group, such as having Saint heal teammates and Athena's shield healing teammates in a small circle and giving them second wind when down. CONS:You find that legendary weapon in Stanton's liver and you try to pick it up, but you realize: you aren't badass enough. 10/10 great game

												Disappointing if you were a fan of 1 and 2.Characters are weak. Dialogue is all tuned for Australians. Low gravity slows down gameplay. Loot system (as of my last playing) was garbage at the end game. Level design runs the gamut. There's a few decent areas, but a lot of them are poorly done.Story suffers from the "why see Titanic if you know how it ends" syndrome.If it seems like the review doesn't make sense because I've put in 90 hours of time, keep in mind that I was a pretty big fan of 2, and I put in 500+ hours on that. I wanted to love this game, but the spirit of it is gone.

number of helpful: 19 of 21 people (90%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 16
												Let's get this out of the way. The Pre-Sequel is easily the worst game in the Borderlands series. Design so often falls short of what it set out to do or works against itself. Despite that, it does enough things well enough to give it a cautious recommendation. If you know the gist of the series, you know what to expect here. (If you don't, start with Borderlands 2.) Pre-Sequel makes some changes from 2 but so many of them don't live up to expectations. Class builds are *extremely* synergy-oriented, which allows for some really cool, highly differentiated ways to play when you get them off the ground, but it takes a long time to get those Rube Goldberg machines working, to the point that you're probably most or all of the way through the first run of story mode before your character really "clicks" and you play meaningfully differently from anyone else. That's a long time to wait and pretty much pre-supposes that you're going to stick around for True Vault Hunter Mode (new game +) to see how the game is really meant to be played.These kinds of well-meaning design screwups are the norm. It sounds nice not to force each class into a particular gun type, for example, but when everyone on your team wants that cool new legendary that just dropped, you begin to see the wisdom of pigeon-holing each character into a different weapon group. It also causes problems in investing moonstones (TPS's counterpart to Eridium) to upgrade max ammo capacity. Athena, for example, doesn't care about the weapon type as much as the damage type, so you can easily find yourself spending moonstones upgrading shotguns, SMGs, assault rifles, AND lasers, needing a giant heap of stones every time you find a good gun in a previously unused family.The oxygen/slam system feels bolted on. Oxygen kits give you air that rarely matters in a vacuum and make it possible to make large jumps and powerful ground-slams that rarely work in atmosphere. The same vacuum/atmosphere split also makes incendiary weapons a lot more disappointing.And finally, the campaign is a dull slog and loot drops have been tuned to only really be rewarding when you defeat bosses, which makes discovering loot pretty disappointing and kitting out a high-quality murder machine mostly a game of boss-grinding. Lame. The "loot grinder" machine was supposed to add some more consistency to it but other than reliably getting you your legendary class mod, it mostly just eats purples for no reward.All that said, TPS shows off the best writing in the series, with a lot to reward attentive players who keep coming back. It does a great job of showing a sympathetic side to Borderlands 2's main foe Handsome Jack without muddying the waters; it's clear he's a bad guy, but we have a better understanding of how he got there. And while synergy-centered builds take *entirely* too long to get off the ground, they can be immensely rewarding. The pure anarchic joy of playing a Claptrap who explodes every time he shoots, hits a target, loses his shields, falls to the ground, or does pretty much anything at all, for example, is something that should delight powergamers and funhavers alike.  Overall, TPS is a deeply flawed game but there's enough moments of true greatness to justify giving it a try. Wait for a sale.

Posted: September 2, 2015
												Overall, I would reccomend this game cautiously. Despite the previous sentence, there are a few big things with the writing that are going to cause me to give this a negative review.-The game WILL ACTUALLY LECTURE YOU on issues like friendzoning and why if you think this you are a dark, terrible misogynist. To see this, in the Light Reactor quest in the beginning of the game return the Light Reactor to Janie Springs. Torgue will come in with the friendzoning claim, and then he later interjects how he has seen the light and is a much better person now.-There are many homosexual queer characters (Which is great! More representation is better! All for that!), however the game will rub it in your face constantly that they are queer, as if this is their defining trait. We get it, they like the same gender as they are, stop pushing it in my face constantly.-Game is comparatively shorter, only being 11 Chapters which will take you about 15 hours to beat (including 95% of sidequests)-You will constantly have to find oxygen, as about 80% of the game is outside where there is no atmosphere (speaking of, how are they outside without any suits to protect against the cold? No real explanation for that).There are also a few really awesome things I like about this Borderlands that should be included in all future games.-When doing quests, your character will actually hold a conversation with the quest giver (giving you more immersion as well as giving insight into the character's personality), and for me, this gives me a reason to play all the characters to hear what they all will say!-When doing a second playthrough (True Vault Hunter Mode or Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode), the game actually changes the dialog. The first playthrough is framed as Athena telling a Story to Lillith and company, and the Second playthrough is framed as Brick and Tiny Tina wanting to hear the story again, but more awesome. It makes a second playthrough feel much fresher.-The plot is pretty interesting, as it details Handsome Jack's descent from "Hero of Elpis" to "CEO Psychopath" in BL2.So with all this in mind, buy if you want. It's not a bad game by any means, but not really a great one either.

												The game itself is pretty good but it doesn't feel like a true Borderlands game to me, it's kinda hard to explain.Some-what of a break down:-The game has pseudo 3D movement, you can do a pseudo double-jump, or boost jump which allows you to hover for a few seconds, while in mid air, you can slam to the ground, dealing damage to enemies-They scrapped slag and replaced it with cryo, which is more useful being that it can freeze enemies in place and deal DoT-Almost all the vault hunters are recycled characters, Claptrap from the series as a whole, Athena, an NPC in the first Borderlands, then you have Nisha and Wilhelm(spoiler)optional and story bosses in BL2 respectively, then the 2 DLC characters are a Jack doppleganger and (only original one) Sir Hammerlock's sister-The story isn't as good as say, they second game but you see how Jack became the twisted mad-man (or moral grey-area hero) he is when you meet him in BL2-These are more nit-picks but the laser weapons I feel, most of them have to much kick to be lasers and the 'Scavs' aren't as interesting as their bandit counterparts, never got a chuckle from them unlike the banditsAll and all, could have used a lot of polish only pick up if you really like this series and or want to learn more about how Jack a villan and Handsome.

												There's no way I can recommend this for 60€. It's more of an expansion pack and should be priced accordingly. I've only played the first Borderlands but this is literally the same thing with a few new weapon types, locations, classes and enemies (although many of the enemies are kind of reskins). The new oxygen system doesn't provide anything to the game, it's only an annoyance and so is the low-gravity. Sure it's fun to float around for a while but not for the whole damn game. The moon makes me want to return to Pandora so bad. Also Claptrap's ultimate gives a random effect to the whole team and sometimes it's an annoying one like wasting all of the ammo for everyone. What on earth were they thinking when they made this skill in a co-op game? There's also way more backtracking than in the first Borderlands and the moon feels too big for its own good, you often get lost since the environments are confusing and pretty much always the same.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												"Do not take life too seriously. You will never get out of it alive."Set at a point between Borderlands and Borderlands 2, four aspiring Vault Hunters fight alongside Handsome Jack, witnessing his transformation into the ruthless tyrant people loved to hate in Borderlands 2, and inadvertently assisting with the rise of the Hyperion Corporation and his position within it.My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:- Atmosphere - Characters - Details - Tactical demand - Story - Combat & ControlsBased on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading:- S-Rank: excellent - A-Rank: very good - B-Rank: solid - C-Rank: satisfactory - D-Rank: inferiorIn case of an S-Rank rating, a game reference will be included in brackets as a token of my respect.Atmosphere: S-Rank(You make me so proud, minion. The way you're carrying on my fight against Sentinel and 5H4D0W-TP. It brings a tear to my eye. A figurative one, of course. The saline content of actual tears would rust my eye quicker than you could say 'tetanus shot’.)Characters: S-Rank(When Claptrap speaks, I feel my brain cells committing suicide one by one.)Details: S-Rank(Did I mention I don’t have a medical license?)Tactical demand: S-Rank(If it took more than one shot, you weren't using a Jakobs!)Story: S-Rank(With the Sentinel defeated, Jack enters the Vault and greets the Vault Hunters, but finds no item of value, other than a mysterious symbol floating midair. As he attempts to interact with it, the symbol then shows Jack a vision of the Warrior awakening. However, the vision is interrupted by Lilith, who phasewalks in front of him and punches through the Vault symbol, burning it onto Jack's face. She then disappears, leaving Jack behind with the Vault Hunters. Jack, having gone insane from the vision as well as Lilith's attack, swears vengeance on her, and all the "bandits" on Pandora. Realizing that the hero who once saved her on Helios is no more, Athena leaves Jack's employ.)Combat & Controls: S-Rank(1337 H4XZ00R!)To conquer all achievements of Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, you will most likely spend more than 100 hours. You have to play the single-player campaign several times, due to challenges like ‘That Helped, Right?’ and ‘Executioner’. ‘Challenger’ is a typical grind achievement.‘The Duelist’, ‘Mouth To Mouth’ and ‘Who you gonna call?’ are the only multiplayer achievement and quite simple to obtain.‘The Bigger They Are’ will take the most time, because it requires a character around level 50 or higher. The achievements of the two DLCs are straight forward and easy enough to get with a high level character.Achievement difficulty: 9 of 10Common: - Singleplayer [+2] - Multiplayer [+1]Special: - Challenger [+1] - The Bigger They Are [+1] - Executioner [+1] - That Helped, Right? [+1] - DLCs [+2]Estimated time for 100 % completion: +100 hoursChronology:Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel (PC)First-person shooter game(Science-Fiction) – 2014Borderlands 2 (PC)First-person shooter game(Science-Fiction) – 2012Borderlands (PC)First-person shooter game(Science-Fiction) – 2009

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												When you strip away all the layers of fluff, this game is fun in the same way Borderlands has always been fun. We play these games because shooting stuff is fun. We play these games because looting things is fun. Based on that alone, this game is great. Looking at the game as a whole, however, we basically have an over-priced, low-gravity Borderlands 2 expansion. Pros:+ Shooting stuff.+ Players are addressed by name...sometimes.+ Player characters have dialogue. (Though Athena is like a robot...)Cons:- The humour is realllllly lacking. They're trying way too hard, here. There are some moments you might get a chuckle out of, but for the most part the game isn't all that funny. - Players are still addressed as "Vault Hunter" from time to time, and quite often the game just always assumes you're in a group. (When playing single player, being addressed as a group of people just seems weird.)- The novelty of MOONPHYSICS wears off pretty quickly. It makes the entire game feel slower.- There is a LOT of backtracking.- Quality of loot is mostly awful.I want to say "there's a lot more to it", but there isn't. If you love Borderlands, you'll find things to enjoy about this game, but wait for it to go on sale, and wait for some DLC to come out. As it is, $90 for the base game and future DLC is far too much to pay for what's there. $60 for Game+Season Pass would be far more reasonable. (Even then, there isn't even $30 worth of content here in the base game.)

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I really, really want to love this game and give it a thumbs up, but ultimately I have to recommend that you wait to buy this game until it's on a VERY good sale, or avoid purchasing it at all. The game is mechanically almost identical to Borderlands 2--the only new mechanic is mildly interesting, but does add annoyance to the game. You have a slot for an oxygen canister now, and when your oxygen runs out on the moon, you need to quickly find an airvent, or airlock to enter. Since there is oxygen every few feet, this really doesn't add difficulty to the game. However, the plus side to the no-oxygen atmosphere is the ability to jump high with the low gravity and slam back down to the ground, injuring enemies. You can also use oxygen to boost your floating in the air.The game itself feels short, and so I think it should have been a $20 DLC---it is certainly not the quality or length of what we've come to expect from a Borderlands game. The world feels rather empty at times, the enemies repetitive, and there isn't much difficulty even to the bosses. They're just bullet-sponges. There are humorous moments in the game, but not many. The characters are sadly forgettable (not that they can ever top Tiny Tina). There are what I presume to be pop culture references, but this game was made by 2K Australia and as an American player they were mostly lost on me. If you haven't played the Borderlands 2 DLCs, I strongly STRONGLY recommend those over the Pre-sequel. They're the most fun you can find in the Borderlands series and won't set you back $60. Even on sale, I wouldn't purchase this game unless you're comfortable expecting it to be a sub-par continuation to the series.

content:
Posted: March 3
												It's a good game, don't get me wrong. If you liked Borderlands 2, but didn't really reach endgame (IE Max level, UVH OP 8) then you'll like this one just as much. There's not too much difference, save for new mechanics and different characters. But the game hasn't really got any worthwhile endgame content compared to Borderlands 2, so if you like it enough to get through to max level, don't expect to stick around afterwards unless you wanna start over on a new character... It's not worth it. The game has quite a lot of content, albeit less than Borderlands 2, and while it definitely feels like you're playing Borderlands 2 in a new map with some new gimmicks for the most part, it's not quite as good. I've seen people complain about drop rates, but that's just a Borderlands standard - you're pretty much going to have times where you'll have absolutely nothing at your level and are having problems as a result. It's a mainstay of the game and it kinda drives you to actually look around a bit more, take more time to notice things and to find the places where you can actually get loot. But I digress. There's plenty of sidequests, though a lot of them are admittedly 'go here, talk to this guy, go here' kinds of things, with not a lot of them being particularly memorable or giving out very good items. Borderlands 2 was better about it because there were plenty of unique guns you could get exclusively from quests that were really good (fibber for anarchy gaige anybody?) but TPS doesn't do as much of that. I'll say that there's a bit better balancing in this than in BL2, namely in the previously mentioned Gaige build being able to destroy pretty much everything with zero effort. But naturally some characters are stronger in different ways than others. An example, your best tank is a girl who's pretty much immune to damage 75% of the time. And she absolutely destroys things at the same time that she's taking all this damage. Back to the aforementioned endgame, though, because this is what made this game so bad for most of its playerbase. There are only three raid bosses. If you don't count the seasonal raid boss that replaces one of them. Two of them are completely unimaginative in that they're literally EXACT COPIES of the final boss - not even reskinned, literally exact copies - but buffed up with more health, damage, and stronger minions. And even buffed they don't compare to the all-encompassing power of Terramorphous prior to the UVH releases, and how good he was for making friends at the time since the means of cheesing him wasn't discovered yet and he was impressive, both in difficulty and in size. Terramorphous was one of the first bosses in the game that would smack you in the face and tell you to bring friends. There is nothing like that in TPS. The closest thing is Iwajira, and he's not exactly hard even without cheesing him. Which yes there is a place you can go that works much like Terramorphous', but you have to work a bit harder to get to it. But even that guy doesn't compare to the raid bosses in Borderlands 2. With the lore-required removal of Slag as a combat element, given that it predates Borderlands 2, they had to dial things back significantly in the difficulty department because you couldn't abuse the damage buff of slag. So TVH and UVH ended up being 'replay the game with a few new enemies and others buffed, but it's basically no more difficult.' Kinda like old school Diablo 2 and 3. Drops are better, experience is better, but otherwise the game doesn't change much. Which is unfortunate because with the introduction of Cryo damage and how it works, it's very possible to freeze-lock about 90% of the game's enemies with no effort. With the right character, you can do this starting at level 3. There's enemies that can't be frozen or resist cryo, and bosses by and large can't be either, with a few exceptions. But most of the enemies are bandits who like to jump around. And what does an ice cube do when it hits the ground usually? That's right, it shatters. Flying enemies that can be frozen are cake. Bandits that jump around are cake. Bandits that you can see are cake. Cryo makes almost everything far too easy. Especially if you're interested in running a melee build, though admittedly I haven't found any quite as ridiculous as Zero's.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												This game is not bad but not really good either. Borderlands 2 was so much better. The missions in Pre-Sequel is not creative, unique and fun like they were in Borderlands 2. In this game it's a lot of running back and forth, pick up a thing and deliver it, go from point a to b and then back to a again. It becomes tedious and boring. The grinding parts are not fun. Pre-Sequel also feels more uptight than Borderlands 1 and 2. But I think that the space-themed setting is great and the graphics are beautiful. Sadly, the story wasn't especially gripping or interesting. I hoped it would get more interesting the longer I played but no. They could have made Jack a bit more "likeable". Yes he is the bad guy but come on, give him a bit more depth. He feels one-sided and stereotypical. It's boring and predictable. I don't really see a reason as to why I should help him with his missions. I have played through the storyline as Nisha but she felt one-sided too. Where is the depth?   Is it worth playing? Maybe. It got the same action-filled, hectic hyper-pace as the other Borderlands games. It's open world-ish and a fun co-op game. But I can't recommend it because the quests and story are meh and the characters feels flat.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												This is one of those games that seems to be a great game at its core but is weighed down by millions of flaws piled on top of it. The combat in this game is great, the low gravity and double jumping makes the combat (especially the boss fights) really cool. It also has the best selection of weapons ever in a borderlands game adding new laser weapons and overall better weapon aesthetics.The bad part? It's poorly written. This game was made by 2k Australia so by extension it was written by Australians. Now I have nothing against Australians but because it was written by people from a different culture with different humour all the funny content from previous borderlands games seems to be replaced with a big inside joke which I'm not a part of. Even humour aside the story is dull and I find myself not caring about any of the characters and it seems neither do the devs because scripted dialog from other sources commonly cuts off the main story. The game quickly turns into a repetative cycle of go here kill this with the story progression and questing that feels straight out of an MMO.So as far as gameplay goes, its pretty good. But the bad writing makes me shut it off after about an hour of playing.edit: It also doesn't like AMD graphics cards, I get frame drops down to 35 on an i7 4790k and 390x so be careful.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												I have enjoyed my time playing so far. The writing and humor is a bit lacking compared to Borderlands 2 so far, but there is no argument that the formula works. The setting and locations are good, the music is notably less dubstep (good or bad depending on your tastes), and the new gun/elemental types are a fitting addition to the arsenal. The most interesting change for me is that your character has a voice now. Playing Nisha and hearing her interact with npcs adds a nice bit of immersion.The combat itself makes it hard to ever play the previous titles again. It feels more dynamic and action-oriented. Less cover and more gliding through air to land a fiery buttstomp. The O2 mechanic isn't as stressful as I feared, although you can and will run out at times, It won't spell death. Many forms of refilling exist whether killing enemies or interacting with devices or air geysers. Plus there is nothing more rewarding than shooting an enemies helmet and watching him struggle and suffocate.The loot looks great so far. I found a chest which required 40 moonstone which I paid and got 4 epics. I also found the famed Bonus Package grenade from BL2 at level 10 which is always welcome in my collection. I'm looking forward to testing out the grinder once I unlock it, but I think that will greatly affect how we view the loot. I hope there are a few raid bosses to farm at 50. Happy hunting!

content:
Posted: March 25
												The first Borderlands was a surprise for myself. I typically don't like dungeon crawlers but, combined with FPS mechanics and a unique personality, I thoroughly enjoyed Borderlands. When the sequel came out, I thought it addressed most of my complaints with the first game and is still one of the funniest games I have ever played; I played and loved the crap out of it.With the first 2 games, I didn't want them to end. With this game, I couldn't wait for it to be over.This game bothered the hell out of me. I would say it actually tarnished my enjoyment of the series itself. It was such a shadow of its predecessors. It really felt like 2K Australia had no idea what made the first 2 games special. Everything felt like a ripoff of itself – from the vault hunters to the supporting cast to the humor. And it bears repeating: this game is not funny. Some of the lines – as they were written – COULD have MAYBE been funny, but the voice acting (and direction, most likely) was terrible. This has nothing to do with the accents – I think non-American accents are a good change of pace. The problem was that there was no personality in the characters or the delivery; they never felt like characters – just people reading a script. It was like the writers collected a list of funny things from the other games and said, “Lets just do that again! Super funny, right?!” Super disappointing. The gravity mechanics were okay at best. What they did, more than anything, was turn Borderlands into a slow, imprecise platformer. I rarely found the slam damage helpful versus weapons (you can't jump ON people for damage, just next to them?!). I died more from jumping where I shouldn't than I ever did from enemies. Not my idea of a good time. There were so many once-thought-extinct annoyances like invisible walls, tiny inclines that you couldn't walk over, floors that aren't actually solid, and see-though spaces that you can't shoot through. Apparently, this game was designed in 1996. I kept saying/screaming to myself, “Did ANYONE playtest this thing?!?!”While I can't definitively say that all Borderlands fans wouldn't like this game – it's obviously got its supporters – coming from this Borderlands fan, I just can't recommend it. Maybe it's more palatable with 3 other people; I've primarily played solo. If you're a crazy-mega-fan (I'm a fan, but didn't really dabble much in any UVHM/post-game content), you'll likely find things to enjoy here. It's more Borderlands, but mostly in name only. Temper your expectations.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												This is going to be the most difficult review I have ever done, but I belive it will help you to make an educated decision about this game. Please read the full review.The game is great when it comes to the technical side. It is very well optimised, I belive it will run great on any PC (but don't quote me on that). The graphics are great and the sounds and music are on point. Borderlands 1 was felt like a console port however the Pre-Sequel feels great no issues here.However this game is funny and great but it is not for everyone. This game feels like an expensive Borderlands 2 DLC (please just hang on). Most Borderlands fans will tell me "No, you are worng", "You don't understand Borderlands", "You are not meant to play alone but with friends". I know that and I did play with friends the game is great fun. However every minute I was playing the pre-sequel I felt I could have just Pressed new game in Borderlands 2 or just keept playing Borderlands 2. While this game does offer some new features, it just feels like a reskin of Borderlands 2. This is why this review is so difficult for me, I belive this game is great, but I just can't recommend it.I can recommend this game but only for these reasons:- If you really care about the Borderlands narrative/story- If you are a big fan of Borderlands- If you have never played Borderlands 2- If you don't care that you are playing the same game just with a different story and some changes.   E.G. like FIFA or COD games.If you don't fit into one of these categories I advise you not to buy this game. The leap from Borderlands 1 to 2 was pretty significant. However this time it is not. True you get new characters, some more weapon choices, a new Oxygen mechanic, weapon crusher/combiner and a different story. But the game feels the exact same as Borderlands 2. That might be perfect for some people. For others you might just feel like, I could have just saved my money and continued playing Borderlands 2 instead. Because of this I can't recommend the game. However a lot of people will disagree. Therefore before you buy this game ask yourself: "Do I care if the game is simmilar or do I love Borderlands so much I don't care?" "Do I mind playing the exact same game, just with some changes e.g. like COD.?" If your answer is no to either of the questions you should buy the game, you will most probaly completley love it, if not you might want to reconsider.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												This game...I really wanted to like it. I pre-ordered it because I like 1 and 2 so much. That's a mistake I won't be repeating though. The game opens incredibly strong with a great hook in the form of its initial level, and then it opens up into the big wide world complete with vehicles and side quests and quirky characters.This is the moment in the other Borderlands games and good open world RPGs when the game usually becomes awesome. But for The Pre-Sequel it's actually the reverse. This is when the game gets bad. The middle 80% is just...boring. The side quests are mostly simple fetch or kill affairs, with little to no importance related to the main story, and certainly requiring no real decisions or strategy to complete. And the bulk of the main story itself feels like a loosely tied together series of side quests.I found the new characters to be annoying to the point of turning the audio off and relying on subtitles (Pickle in particular). It just seems like the character design was much worse overall than the other Borderlands. And the writing in general was much worse. It wasn't funny. Most of the jokes were just dumb.My single biggest complaint by far though is the leveling system. It was purposefully slowed down from Borderlands 2 to make the game take longer. And wow, it shows. You take longer to level, longer to get better loot. And because weapon quality is related to level it means that for most of your first play through that even just firing a gun is a challenge because you're more worried about controlling the huge amounts of spray than actually hitting anything. I was extremely frustrated by this reduced pacing at every turn.The graphics also do not do well on a modern system. The engine is dated, and it shows.I went into this knowing it was milking the series, but I was still confident it would be that loud, crazy fun experience that the first two games were. There are glimpses of that bookending the game, but it's too little too late compared to all the exhausting hours in the middle.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												That 24.9 hours? That's my total playtime. I've done almost all the quests that the game has to offer (bullet sponge raid bosses aside). I think at 60 hours, I'd done "most" of the content in Borderlands 2, a game which, for the same price, has more areas, more story, more quests, everything.It's more Borderlands, yeah, but at $60 for a game that's less than half the size of its $60 predecessor, it's definitely a bit of a letdown. Likewise, most of the DLC is about new characters rather than places to go.I will say that Athena herself is super fun to play as, the butt-slam mechanic is cool, and zero gravity exotifies the gameplay in a cool way. I enjoy the core of what's there, but the shooting mechanics haven't been improved from the previous games (and I personally think there's lots of room for improvement in terms of enemy feedback, etc).Then there's the writing. Pre-Sequel feels like a game with an agenda. I've never felt this way about the series before, but some complaints from one of the writers about how people clearly didn't like a character because of her sexuality or her being a girl, combined with some other stuff in the game, has me feeling a bit off.Personally, I feel that the character in question is a bad character--she constantly badgers the player for attention, yet the game provides no way for the player to give that attention, giving impression that, within the narrative, the player char doesn't WANT to give it. More importantly, a well-liked and trusted NPC from previous games, Moxxi, constantly treats the character with derision and annoyance, confirming for the players that yes, this is a character who engages in unhealthy sexual harassment.That on its own would just be a weird disconnect between the game's author and its audience. But the game takes it further.Most of the insane mission givers in the game are men. Scratch that, I think it's all of them. Whether it's a guy who blows himself up or a guy who wants to kill his wife or a guy who enslaves a female computer 'cause he can't get any, the men of The Pre-Sequel are generally crazy and bad. The only male playable character at launch is a man so obsessed with machines that he becomes one. So the characters the game launched with two white women and two robots.TPS' women fare much better: it's the female computer who rolls her eyes at the men in the game, heck, if I remember right, she's the character who makes the stereotypically huffy "men" comments in TPS. The villain, Zarpedon, is the most sympathetic in the series--she is doing something we try to stop, but she's doing it to save the universe. She also wants to pay for her daughter's health. We're the bad guys. The woman trying to rid herself of her psychotic husband apparently runs a gang and, like Zarpedon, runs this gang with matriarchal efficiency.And this could all be accident, but it feels like agenda, and one that downplays equality in favor of the "women are wonderful" effect--the idea that women are great and can do little, if any wrong, and men all suck in comparison to them. This game feels as if it disrespects women because it feels the need to put men down, rather than let the women stand on their own. Like... it feels as if the game thinks women aren't good enough to stand up against great male characters, so it has to tip the scales in the women's favor by giving us really crappy men instead.Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel fails to give us any equality, and in doing so, ends up treating everyone like crap. Women with disingenuity, men as targets of aggression.Literally the only "nutty" women I could think of were the ones who ran some silly "people's liberation army" thing. Borderlands 2 felt a lot more equal than this, with cool women as both psychotic villains and admirable allies. At this point, I'd like to say "whatever, it's more Borderlands," but it's not even that. It's less Borderlands than you're used to. The tweaks feel like they'd be right at home in a DLC rather than something one might expect of a sequel. While I think they're vital additions to the game, I just wish I had a more substantial, better-written game to play than this. Definitely a disappointment.

content:
Posted: February 27
												This really is a "Meh" game. Its hard to really think of this as a Borderlands game due to all the ways the game heavy handedly tries to be cleaver, and fails. As a looter-shooter though, it is effective.But first, the start of the game is very, very, very, very slow. Forced to dive into the new mechanic of low grav and O2, you are plunged into Space Australia. A thing the game wants to be abundantly clear about. Its slow, tedious and a chore to get past till you get back on the station. But thats when the game starts to feel better.The characters/classes are all fun to play as. As in previous Borderlands games, there are very clear stronger and weaker characters. However that doesnt deminish the fun of each one. They play as unique as you would expect, and the voice lines and interactions are spot on. The weapons are not as expansive as you would like. Many are just carry overs from Borderlands 2, with the addition of Lasers and the Cryo mod. This really makes the game feel less like an addition to the series, and more of a long, expensive DLC to Borderlands 2. For the story, its solid. Seeing how Jack gets to be the psycho he is, is quite a fun story. As fun as it is, its too short. Much like in the previous games, a lot of your time is spent on side missions. This isnt typically a problem, but the main story is quite short leaving you to complete is sooner then wanted. Overall, 6/10. The game failed to hook me in the first 4 hours of the game, lending itself to poor design. However, once past the first few hours, the game picks up and is much more enjoyable.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												*STORIES AT THE BOTTOM*I need to start this review with an apology... an apology to myself.I am sorry that I forced myself to like this game as much as I did... I really am. I really, REALLY, REEEEAAAAAAAAALLY wanted to like this game. Unfortunately, the game is just too bugged and feels too... boring.The low gravity thing is a gimick and makes the game feel slow despite the fact there are low gravity boosters and whatnot. This is Borderlands. I don't play to go slow. I play to kill things mindlessly while mindless things die and drop loot. This mechanic brings out the worst aspects of the game and reveals what the Borderlands series really is; a grindfest. The oxygen management system is pointless and feels like more of a chore than it does a method of survival. The UI is the EXACT same as Borderlands 2, leaving me to wonder if this should have been a major DLC update or not.Oh, and don't get me started on the AI. The AI is just horrible. Too many times have I seen enemies just face eachother while I shoot them. Too many times have I seen them run RIGHT PAST ME while I shoot at them. Again, I have played the game for 3 HOURS while writing this review and so far I have seen so much wrong with the game.Again, I need to stress that I LOVED the second one. I thought the second Borderlands fixed a lot of issues the first one had.As for bugs, I have run into countless nonsense bugs, like quests not starting, quests not triggering unless I do something very specific (for example having to leave the bullet and reenter it despite the fact I was already on the quest marker in the beginning of the game). There were DOZENS of moments where this happened... IN 3 HOURS OF GAMEPLAY! There are graphical issues with the cut scenes, like the cut scenes having these strange lines and deviations throughout the scene.Driving just sucks. It is horrible. I dunno if there was a coding error or what but it's very difficult to drive in this game. You either don't turn sharply enough or you turn too sharply. It's difficult to gain acceleration so you will miss a lot of jumps. In fact, that's the main reason I've died while playing this game, my damn car wouldn't clear the jump despite the fact that I have done it before. The car just won't gain speed. At this point I just completely skip out on driving in this game.I will keep playing, because I feel like there might be something in here worth playing. However, for newcomers to the series, I say play Borderlands 2. Something needs to change. I am not sure what does, but something does. Skip this one until the issues have been fixed. Even after the issues have been fixed I'd still be weary.EDIT:So playing 1 more hour and I've noticed even more bugs. Enemies will literally spawn right in front of you, more horrible AI, invisible walls everywhere, getting stuck in place while running... and just try to watch Jack while he's on an elevator. This game needs to be patched. I am shocked this game was released in the state it is in now.EDIT: STORY TIME (will post as I get them)!I may as well tell stories of the silly things I see. See this section for stories and things I see!-I just had a lunitic stand in front of me and attempt to butt slam me over and over again. I just stood there. I wish I had a capturing software. He did it for a good two minutes until I killed him.-Just saw a Badass Lil Skiv fight other bandits. Bandits didn't respond to it. Go little badass, go.-Walked up to a raider. He walked right past me. Never attacked me. Moved around him. Jumped all over. Shot next to him then he and all the other raiders engaged me.-Hate low gravity. Makes gathering loot a hastle. Kill a badass, everything goes flying everywhere and I need to spend more time than I should picking it all up.-Enemies really seem to hate Kraggons. Whenever there is one nearby, they all focus on them, despite the fact that they're jumping around and I'm shooting at them.-Just had an epic level item fall through the map. Yes. I'm mad. It was a pistol and I'm using pistols.-Shot a guy with a newly acquired rocket launcher in a low gravity room. His body went flying around at about 1000mph and then got stuck in a wall. Shortly after he flew to the other side of the room then went through the world.*MAY AS WELL PUT TIME AND DATES FOR THIS NONSENSE*-October 15, 2014 1520: Just fell through the world...-October 15, 2014 1530: Just realized that Tork Swarmlings (take about one shot to kill) grant 50% more exp than a Skav (takes about 5 shots to kill). BRB gonna farm some Torks.-October 15, 2014 1550: ...Just look at my screenshots... This AI...-October 18, 2014 2022: Your character talks too much and often makes no sense. For example, why is my character talking about looking at a map when I'm in the inventory? Why is my character talking about choosing skills when I'm looking at the map? Why won't my character just shut up?-October 18, 2014 2248: Walked in front of a soldier. He just walked right past me too. I guess they gave up...-October 18, 2014 2253: A Tork jumped through the wall then attacked me though that same wall then jumped out of the wall and attacked me again.-October 20, 2014 1152: There is a mission where you need to download AI into a loader. You need to defend it while it stays in place and downloads said AI. Well, the loader started to walk around after it was attacked. Then it was frozen by an Ice Marine. Now it's permanently stuck and it won't allow me to continue with the mission. Check out the screenshots.-October 20, 2014 1937: An invisible wall just killed me. Like I was jumping from platform to platform and then I just suddenly die. I didn't fall. I just straight up die.-October 20, 2014 2007: So I killed an enemy while I was down and I didn't come back to life. WTF?

												Not as good as the previous games.Pro's:--------- New heroes are good and unique. I played Athena and had a lot of fun with her abilities.- The addition of cryo as a new element that freezes enemies is pretty cool.- Laser guns were my go to weapon type, they are a fun addition.- Oz kits were not hindering, very rarely did you actually run out of oxygen.- Slamming is a cool mechanic and I used it a lot.Con's:--------- Main campaign was too short and too easy, we finished the main storyline in 11 hours and I died only 2 times without getting a second wind because of something stupid, not even in big fights. Now we just ran out of ammo in difficult fights.I bought it on sale for a little over $4 and I liked it but I would not pay full price for this one.

number of helpful: 174 of 308 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Long post, sorry...I tried to love this game. I tried as hard as I have ever tried. As a huge fan of the Borderlands series, This game looked like the best thing to ever happen. I watched every ad with wide eyes, and preordered the second I was able to. I even bought the season pass, as Borderlands 2 more than delivered on its price for its season pass. When the Presequel finally came out, I had booked several days off worked, stocked up on food, and prepared to delve into another adventure into the borderlands universe. Barely an hour later I was standing away from my PC, shaking my head, and regretting my blindness.This game is bad. Not legendary 'bad', just bad. From gimmicky mechanics which interfere with your gameplay (Goodbye rare weapon headed for low orbit!), to ridiculously unintuitive level design (Because instant death pits immediately outside of vehicle spawns are fun, right?), to length padding of the worst kind (Hey, you got the thing! Now go get three more from the other corners of the map!). However, this isn't the worst part, not at all. Both previous games had their glitches and faults. However, what they did have was fun. Hours upon hours of childlike fun, especially Borderlands 2. Even the worst areas in the game (I'm looking at you Sawtooth cauldron, padding based level that you are!) are still enjoyable, although perhaps a bit tedious. This is where Borderlands: The Presequel fails. It simply is not FUN to play. Oh sure, it has interesting gimmicks, such as low gravity, Oz kits, Laser weapons, and plenty of eye candy, but this isn't what makes a game fun. A game is fun when its has honed gameplay mechanics, well designed levels, creative enemies, good music, enjoyable characters, and passable writing. The presequel has none of these. - The gameplay mechanics are pretty much ripped right from borderlands 2, icons and all, with virtually no change at all, bar their gimmick of gravity and air; you control exactly the same on the ground. The mission are padded beyond belief, resulting in grindfests which will last ages. Get used to hearing the phrase "A few more components", as it is used a lot, along with "wait we have to go here first". Metroid style backtracking in a FPS...- The levels are a bunch of interconnected linear paths of which you will be backtracking along most of during the story missions (cause backtracking is one of FPS gamer's most beloved mechanics!). And yes, I said story missions. Not side missions sending you back to somewhere, but straight up backtracking in th mandatory story missions...- The enemies are almost completely reskins with one or two quirks. The soldiers are just hyperion soldiers with more health and medics, the scavs are just bandits with jetpacks, the Torks are just spiderants with corrosive attacks and wallclimbing, the Rathyds are just Rakk with a more sustained attack, and the infected are just rats with helmets (Because rats weren't hard enough to deal with, and now they have headshot immunity!). The few enemies that aren't reskins, like the Shuggaths, are ridiculous. Huge floating sacks with tentacles with elemental attacks. Then the game begins not even reskining enemies! Yup, straight up throwing Stalkers at you with no explanation other than "R&D department" (Because again, everyone loved the guys, right?). Even a thresher makes an appearance!- The music is uninspired, and a very poor followup to the soundtrack mastery of Borderlands 2. The entire score is par for the course in a sci-fi based game, and has no high points, just a mediocre soundtrack to your mediocre journey.- The characters... Oh god... Every lovable trait in any returning characters has been scrubbed away to make room for the Memes, such as Moxxi, who is now only innuendo, instead of the clever character from Borderlands 2, who had surprising levels of depth to her.. There's no originality in the new characters either, just a shallow representation of a single character trait, which is then amplified to truly irritating levels! The Australian character is a mechanic/homosexual/story-writer/blackmarket-dealer, who has almost no relevance past the first few missions, and is a poor followup character to Sir Hammerlock, whose role she fills. The British kid is... British. A pickpocket/junk-dealer/information-dealer/salvager who ends up WELL overstaying his welcome in one mission which has the most padding out of all the ones I played and only serves to remind you that you're not done yet! Jack is the one who has suffered the worst, though, coming across as a jerk right from the beginning and only getting worse as the game advances. Wasn't the game supposed to be his fall from grace, the story of his transformation from decent leader to the tyrannical dictator that we all loved to hate? Well, he starts as an♥♥♥♥♥ and stays that way the whole game.- The writing is uninspired, lazy, and predicable. Plot points are forecast way in advance (Hmmm, an AI companion? Hope shes not gonna go crazy!), are often lackluster, and most often serve to make the game's characters worse. Again, Handsome Jack just become less and less enjoyable, and his actions aren't justifiable in the least throughout the game.In the end, The Presequel is a disapointment. It fails to live up to its hype, and even its previous incarnations. The gameplay is slow, the lootdrops even wors than BL2, the bosses tiresome, the vaunted GRINDER being just another moneysink... The only things in this game that work flawlessly are the elemnts that they ripped from BL2's chest. Heck in some portions of the levels you can see that they would import loot containers, but not change how some of them looked, resulting in a design clash that rips you right out of the experience. My advice? Don't buy this. I know it looks shiny and crazy, but thats on the surface. It is dull grindfest on the bottom that somehow takes the Borderlands Formula and makes it boring. Play Borderlands 2. Play Borderlands. Don't play this. Maybe once the price on a 75% sale, but even then, think carefully.Final veredict: 5/10 (only for the stuff ripped from BL2)

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28
												This is my first Borderlands game, and to be honest, I think it's awesome. Now, some people might think that starting right in the middle of something can be confusing, and I agree (I did have to do some reading about some of the characters), but even then, the game does a great job at storytelling, since you get to know the characters and all. While I wasn't too familiar with the Borderlands universe, I did know about Handsome Jack, and it's nice to see how a person with noble goals descends into villainy; and it isn't just a "he's a good guy who becomes crazy with power", there's different events throughout the storyline that start showing his true nature.Like I mentioned above, the storytelling is pretty good. The main story seems somewhat short when you think about it, with a few missions that feel like filler; mostly because of all the walking around, not so much the writing, which is great, with lots of hilarious dialogues, and some serious ones when the situation demands it. If there's something I enjoyed about the writing is that; it can easily go from the characters making jokes and such, to a really dark moment, and it still feels natural. The game also has tons of side missions, which unlock as you progress through the storyline, and offer some more gameplay (as well as some great rewards, depending on the mission).The level design is mostly good, with great open areas, and some really cool visuals. Still, there's a few sections (mostly during main story missions) that feel like they were designed in order to extend the game time, as there's lots of going back and forth in order to open a few doors. Also, while most of the large maps have vehicles for you to use, there's one near the end of the game that's really big as well, but doesn't have any vehicle station, which means you must walk around.Now let's talk weapons. From what I know of Borderlands, this game is practically Diablo with guns, or a shoot 'n' loot, as the game says. That means that a great deal of the gameplay involves killing enemies, finding better weapons and gear, and so on, until you can defeat stronger enemies, to get even better loot, all the way up until you finally get a broken♥♥♥♥♥combination of loot, which you'll then proceed to show off on the Internet. It's a good system, I'd say, especially when you defeat some tough boss and see all that sweet, sweet loot dropping from them. And the variety is impressive: from pistols and submachine gus, to laser weapons with different elemental effects, not to mention the legendaries and uniques, which have their own quirks (I love Miss Moxxi's Vibra-Pulse, for example).The soundtrack is mostly ambient sound, which changes depending on the situation (combat or exploration), it's good enough, but it's not something you'll pay a lot of attention to.As far as playable characters go, there's four of them, at least in the vanilla game: Athena, Wilhelm, Nisha and Claptrap. I haven't played Wilhelm and Nisha that much, but their skill trees seem interesting. When it comes to Athena, she's easily my favourite character, her Aspis shield is great for soaking up damage and throwing it back at the enemies, and one of her skill trees greatly improves elemental damage. And Claptrap, well, he's fun to play, but the randomness of his action skill can sometimes be frustrating.Well, I think I've written a fair bit about Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. There's a lot more I could write, but this review looks long enough. To sum everything up: get this game, because it's awesome.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Back when the game was released I was on the fence on getting this. Until it recently went on sale for 70% off that gave me the thought of "Why the heck not?" because I like the Borderlands lore. Before playing this game, I already played all 1, 2 and even the Tales from the Borderlands but only when I finished the point & click game I came to realized that Pandora is an interesting world to discover. Additionally, as the credits rolled I got surprised that the supporting actor for Troy Baker[en.wikipedia.org] was Chris Hardwick[en.wikipedia.org]! Then I thought "That was more awesome!". It left me wanting more to discover the Borderlands series. So here I am ready to review this game...The presentation never fails to look badass like it always do since the first BL, it just as explosive, bloody, funny & dynamic which is all exciting for me to anticipate another epic adventure! But upon my understandings on what makes it great also gave me the same on the other side of the coin of some sort. What I like the most about the game are…The unchanged elements which made it fun and Borderlands the way it should like gunplay, looting, the hilariousness, the colors, the graphics, the skill trees of each class, the dialogues, the co-op, the phasing & the boss fights. Returning NPCs from two previous titlesSome hilarious missions & side missionsThe traveling time between places does not take that long anymore unlike the two previous gamesAdditional combat elements like the stomping is funZero Gravity controls takes me to some hard-to-reach placesInteresting players like Claptrap, Nasha & Wilhelm (+ Jack as DLC)What I do not like are… The lack of music to set the theme (I miss the western theme-like of the music) The bugs (but I never encountered any game breaking ones)The good plots from the game wasn’t as epic as the previous oneI guess the Borderlands 2 was the peak of its time and where else will you go if and when you reached to the top but down right? I’m not necessarily saying that this game is bad in fact it is fun and a very good one at best. However, it does not have that dynamic impact from Borderlands 2 as well as the music from the game. In the end, this game is worth playing but to those who played BL2 and expect more, please tone your expectations down and HAVE FUN.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												As an avid Borderlands fan, there was pretty much no chance of me not buying BL:TPS. However, I cannot in good concience recommend it to anyone who isn't a huge enough fan to have already bought it by this point. Just go grab BL2 for wicked cheap during a sale.When the price drops, you should totally buy the crap out of it, but for $60, absolutely not worth it. Shoot for $20 ($25 with season pass) like it was during the summer sale.Why would a diehard Borderlands lover like myself tell you to avoid this till the price drops?Feels like a big BL2 DLC    Only a few mechanics have changed. Sure, we've got the Grinder and low gravity, but what else is there that isn't just an older concept with a new coat of paint? New vehicles? Scarlett's. Moon rocks? Eridium. Moon chests? Dice chests from Tiny Tina's. The vast majority of the weapons are the same. The same UI flaws exist (including a new one, the 4-vehicle Moon Zoomy interface is terrible, half off the screen). The list goes on and on.Beta quality    With 24 hours of gametime since the release, I've suffered at least 5 crashes. Yes, Borderlands saves often, but not often enough to prevent me having to clear those baddies several times. I also had 2 failable quests instantly fail when going through area-based checkpoints. In one, I killed a special thresher and took the elevator up into a shop. The quest promptly failed, citing my having (not actually) died, conveniently locking me in until I reloaded the game. A release quality game should not have these issues.All that aside, I do rather enjoy the game.Low Gravity    Gravity actually adds a lot to the immersion of the game - variable gravity based on area adds an element of realism to buildings. Low gravity allows for a lot more interesting maneuvering and varied combat. Don't stop there, though, because low gravity allows you to really get into every nook and cranny, really allowing you to appreciate the beauty of the entire world by boost jumping all over it. Butt slams are another great low gravity mechanic, making it easy to deal with many small enemies at once - in my opinion, a rather annoying (and common) situation.The Grinder    Combine, reuse, recycle. Got old or junk gear? No worries, just combine and upgrade. Want a specific legendary? No, you don't need to grind the boss that drops it any more, just any two junk legendaries and a purple of the right type, then repeat till you get what you want. It's great but almost feels too easy, something I'm sure irks many of the BL2 fanbase.
