content:
Posted: April 20
												Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is the "third" installment in the Borderlands series, and personally has to be my favorite. As someone that has completed Borderlands 1 about 14 times on the PS3, completed Borderlands 2 on the PS3 PS4 and PC for a total of about 20 times, and completed Pre-Sequel on the PS4 first, I've become exahusted with the series. It's why I didn't bother trying to 100% the achievements for this game. But why do I say this is my favorite one of the series? I'll explain.Pre-Sequel takes place after the first game and before the second game, and Athena is re-telling the events of the Pre-Sequel. (So it kind of is after the second game...) It shows the events up to how Handsome Jack and how everything came to happening for Borderlands 2, and frankly I think the story is just as good, if not a little better than BL2s story. I will say though that it does take awhile for it to pick up. I find the first hour to be pretty boring and very hard to get interested in the game, but once it starts to pick it I found it easy to play through it and have a blast. What is even better is having what ever character(s) you are currently playing chime in with unique dialog during certain parts of the story. That little feature alone made this story more interesting and enjoyable compared to BL1 and BL2. Even playing on True Vault Hunter the "Re-telling" dialog is slightly different, with different characters chiming in about the events. It gives another reason to play through the story again.CharactersThe Vault Hunters this time around are previous bosses from BL2 and characters from 1&2. You have Athena the Gladiator which first appeared in BL1 DLC. She wields a shield that absorbs damage, then thrown to hit/kill her enemies. Then you have Wilhelm the Enforcer, who was a first major boss in BL2, summons drones to help fight/defend him. Cool fact about Wilhelm, any major upgrades you take on his skills, will actually change how he looks/sounds, which is a cool little feature!Next you have Nisha the Lawbringer, who was a minor boss in BL2, who plays as a cowgirl/weastern shooter and duel wields pistols... and stuff...Last but not least, and by far the best character to play as, you play as Claptrap, but is now trained in combat, so hes now called Fragtrap. Claptraps ability is "VaultHunter.exe" and is the most entertaining out of the other powers, because it's semi-random on what you can get, based on your surroundings and what is going on. You can get a super useful boost like increase damage/speed/rate of fire, or cause a lazer disco inferno, or you can cause the whole party to start bouncing around. And to top it all off, Claptrap also has some of the best dialog in the entire game. Nuff said!*DLC CharactersThe Handsome Jack Doppelganger is by far the second best character to play as. Also has some of the best dialog in the game. The skills are also tons of fun. You can get frickin lazers on your arms!Lady Hammerlock the Baroness... I absolutly hate. I hate her more than Nisha, so I'm not gonna talk about her.Combat/WeaponsThe new addition for combat in Pre-Sequal is the introduction of Low Gravity and Butt Slams. This makes the combat so much better compared to BL2. This adds in some verticallity and more range of movement to the combat, making it more enjoyable and feel more fast paced and action packed. Now being a Borderlands game, it has the trope of "It has a bazzilion weapons!" and frankly, I hate it. Why? Because 98% of the weapons is just useless trash! Just like BL1 and 2, yes it has lots of weapons, but in terms of any "unique" or fun weapons, are very limited. This was always a feature that I hate, cause I'd rather have more interesting and fun weapons, instead of being dumped a bazzilion useless trash guns/items. Still there is some great weapons that have special effects or abilities to them that can make things more interesting. With the new addition of lazers there is even more fun weapons to use.I will say though, the Moon Buggie has the WORST driving mechanics I've ever seen. The slightest bump on the road can send you flipping off a cliff to your death. The second I was able to get a hover bike, I never used that pos buggie ever again.PROS:- You play as Claptrap. BEST DAY EVER!- Story is slow to start, but gets great.- Low gravity is really fun.- BUTT SLAMS!- New lazer weapons are fun.- Season Pass does NOT give you "Shock Drop Slaughter Pit" (It's not worth it, it's garbage.)- Claptastic Voyage is a GREAT DLC!- Jack Clone is too sexy.- Achievements.- Steam Trading Cards.CONS:- Athena, Nisha, Wilhelm, Lady Hammerlock all have boring dialog.- Jack Clone is too sexy.- Not lots of DLC.- Holodome Onslaught DLC is boring and super short. Only thing worth out of it is the Upgrade pack.If you're a fan of the Borderlands series and wanted something thats the same, but a little bit different, it's a great pick up and is really fun. The Claptrap DLC adds on for even more fun and makes things even more interesting. I highly recommened it!

number of helpful: 16 of 21 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Rating 8/10Overview: First Person Action RPGThe Good: + 4 characters to choose from, each with 3 skill trees. The skill trees are more robust than previous games. The skills themselves are also more unique. Plenty of different character builds and options. Clap trap being one of the most unique characters to play as in the borderlands universe. + A good story that explains how the events unfolded leading up to Borderlands 2. + Two new gameplay mechanics. The first is the jump pad, this allows you to jump really high or traverse large distances. The second is the oxygen meter. Many environments have low gravity allowing you to jump really high and far which allows for faster traversal over the terrain as well as more interesting gun battles. Running out of oxygen is never a concern because there are so many ways to refill your oxygen.+ Lots of good loot. + Plenty of graphical/audio/gameplay options, very well optimized The Average:The overall map design for most levels feel a bit too condensed. I was hoping for more open spaced levels where I could drive around but that never really materialized here. Like every borderlands before it, side missions are not "optional". If you don't complete them you will be very under leveled for the main missions.  The side missions themselves are not the greatest either, many of them are not as creative as Borderlands 2. Humor is very hit or miss. The Bad: -Multiplayer is near dead making it very difficult to get some achievements. The game is also a lot more fun when playing with more people. Conclusion:This game is really good yet never really gained the same attention or critical praise as its predecessors, partly because many people were 'borderlands fatigued' by the time this game came out and the fact it was made by a different studio gave the game the impression it was a quick cash grab. Other than the new characters and new features mentioned above this is almost exactly like its predecessor in almost every way. This isn't bad but those looking for a completely new experience will not find it here.  Is this game as good as Borderlands No, but this game can certainly stand on its own.

number of helpful: 141 of 251 people (56%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Wow, Gearbox. I take back almost everything I said about Borderlands 2 and the Pre-Sequel, before I played the latter title. BL2 struck me as very very derivative of the first game and way too impressed with itself -- I mean, it worked as a business idea, the game sold a ton. But I really thought Gearbox was creatively bankrupt after playing most of BL2 a while back, and never planned to get the Pre-Seq.But holy crap, I was wrong. The Pre-Seq is BY FAR the best in the series IMO. They added some ridiculously fun mechanics with the O2 tanks, some very clever (and slightly annoying, but mostly clever) altitude-based environment puzzles, and the LASERS, man. The lasers are FUN. SO much fun. The characters' skills are way way better than 2's -- Athena is my girl all the way, although I also dig Nisha's gunslinger skills. Wilhelm is a pretty amusing character, and I dunno about the robot. Don't care, honestly, but I do plan to fiddle with him at some point. Actually, I'm so glad they finally regulated him to a much more secondary role, because I don't know about you, but that "ha ha I'm an annoying sidekick" joke was running damned thin.And they actually wrote a -- so far -- rather decent story that isn't 75% pop-culture jokes, and they manage to give some of the characters some personality, AND the level design & art design blow me completely away. The writing: as much as I love Anthony Burch, the comedy in BL2 got super old after you ran around Pandora for the tenth time, and there's only so much "look at me I made an internet joke" I can take, honestly. The Pre-Seq actually puts forth a fairly interesting story and the comedy is mostly derived from the characters and who/what they are, not all the quotes they can spout at you. And that is a HUGE leg up in my opinion.I still get frustratingly lost in some of the environments and the map still sucks, but wow. I'm kind of in love with this one.--Haven't finished the main story yet, so this review may change in the future. But, so far, if you're a Borderlands fan, you'll be pleasantly surprised with the third installment of "Pithy Punks Populate Pandora: PEW PEW PEW".

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
-Quick Review-Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is FPS RPG developed by 2K Australia and Gearbox Software, and released in 2014.  Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is pretty much Borderlands 2 but on the moon/station seen over Pandora. If you're not sure if you'll like borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, go give Borderlands 2 a try.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: Borderlands: The Pre-sequel takes place between the first Borderlands game and Borderlands 2. If you couldn't figure that out for yourself based on the colorful word-play. (Is a Pre-Sequel even a thing? *googles* well seeing as the only results are Borderlands the Pre-Sequel)To add a bit more clarification or to completely lose you: The story is actually taking place AFTER Borderlands 2, but in story format, as told by Athena (A secret agent-type, gone rogue. You meet her in Borderlands 1's The Secret Armory of General Knoxx).For simplicity sake lets just say it's an "in between" game. You play as one of Handsome Jacks henchmen and discover what eventually led to his turning to the dark side. Okay, not star wars, but the "turning" aspect or "corruption" felt very similar. You start out by working with a cheerful happy-go-lucky employee of Hyperion, and see him slowly descend into a paranoid power hungry shell of his former self.Controls: The controls feel pretty much the same as Borderlands 2, or generic FPS's, WASD to move, mouse to move the camera, keyboard rebinding is available, mouse wheel up or down to change weapons, or press 1,2,3,etc. I've always liked the controls in Borderlands games, simple straightforward, no keyboard piano playing.But wait! There is a few new changes! Namely Gravity! If you're outside of a location that has artificial gravity (inside a ship, indoors, in a base, etc) you will float higher on your jumps. While definitely entertaining, and adding a whole new level of stress when you miss a long jump. (have you fallen into the abyss slowly? It's agony!)There's a new mechanic that you can also press CTRL (or whichever key you bind) to slam down onto the ground, or on top of enemies. A new gear slot will represent an air container which is necessary for all humans to survive in the vacuum of space but furthermore doubles as being used for double jumping in space. (You can jump once, then jump again at the expense of air)Enemies sometimes drop air canisters that will replenish some of your air, there are other locations where you can go to get oxygen filled up, buildings, and specific devices which create a force-field of air you can stand in.Progression: There are several sources you can get a sensation of progression in Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. The most obvious representation of progression is by story progression or level progression. After you finish the story you can repeat the story again to continue leveling until you reach the cap.Or you can reroll another character, if you made the mistake of playing Claptrap on your first play through like I did. For those that don't know, even though claptrap is hilariously annoying vocally... he makes a terrible playable character, when you use your special ability you're basically rolling dice and the game tries to judge your situation for whichever vault hunter power to immitate.Unfortunately the game decided my situation required me to blow myself up 9 times out of 10. Yes I'm a bit salty about that. I don't use self destruction abilities in any video game really. So yeah, good times. It was fun hearing his cackling while I bounced on top of people, and it was nice not breathing air. Butttttt... I was a liability.Style/Graphics/Appearance: Borderlands doesn't try to aim for "realism" in their game assets, instead they stylize their characters, models, and textures. This is very good in the long run, because it increases the longevity of the games appeal. You don't need to jump into the most recent game to enjoy the newest aesthetics, they start to average out over all their games.Don't get me wrong, there is a sign of improvement from game to game, but the style they use stays very uniformed rough and "Borderlands-y".Price/value/game time played:Borderlands: The Pre-sequel is priced at $39.99, and the game with the season pass is priced at $69.99. If you're an achiever you will need to get the "Holodome Onslaught" and "Claptastic Voyage" DLC to earn 100%. At the time that I'm writing this review I've played 36 hours of Borderlands: The Presequel. That number will definitely change, there is still plenty to do, so you can definitely get your moneys worth out of game time.Conclusion:All in all, I've enjoyed what I've experienced with Borderlands: The Presequel, It's been most fun playing it with friends. I've enjoyed "flying" around (okay, it's not really flying, it's 'falling with style'.) and as I so eloquently imaged it "Mario Butt Pounding" the NPC's.In a way the game feels shorter then it's predeccessor (borderlands 2, man this "pre-sequel nonsense is complicated, isn't it?), so if you're looking for the best quality borderland games, this one doesn't have too much to offer outside of a couple new gimmicks and a few new playable characters. Story-wise, it's definitely worth it and very interesting! This game makes me want to own Jacks Hyperion Jacket. (Why doesn't Borderlands have a clothing line?)In conclusion, I'm not sure what to tell people, It's borderlands 2 ...in space! If you like borderlands, if you enjoy FPS, if you like the humor in the game series, you'll love this game just like borderlands 2.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24
												First of, I've seen A LOT of downtalk and "DON'T BUY THIS" warnings from other reviews.Which is why I've been hesitant to try this game untill recently, despite having thoroughly enjoyed Borderlands 2.But after having played it for 30 hours, and completed the entire campaign + side missions and DLC, which only took roughly around 30 hours... I honestly found it just as good as Borderlands 2.Story missions feel more interconnected and relevant to one another. Gives a proper feeling of necessity.Unlike some of BL2's missions which felt like they were dragging out the story as much as possible for gamelength, as well as sending you on sidetracked tasks when there is a very obvious and easier alternative.However that does not necessarily mean the story was more well-made. Honestly I cannot say which was the better of the two, as I enjoyed both games equally.Which should not be a surprise, as the Pre Sequel's template is literally a copy+paste of BL2.Though solo-play suffers from the same downsides that every Borderlands game has. Far more difficult (or far too easy) with certain classes and/or builds than others. Singleplayer combat is sometimes very unfair.As is the utterly contrived player-on-player duel system.I consider this game to be neither a step-down nor a step-up from BL2. It is simply the same game, but a different setting, different--and to me, slightly better--story and with a tiny few extra mechanics.Like the oxygen management, gliding and slamming, and cryo element are introduced exclusively in this game and makes things a little more interesting. But ultimately irrelevant to making it the game it is. Would still like the game without it.But I must urge people to avoid buying it (or the season pass) at full price. Though it is just as good as BL2, it is noticably lacking in terms of side content and DLC. Regrettably I did pay the full price of the basegame + season pass.On the subject of season pass, I must once again iterate that it is not worth the full price.The two additional characters were not all that interesting to me. Especially the Doppelganger which feels like just a way to get quick cash from making a popular character playable.And 2 of the 3 playable DLCs are just repetitive 5 rounds Arenas identical to BL2's Fink Slaughterhouse. Which were featured in the game as sidequests, part of the basegame, not an overpriced DLC.The final DLC however, Claptastic Voyage was fantasticly entertaining with a story that connects with its chronological sequel. But as expected, it was also disappointingly short. Buying it standalone however is worth it, unless you already got the season pass.7/10

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Borderlands: The pre-sequel is the third installment of the Borderlands series. Unlike the previous Borderlands games, TPS does not take place on Pandora, but on the moon which is called Elpis. If you've played Borderlands 2, you would know that TPS share a heavily resemblence of it with the same graphic engine and UI so many vetaran fans would picked up the game right away. Following the tradition, you have the option to select four playable characters/classes with two more coming on the way as DLCs. You'll discovered some new and old faces NPCs and get to know their story. Get ready to play as the bad guys along with Jack, the man who will eventually becomes Handsome Jack in Borderlands 2.Let's talk about the new gameplay mechanic. There are two enviroment areas that you should be familiar with. They're called Atmosphere and Vaccum. Atmosphere is a area with oxygens. If you're in this area, your O2 gauge won't deplete, but your jump mobility will be limited. Unlike in the previous installment, you can only ignite enemies in an area with an atmosphere.  Vaccum is a area with no oxygens. If you're in this area, your O2 gauge will deplete over time unless you're playing as the Fragtrap, but your jump mobility will be much greater. Once you get a Oz kit, you will gain the ability to "double jump". Oz kit also allowed you to do a slam attack by jumping mid-air and holding crouch will do a AoE damage around yourself so it's a good way to get enemies with melee off your back. If you run out all of your O2 gauge , your health will drain over time regardless of your shield, but not to worry, there are oxygen and atmosphere areas that will replenish your O2 gauge. TPS also introduced the Cyro elemental that freezes  your enemy and immobilize them temporary. What's great if you freeze a enemy in the air, watch them fall down and shatter into pieces if they've taken enough damage from the fall. Last but not least lasers are a new type of guns that comes in various forms. They can take many shapes like assault rifles, shotguns, and sniper rifles and they all use the same ammo. Last but not least, you can use the grinder to dispose three of the same quality guns that you don't like and it will pop out a new gun with the same or better quality. What you get is depend on what kind of recipe you've used so becareful on using the grinder. In conclusion, BLTPS is a great game and it lives up to the name of Borderlands, but it does have flaws and many bugs including gamebreaking ones. Some NPCs will take forever to finish up their echo conversation and it's a pain to wait for them to shut up until you could do your next objective. There are time when you have to backtrack many times to complete side quests and you could get easily lost until you become familiar with the areas. If you guys are Borderlands fans, but you're worry about the price and you're afraid the developers didn't put in enough efforts to make a illegitimate game, then perhaps it's better for you to wait for a price drop or the inevitable GOTY edition. BLTPS story ties the knot of the events of BL1 and BL2 really well. You will see and understand a different side of Jack and why he became the vicious villain that we all loved to hate, Handsome Jack.

number of helpful: 86 of 151 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												This game suprised me. I was not expecting it to be as good as it is. The story line is great, asnwering questions you might have had from the Borderlands games 1 and 2, as well as opening up more questions (maybe the DLCs will shed further light).I like the low gravity aspect - I was worried about playing with low grav at first, but it's fun and doesn't impede gameplay. The butt slam is a favourite. Plenty of new weapons, with Cryo being a replacement for slag in some ways. Vending machines have many Legendary items, so it's worth checking them wherever you go. They're in the machines more often than as weapon drops. Lasers are a nice addition to the game too.The characters are interesting to play, each of them have a nice unique blend of options, and I think they're well balanced.Some of the side missions are a pain, causing you to retrace your steps, but there's not too many like that, and a lot of side missions can be skipped if you're not interested in the lowly weapon rewards. Good for XP and Moon Stones (like eridium from BL2). There are way too many bugs in the game, some that were ported from BL2 and some new ones; hopefully these will be addressed though I don't hold my breath.Overall I really enjoy this game, more than I expected to, and am looking forward to Playthrough 3 when it becomes unlocked. Also looking forward to more content in the DLCs.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												8/10. In short, it's very similar to Borderlands 2 from every angle, and I recommend it to these loving BL series and other open world+ FPS+RPG combination.  But as a Borderlands fan, I have to say it's not as good as BL2, overall. Here are what I've realized so far. Pros:1. low gravity and jump pad system, which makes combats more flexible and three-dimensional. 2. brand new atmospheric environment3. more interactions between NPCs and your character4. novel laser weapons and cryo element5. better item scaling, which is like Borderlands 16. moral dilemma, no longer good/evil binary boundery7. novel grinder (a new way to get high/rare quality items)Cons:1. Laser weapons are overpowered , which makes other types of weapons more or less useless, which narrows down weapon selection. 2. less extensive contents (main story, enemies and environments)3. limited looting, legendary farming has been swtiched from boss farming to vendor machine farming, which isn't as resonable as BL 2 imo. and raid boss is lack of originality. 4. less dramatic main story5. way less explorable map as BL2, while still much time wasted on covering the mission path (running/jumping from mission spot A to B). Others: 1. The combat is way less intense than BL 2.2. same humors as usual Conclusion:$60 is a bit expensive for it, but it's still a good game compared with many junks with the same price on Steam. Wait and grab it until sales and it'll make you worthwhile.

Posted: May 31, 2016
												This review is biased. (I enjoyed the first and the second game thoroughly).I would recommend this game. If you enjoyed the 2nd game, it is very similar to that game in regards to play style, weaponry, leveling and difficulty. The new additions in regards to different abilities between our vault hunters, the low gravity, and the ability to grind weaponry were enjoyable editions to the game. Put a good 100 hours into playing 3 of the characters (one of them of course being ClapTrap). I will say the best part of the game was the story in regards to learning about Jack and why he believes himself to be a hero. Knowing that he will become our villain in the seconds. In addition, I thoroughly enjoyed the ClapTrap DLC and how it tries to explain what happens to our favorite annoying robot between his revolution to the beginning of Borderlands 2.Only issue I would say is that there was not much change to the game play. Game play is good, but there are still broken aspects whether being weapon bugs, inability to be able to grind for certain weapons, or easily being destroyed at higher levels by a enemy / horde of enemies on solo when 4+ higher than you. (Part of the exponential difficulty and weapon changes).For me this game is still a 9/10. Because it is Borderlands.

												Many of you who will go to the comments will wonder whats wrong with the game. May you be a potential buyer or a gamer who has it and wants to see what other people think. let me elborate what is wrong with the game. 1) Humor is dead.- the jokes are flatlined and if its a sex joke the character saying will explain it to you. censorship is also in the game but not bleeped out instead with replacing words like b***h with  "taint". Characters will often use the term " son of a taint" which will drive you insane pretty damn soon. This is what makes borderlands engaing as it bring character to characters ( not a pun). you see non of that. The citizens of the city you go to as a main hub for suppiles and quest are dull. nothing they say or do is interesting. in bl2 they were amusing at times but annoying. that aleast made them noticable. Character devolpment is slow and empty as they rely one every new characters sense of humor to be the character for them 2) Story.-the story supossedly follows handsome jacks rise to power in the hyperion corpartion to become the CEO, madman and all around smartass we all know and love from BL2. We however see little of that he wants to build a robot army to fight the lost legion and take heilios the station. most of the central story ACTUALLY REVOVLES AROUND YOU DOING FETCH QUEST AND PREPARING TO HELP JACK ROBOT ARMY RATHER THEN ACTUAL FOCUSING ON JACK HIMSELF. Thats right. And guess what? NO ANGEL. Thats the problem with this game as its shows in BL2 that jack used angle to trick roland and co. to open the vault. in this game we see the erdidum explosin on pandora and get to meet liltih and roland on the moon just for them to tell us to♥♥♥♥♥♥off . so where angel in all of this? why did jack trick them into opening the vault when he wasnt even ceo of hyperion? major plot hole. -little time is fousced on jack and we do see his ugly side from time to time but nothing to show his moralty and insights and personality changing to more chaotic or justifying evil with good intenions until the end when he becomes handsome jack. there was almost no character devolepment into jack and more put into the commander of the lost legion as she has over a dozen autologs on elphis to find and several missions on her background. but non for jack unlike in bl2. Few characters in this game are gay or oversexualized but when they are 2k austrailia is constantly reminding you. Several other characters do this as well and when you decide to base your characters almost soley on their sexuality, thats just horrible writing.- loot systems sucks as you only get purples on missions and in gold chest- almost the exact same as bl2 this is just the negative and its incomplete. ill post another review to cover more later

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Borderlands: Great vanilla game. Gameplay and character "classes" were solid, fun, and had obvious roles.Borderlands 2: Great addition to the series. Better story. Each of the characters trees added a slighly different to the character, with some characters able to fill different roles. (range/melee/support/tank). One con to this game was that the non-dps trees felt a little lack luster, like more time was put into designing more ways to mow down foes.Borderlands Pre-sequel: Story pretty good, but not on the same level as Borderlands 2. Low gravity wasn't a bad idea, added some different gameplay elements, but was used way to much. With you either getting way to used to it and try and jump high while inside or being thankful that you are inside for less gimicky gameplay. However, Cyro-elemental weapons were a great addition for crowd control and shatter damage on weaker oponents.I also thought the non-dps trees were given far more love in this game. Tanks getting more than just HP increase and damage reductions. Like being able to increase the resistences  of you and your party when hit with a status affects and splash it back on your enemies.Support trees can help keep the group alive without fully relying on their action skill to heal or rez someone quickly. Overall. Borderlands 2 had a better story. Borderlands pre-sequel had better character class design.Hope for the future of the Borderlands series is to add more active skills. Atm with all three games the there is only the action skill and melee overrides.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												So far, Borderlands Presequel did something I admire. It took a risk. Borderlands 0 also illustrates a point I as a gamer, feel fails to be understood by the day to day devs: While we may not like your boss and studios direction, that does not mean we as gamers have a negative view of the people who work on a big studio game. In spite of the handicaps a publisher may lay upon you, it isn't personal when we dislike a work of this caliber.I feel that my/our dislike of forced sequels sometimes comes off as an affront to those that busted their butts in the hellish crunches that make up the life of your average studio employee/work for hire. This is far from the truth. In spite of the system that often squirts out derivative works to cash in on an IP, we do indeed respect and recognize your hard work.2K Australia took a chance on trying to humanize an arguably annoying bad guy in an argubaly annoying and bland story. Many people loved the second game in the series, I was not one of them. It had the coda of being fun* Fun with a friend, and even then it could have numerous low points. One need only look at the works of former designers from this publisher and others to see the difference. As for this game, it is entertaining enough with friends.

number of helpful: 49 of 86 people (57%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												A dry husk of repetition.PREFACEThe first Borderlands came out years ago. It was new in tone and gameplay and it was a lot of fun, despite some problems. By today's standards, I think we should know better by now and should have improved. A lot of the problems in the first Borderlands plague its sequels. Play your first Borderlands game. Play a second one for more of the same. Don't play a third. Take the amount of hours you've played in Borderlands 1 and 2. That's how long you've already been playing this game.+++PROS+++If you happen to like Borderlands, then this is more of the same. It's at least that.The new frost element is much funner to use than slag.---CONS---STORYIt doesn't feel very good to play characters who are so unlikably cruel. A lot of people have a taste for sadism, but usually as revenge or justice against wrongdoers; our characters seem unnecessarily uncaring. It also doesn't help that we're helping someone who we know is a jerk, and playing as some characters who we know will die deservedly in the next game. Our characters' motivations seem weak as well. We're there because... we were hired?On a small level, the story drags on and on, with predictable excuse after excuse to lengthen your adventure.On a larger level, we know what's going to happen, and don't even like the side we're fighting for. When you do a movie about nazi protagonists, you watch their side of the struggle, as they truly believe they are fighting for the good of their country, and you portray a new perspective that most people don't consider. This was not done here. The story is always delivered through expository audio dialogue, boring as the only way to get story. Then again, what else was supposed to be done? The story isn't very complicated or emotionally stressing, so there isn't much material for cutscenes with subtle and strong emotional animations, or set pieces showing the lives and personalities of people.The Borderlands series has also taken this bizarre twist in tone, with serious dramatic and political matters at hand while fabricating tragic deaths. This dramaticism clashes harshly with the game's silly dialogue. The dramaticism also feels unearned when crudely force fed through audio dialogue. The game keeps verbally telling me the way things are, not showing me; is this character kind hearted? Why don't they affect my gameplay? It could be argued that I'm being greedy, demanding masterpieces when I suppose audio dialogue could be enough, but I push for story and gameplay melding so that I'm paying attention and I care; I was just absent mindedly following waypoints and killing.The characters are not as memorable as they were in previous games. It seems the strategy was to just make a character with a new accent and a one sentence description. They don't even stick around for very long. I remember the cast of Borderlands 2, because they stuck with me the whole time, the whole city against this evil man.The humor is also getting worse. It seem that as long as you have people saying ridiculous things with no punchline, exaggeration, or surprise, it'll be funny. It's the kind of things you hear when you're playing multiplayer and someone decides to be a radio dj comedian, saying anything desperately hoping to be funny and popular.The recycled assets of Borderlands continue to build an unforgiving wasteland well, but other than that, the sense of the world isn't built very deeply; it's all just a 2d poster backdrop to your adventure. The citizens walk idly and never say much; they're not alive. The buildings themselves are not very memorable either, repeated cut and pasted spaces.GAMEPLAYRepetition, over and over. Shoot, walk, use, shoot, walk use. Pick up guns, sell. The elemental and RPG elements? They hardly matter. Just shoot critical points, pick the thing with the highest numbers, oh, keep a corrosive weapon for robots. It was fun the first game, getting better and better treasure.The open spaces. The maps are sprawling with empty space to lengthen your boring game time. The objectives are often placed in deceptively far off places, like on a super high cliff right next to you. It looks close on the map, bu you actually have to travel all the way around.You can get lost a lot, especially with all the vertical space that is not well represented on the map.The AI is still the same as always. Idle until aggravated, perfect aim at all distances, moving erratically with no turning animations to read movement. They're deceptively hard to shoot, dull, and annoying; flying enemies are worse. The low gravity and oxygen does not really add anything new to the game. In fact, it's just annoying to have to manage them.The design and balance seems sloppy. You can be a little more loose in design in PVE than in PVP, but this is just too sloppy. It feels as if players are just thrown into a mess of complications, without testing, without consideration for gameplay and strategy, and it's expected to be okay because, "well, if they keep trying, they'll make it." I've had skirmishes of enemies spawning all around me, sporadic cover, jump pads that didn't help, and enemies with rocket launchers while I still only had two weapon slots.Even the special abilities are less interesting. In Borderlands two, I could wait patiently for my cooldown, then pull out my skill that allowed me to engages waves of enemies. Now, I have to use my skill much more often to kill 1 or 2 people at best. I played as Nisha. Her skill is to, for a brief period, automatically aim at enemies and gain increased gun stats. A lot of her skill tree depends on her being able to get kills during this period; it's so brief and can hardly kill. The skill itself also functioned quite uselessly. As long as enemies were moving, none of my showdown bullets would hit. I would also lock onto enemies behind cover. I would aim at far away enemies rather than the ones right in front of me that I wanted to kill. If the enemy was posed in the right way, their head would be cocked to the side and all my bullets would miss.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												This is not Borderlands 3.  This is a very long Borderlands 2 DLC done by the B-Team.  It feels a bit lazy, but it's still a lot of fun.The Good: The story is interesting and there's a lot to do. There's four new playable characters and they're gender balanced (the game, as a whole, is excellent in that respect). Low gravity, butt-slams, lasers, freeze attacks and Australian in-jokes round out the new features.The Bad: There's not really anything bad. There's a few polygon tearing glitches, all minor.The Lazy: It's the Borderlands 2 engine, so if you were expecting something really new, this isn't it. The writing is not up to Borderlands 2 par. Character gestures are rarely customized resulting in them repeating the same generic ones while talking. There's not nearly the variety of enemies and locations as in Borderlands 2.The Weird: You can play as Claptrap!  SOLD!  Why wouldn't you want to play as a murderous, incompetant robot?  [Hint: you hate his voice.]  It's about as fun and stupid as you'd imagine.  His action skill is a random version of other Vault Hunter's powers, except done wrong.  Example: You can get two guns like the Gunzerker, but you never stop firing.  It gets a bit confusing when you're talking to other Claptraps.Compared to most FPS, it's excellent, and this is why I recommend it.  Compared to Borderlands 2, it's not quite up to par, but they set a very high bar.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												While the mechanics are slightly tuned from borderlands 2, and to great effect, it doesn't make a satisfying sequel. Positives:-Story does more than expected.  even though there's less than the second, it does a better job than I thought it would, and the humor wasn't bad either.-jump mechanicsthis is the small tweak I was talking about.  Although small, it makes a huge difference, the feel of gliding across a map unhindered, slamming down into opponents, and having more free movement is wonderful.  So much so I feel more games should have it.  If they make a sequel to the series, I hope they bring it back as a jetback or something, but with less of a limiting feature on the oxygen count, which is the only downside to this mechanic.  -charater personailtyanother small adjustment that has done leagues to affect the game positively.  Your character now has things to say, and responds to people, and events.  They even have some quick backstory to most of them that you can find throughout the story.-enemy variety this is something that it's predecessors didn't have, as I often found myself getting bored, or annoyed at the same old callouts over and over again.  Here it seems they bothered to record more dialogue for enemies so that it doesn't grate on you after a while, and it seems that the enemy types are at least as much as the last two games.-co-op gameplayalways a plus in this game, but not necessary to enjoy the game on it's own.  Although it does help quite a bit. Negatives:-Bugs out the♥♥♥♥♥br>You will run into a myriad of bugs in this game, from game geometry not working right, to MORE then frequent game breaking bugs.  When I first started the game I got locked out of one of the very first quests because a gate wouldn't open.  Later on I couldn't proceed in NG+ because a verbal exchange didn't go off so another door locked me out, I gave the game a break for a while when I was asked if I wanted to skip a segment of gameplay that I'd already done, and it gave the game a fatal error that caused it to crash everytime I said yes.-No player basefor a game that has a larger emphasis on online and co-op play, the player base is even smaller than borderlands 2 at release, maybe the pc crowd is waiting for it to go on sale, or maybe they're not keen on buying what looks and feels a bit like a souless cash in. -Game length is shortCompared to the length of the bas game of borderlands 2, I was severely discontented with the length of this game.  It's almost as short as the first game, and pales in comparison to the second. -lack of enviornmentsCompared to the second game, this game's enviornments are not nearly as varied.  Despite the fact that the second and first got more milage out with some really nice dlcs, this game does not even get close to their base game enviornments.  There is, hyperion moon base, the final area (which is really interesting but short), and an icy moon surface.  That's it.-looting systemThe loot system is slightly better than 2 but still not as good as 1, your only chance at finding good weapons and gear is either by grinding raid bosses(3 in the game) endlessly, or getting the items through a cheat device or a co-op partner.  You're not going to see anything of value out on the field, or in the vending machines.  Your only options are to boss fight and get lucky, or grind some weapons and hope you get something decent-mics don't work and connection problemsMics do not work properly in game, and connections will be unstable, despite good internet connections.  Something that was never a problem in the other games-garbage DLCFinally the dlc is lackluster, and overall disapointing, the one thing that borderlands NEVER did.  In the past, the dlc was both interesting, added new enviornments, good dialogue, more items, and SOMETIMES a new character.  In fact the initial game had a huge dlc campaign with a ton of new things, the second game had the same thing, but you were guaranteed four dynamite dlcs AND two extra characters, with other dlcs replacing the characters for the second season.Now for it's outrageous price you get nothing.  So far, we've gotten one good character, one lackluster character, and an arena.  And there's only ONE MORE DLC LEFT before the season is over.  It's probably going to be short and awful as well, and so far, none of these have served to extend the gameplay much more than an hour or two.  All in all, it's not worth full price.  If it goes on sale for 15$ for all of the content, then I'd say it's worth it.  But I wouldn't pay sale price plus the admission fee for dlc.  While I like the game, and think it's a step in the right direction in some ways, I do not believe for a second it should've retailed for this much, and should've sold at a more humble price at release.Wait for a sale if anything.

												After nearly 20 hours with the game, I've found that it's tough to separate the high-quality DLC that supported Borderlands 2 and The Pre-sequel. Speaking of her, I like how progressive this game is and Janey Springs is a good example! Instead of just making a gay character, they decided to make her a creepy stalker and have every other line from her be about how she is gay. That's a realistic portrayal of a gay person. I also like how you only get 2 types of weapons until you enter Concordia and most of the weapons are terrible. What a wonderful game.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												This game was a huge dissapointment. How anybody can rate this game in a positive light has never played a Borderlands game before and I would even go as far as saying has never played a game before. There are huge gaps in the story, random invisible walls, stupid mechanics, an extrememly small amount of bosses and unrewarding loot. Let me start with the loot. I played this game with 3 other friends and we all played a different class. We saw 3 legendaries, 1 of them being from a vendor and the latest drop was around level 21. We found ourselves being extremely overwhelmed with the enemies strictly because we had no loot drops. All the crates and loot thingys around Elpis contained commons and greens, sometime an epic or two. But most of all we found ourselves grinding out money to afford to buy a weapon or grenade mods to kill whatever we needed to kill at the time. Next up are all the glitches in the game. There are random invisible walls all over the world in spots where you have a clear line of sight to a ledge or a cliff that will just stop you and make you fall to your death; there are gaps in which you must jump over with your vehicle but even with a boost going top speed youd make it 50% of the time. The rest of the time youre falling helplessly into lava pits. Elevators will randomly glitch out and keep going up and kill you, bosses jetison loot out of their bodies when you kill them only to find yourself chasing the loot into a black abyss of nothingness, thus losing the loot forever. The characters are probably the most disappointing thing to me. Athena and Claptrap by far talk the most, and even then its not that much. Wilhelm and Nisha say next to nothing which is dissapointing because they are Jacks right hand people in Borderlands 2. They never address very important plots holes (I will not say in fear of spoiling it for people), and the end of the game seems extremely rushed. In total there are about 9 bosses. All of which are just point and shoot with no mechanics whatsoever. The typical comedy in the Borderlands series falls short in almost every avenue. The only redeming thing was Claptraps typical quips. Other than that, nothing. Cringe worthy material that is sure to make anyone feel dumb and awkward. There are pop culture references in the game that are just God awful. So awful to the point I almost ALT+F4'd out of the game. Having put in hundreds of hours in Borderlands on 360 and hundreds of hours on Borderlands 2 I can say I lvoe this series. With the exception of this. It is terribly short (we beat the entire series in 16 hours) and that was doing side quests and messing around at some times. The raid boss is just a harder version of the final boss. Overall this was a HUGE dissapointment and I will probably never load this game up again. I am very sad.

content:

												Ok the reason I am giving this game a Thumbs Down is for plenty of reason of which i shall List the pros and cons...Cons:-I have followed Borderlands since the beginning and grown accustomed to certain expectations of it, this definately does reach alot of them            -The story isnt quite great as i expected it to be            -Gearbox being a professional company who charges 60$ for a pre-sequel or whatever you expect no bugs and a solid playthrough sadly i run into bugs often-If you played Borderlands 2 or the first you would love characters such as Moxxi well they kill her character in this (not literally just as she acts and such)-The Enemies (minor thing that bugs me they gain health back right after you die even if they are in your spawn and are to op for you) other than that they often glitch run through walls etc. -Jack's character which seems to be the main reason this game was created (when instead they should have moved on) as been throughout the game (as of where i am) just checking off his personalities (random rage, sarcasim, etc.) -Some of the guns such as the lasers are often completely useless outside of iron sights, they shoot completely off to the side (which yes proly is the aiming of the gun) but no instead lets say you shoot a complete stream at someone it will just go completely through them it picks and chooses when it's going to do damage-Missions, Oh my god how it feels like they just copied and pasted half the missions and the pointless running of it all is ridiculous -This game should proly be rated E for Everyone because they not only bleep out cuse words but it just feels like a game i would have my younger sister play (she's like 7) which is ridiculous the humor seems beaten down and worn out like they lost almost all sense of humor. this is the kind of game im ashamed of laughing at the childish moments, it's bad really the humor is anyways-A re-used Engine for the game which really isn't a con just goes to show they were trying to make a quick buck before the next game so it seems (And I bought into it) alot of it is copied just added new weapons and new textures ( a waste of a team instead of working on Borderlands 3)-they bring in replacements for the characters from the first 2 games like scooter and Zed yet they cant replace a villain who is dead already (maybe im just ragging becasue this seems to be a fix for people who cant seem to wait which will proly kill alot of hype for the next game) The pros:-It is off pandora which was beginning to feel old and used up-The characters that you play can actually talk now which isnt that big a deal but its the details that matter to me-The story nonetheless is somewhat intriguing just poorly written-Scenery is a nice change, If you think Borderlands 2 was full of color well this game jesus can hurt my eyes after awhile just of the pure intensities of the color -No matter what to me at least it seems that I can never step away from borderlands no matter how frustrated i can get it has that draw-the claptraps are back now in the first one they didnt talk all as much and all seemed the same (they are robots but hey i like diversity) but in this one it seems every single claptrap has a different personality, Still abused as hell always is a joy to see that XDAs I progress through the game I will post any changes of feelings towards the game, which might just get worse. I am not very far and these are my observations of it so far.

												I really tried, but in the end though this just wasn't the Borderlands game for me. I love Borderlands 2 to bits. There are just too many elements here though which don't come together in the same way Borderlands 2 did for me.Perhaps more than anything else, the writing really grated on me in a way that just didn't go away. Rather than adjust to the differences, it felt like it was trying to be another Borderlands 2 but missing the mark by a wide margin. But it was more than that. The environments were just bland. The "graphics" were of course at parity with the previous game, but the art and design completely failed to inspire me.Without any engagement in the story, or excitement to explore the environments, I just felt like I was wasting my time with the Pre-Sequel. The jumping and oxygen depletion systems added nothing of value to me, so it was essentially the same shooting in an inferior package.I will say that I've had similar sentiments when it comes to the the Borderlands (1&2) DLCs that I've played, which is admittedly not all of them. But if you liked most or all of the DLCs from previous Borderlands games then my experience with the Pre-Sequel may well be a very poor guide.

number of helpful: 167 of 311 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												6/10 - This game feels a lot like just a big addon for BL2, which in and of itself wasn't that bad of a game. This game DOES add a lot of new things to the experience to freshen it up a bit. I feel like the game relies a bit too much on its sense of humor as a selling point. Honestly as a successor to the previous game, I felt as though this was a let down, let alone the price of it. Game play is still solid, shooter at its core. May revise this depending on how the DLCs that inevitably will come out do. All in all nothing too new here, didn't feel like it was worth 60 bucks.EDIT: After having had a chance to more thuroughly play this game and feel it out, I'm revising my previous score of 6/10, I now give this game a 4/10. Between the amount of hindering glitches from the previous game they left in (mostly in the UI), the inclusion of new ones (mostly graphical that I've seen at this point), and the removal of some beneficial ones, it has become obvious to me that they made no honest attempts at playtesting this game outside of the already known bugs that gave us an "unfair edge on the game", and giving little to no thought or care of the bugs that impeded us in the previous game (Ex: The UI bug in bl2 where it would jump to the opposite end of the list you are selecting if you attempted to interact with it too quickly). In addition to this, the AI feels the same in how annoying it was in bl2 where their pathing and movement was generally braindead until you got put into fight for your life, at which point every enemy within range would make a direct beeline for cover, sometimes as I've noticed, even clipping through walls and floors to do so, this made the combat feel tedious at times, and outright unfair at others. They also essentially remade the BNK3R fight from bl2 which I had a personal distaste for, if only because there were periods of anywhere from 2-5 minutes at a time where the boss would not even come into range of attack putting you in a deadlock of dealing with enemies and dodging mortar rounds from the boss that you could not hit. While they fixed not being able to hit the boss for this one, they made its attacks much more damaging, gave it more health from the looks, and threw in harder enemies to fight between phases, all of this is compounded with the fact that I found ammo to be scarce in this fight, constantly putting me in a position of buying ammo, or leaving the area to go find more. In general this game offers nothing new that is any good beyond laser weapons, zero gravity, and the cryo element which just feels like a slag that stuns. The story was a decent link between games however, but not enough to make up for its shortcomings.EDIT 2: I feel as though I may have been too harsh with the review. All of these things I still hold to now, however I no longer feel as though they are as much of a detriment to the experience as I initially gave credit for. In all of it's shortcomings, it is still a Borderlands game. That being said, several changes and patches were made to this game to this point in time, a lot of these changes were bad, some were subsequently good to fix them, and public accounts from the devs were made that tweaked some members of the Borderlands community a certain way. Social media stuff aside, these changes IN THE END helped improve the game to a certain extent. With that in mind, what will likely be the final revision in my score is now 5/10. I still do not recommend it over BL2, but if you are looking for a fresh experience, provided you take it with a grain of salt, you may enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												It's quite hard for me to give this game a just review.I really enjoy the game, though I don't enjoy it as much as Borderlands 2, maybe after playing that for a couple hundred hours, the gameplay feels a little worn out.I think that's because the game is almost identical to Borderlands 2, don't expect any revolutionary gameplay changes or a lot of new features. It really feels like a big DLC, with a new story and new characters to play as.I don't like the characters (neither NPCs nor playable ones) as much as the ones from Borderlands 2, but then again, maybe that is because I played Borderlands 2 so much.What I did like was the hole space and vacuum atmosphere, it's done quite well, you have low gravity and a ground stomp attack to use against enemies. Downside: You have to make sure your oxigen supply doesn't run out (unless you're Claptrap)You got laser guns to go along with the space theme, which are kinda cool, too.Elements still work the same as in Borderlands 2, though there is no Slag - it has been replaced with Cryo weapons, which can be used to freeze enemies solid which then increases Melee damage, explosive damage and critical damage - not exactly like slag, but similar.I'm not sure about the dialogues (your character talks now, too), but at least when playing Claptrap, it's pretty funny and the humor is definitely still there.Though I didn't enjoy the game as much as Borderlands 2, I can't say that it's a bad game, so I'll definitely give it a thumbs up!

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												First, one of the big reasons I put off buying "Borderlands:  The Pre-Sequel" for so long was all the reviews complaining that it's nothing but a DLC of "Borderlands 2."  Well, after finishing my first run-through, I've got to say that's horse-pucky.  That first play-through took me 90.6 hours (and I'm still slightly less than half-way through the Achievements (though I've got most of the Badass Challenges done)).  Yes, the game plays a whole lot like BL2, but that's not a bad thing since that game was so good.  But, this is a whole new environment with an entirely new story that fills in the back-story for BL2.  It's definitely stand-alone and definitely worth the money.Now, I also have quite a few gripes with the game:- The pacing of the missions needs a lot of work.  The main story missions are excruciatingly long.  Yet, many of the side missions are totally trivial (for instance, closing a window, for goodness sakes).  Slightly shorter core missions and longer side missions would be nice.- The game's suspense factor needs a lot of work.  Very early in the game, we get a type of Sword of Damocles hanging over us.  It continues to hang there for most of the game.  It would have been nice to have the game progress towards that suspense point as we progressed through most of the story.- Some of the major areas are just too darn big.  I suppose if you're a person who just bulls through the game without exploring, that might be OK.  But, for me (who likes to explore and get all those Badass Challenges), it's really frustrating.- There are a LOT of missible Badass Challenges and Achievements.  It's extremely frustrating to get through an area, take a look at the Badass Challenges and see you've missed some and that there's no possibility of getting them until you re-play the whole game with the same character.- It takes far too long to open up the 3rd and 4th weapon slots (27 hours ("Intelligences of the Artificial Persuasion"), and 48 hours ("Home Sweet Home"), respectively)- Similarly to the earlier games, the weapon drops are almost never at my level (usually, they are 4 or more levels below me).  About the only time I ever get decent weapons is from the SHIFT code chest.- A darn high percentage of the Cult of the Vault symbols are really hard to find.  But, that's tolerable.  Unfortunately, one of them is positioned in such a location that it's almost impossible to reach.  It took me two hours and over a hundred runs to do the platforming needed to reach it.- The "To Arms" side mission is poorly thought out.  It requires you to fetch a boatload of white-grade weapons.  Unfortunately, I didn't start that mission until I was level 17 and white grade weapons didn't drop all that often at that point.  The mission should have caused the mobs you have to kill for the mission to actually drop them.  Instead, they drop almost nothing.- I don't know if it's an Australian English issue or just an inability to use words, but some of the Badass Challenge descriptions make no sense.  For instance, one says you have to shoot a "target."  It's not a "target."  It's a circle (perhaps a headlight).  Another wants you to take an "elevator."  It's not an "elevator."  It's a tram or cable car.  Spending time looking for things that aren't there isn't fun.- And, finally, even though we've got some kind of personal recorder in our inventory (which it turns out we can sell without problem), there's no way to replay ECHO recordings.  I can't count the number of times I missed those recording because some other event caused a conversation to pre-empt it.That's a lot of complaints.  But, still, the game was fun and is certainly long enough to be worth it.  It's not as good as BL2, but it's sure good enough.

												Of course you will get those elitists that will say Borderlands 1 was the best and nothing can hold a candle to it (especially this, for how much flak they are giving it now).I'll cut to the TL;DR version.It's not that bad at all, granted it runs off of the Borderlands 2 engine which is why tons of people feel...unsatisfied to say the least. Plenty of new weapons (as well as some fan favorite returning ones), abilities, new playable (but familiar) characters, missions, and elements to be able to have fun with. Witness the rise of Jack as well as his mental downfall.Some wouldn't warrant paying full price for this, I would and I did.BUT, what I would recommend is getting this during a sweet deal (as well as if you can pick up the season pass for a sweet deal). If not and you can't justify paying full price for either Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel and/or the Season Pass, then wait for the Game of the Year edition (with all, if not most, DLC bundled) for either full price or during a deal (depending on what you think of the other 2 DLC that has yet to be released at the time of this review).One way or another I recommend this game (elitists be damned if they don't like my review along with this game).

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Well, it's a good game. I've gotten nearly 100 hours out of it so far, so I suppose I can't say I haven't gotten my money's worth. But honestly I would recommend waiting until it goes on a deeper sale and/or the base price drops significantly. It is the weakest of the three Borderlands games so far. A release-day base price of $40 might have been more reasonable based on the amount of content compared to the previous games in the franchise.So far the Season Pass has been a real disappointment. I would unreservedly NOT recommend the Season Pass until it is much cheaper.  In BL2, it was four full story expansions with story missions and side quests. So far the Pre-Sequel's Season Pass has included the Handsome Jack character add-on and the Holodome Onslaught challenge, which I admittedly haven't finished yet. Plans have been announced for the remainder of the Season Pass to be another character and one (and only one) story expansion. Of course they never really promised four massive story expansions...Don't get me wrong - I've had tons of fun playing it, but I think more of that was getting together with my Borderlands buddies online again than the actual game content. It is a good game; if you like Borderlands-style gameplay, it is an eventual must-have, but there are other games to play until this one comes down to a more reasonable price.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												I'll keep a TL;DR version up top.  My review in a nutshell...Do you hate Borderlands?  Don't buy this.Do you love Borderlands? KEEP THOSE GOOD MEMORIES. DON'T BUY THIS. SERIOUSLY.(And if you're questioning the 400 "positive reviews" - keep in mind this.  At the time of writing this, for GLOBAL ACHIEVEMENTS, 75% of people have the achievement for hitting level 5.  Only 25% have the achievement for hitting level 10.  They aren't even playing the game, just snapjudging.  PLEASE SAVE YOURSELF THE TROUBLE.)[[-- If you still feel like playing this mess, I'll add some game-breaking bugs at the bottom of this review. Maybe it'll salvage it for you. --]]Waited a long time for this to come out, friends all took off from work and got together to binge this game to death - having loved the first two Borderlands.After the first 3 hours, the characters were forgettable, story was .. whatever and none of us seemed willing to say anything yet.  Scared it was just us.After 4 hours, we all looked at each other and went, "This kind of sucks." One of us held out saying, it's still early.After 7 hours, that last person gave in and agreed this was pretty bad.We went to sleep at this point.The next morning we completed this unpolished turd.  None of us want to even try a second playthrough.  It was one of the most unsatisfying experiences we've ever had in a co-op game.  The only fun that was had were the jokes we were making between ourselves.This is an overpriced DLC - and that's being generous.  As a DLC, it falls short of Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep.  That had more interesting writing, varied areas and weapons.The oxygen mechanic is horrible and tacked on.  You get so much oxygen tanks that it doesn't matter, it seems it's only there to be annoying.The "Butt Smash" is a nice brake-mechanic, but as an offensive move - it's just tossing you into melee range so you can be killed easier.The damage is horribly balanced.  There are two types of enemies, normal ones and "Badass" ones.  The former killing you in 3 hits, the latter killing you before they've seen you.  AND THIS IS PLAYTHROUGH ONE.  It felt like the level range of 51-60 in Borderlands 2. Loot? What loot.  The only decent loot we found were from the automatic purples we got from Shift Keys. (Which were also bugged, seems everytime we stepped up to the machine we got another set of 5.)-------------------Bug 1:  Play Nisha.  Spec middle tree down to having double pistols.  Now equip a pistol so you have two out.  Now respec... to anything.  Ta-da.  You now keep your two pistols!  (Until you log out.)  Unlike before, you can use your Right-Click to fire your second gun instead of Zoom in with one gun.  Seems like they did a bad job modifying Salvadore's active skill here.Bug 2: ONLY WORKS IN MULTIPLAYER, WHEN NOT HOSTING.  It has to do with how the client updates to the host. Anyway ... Any melee over-ride skill while using a free spin scroll mouse.  (This works in Borderlands 2 also, with Maya's Slag Bomb thing. I mean.. it's the same engine and all.)  I've only tested this with Nisha in this one though.Anyway, spec yourself to Lightning Whip in left tree.  Set your melee skill to mouse-scroll-up or down.  Spin that mouse.  Ta-da!  You'll use it like 5-10 times per use.  (It's hard to see with Nisha, but you'll notice a lot more tendrils of lightning.)  It's easier to see in BL2 when she fires out 10 slag bombs at once.Enjoy..  Sort of.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I don't think the game is really worth the current pricing. With a discount though, it's probably worth it. Here's why: Poorly balanced, just as bad if not worse than Borderlands 2. I still play BL2, mostly because I have friends to play with, but nobody I play with thinks that getting downed in 2-4 hits feels fair. In BL:TPS this doesn't seem any different. The higher level you get, the stronger the issue seems to become, especially if you're having bad luck with loot drops, i.e. having less of a fighting chance. Bosses are few in my opinion and they almost don't feel meaningful, even though they're supposed to have a major relevance in the story's development. Bosses are also, again, poorly balanced. They often have minions that join the battle, presumably so you can get second winds if you go down, but they almost do the opposite because of their own individual power. The last and before-last bosses atleast had some "loot explosions" but I must have been extremely unlucky because most of it was junk, this despite the fact that I had really crappy equipment, many levels out-dated, which made me struggle to do the actual fights. The story was good for the most part, but it feels rather short and the way the characters evolve is predictable (somewhat understandable) but I just think there could have been - a lot - more character development. Oh, right, and almost everyone that isn't a character of some importance has an australian accent, which seemed to get old a little fast for people who watched me play through. Interface. Everything is the same as BL2, which isn't bad by itself, but the BL2 UI had some ergonomic issues - such as the poor handling of the way the interface "slants" and panels block each other - and had a few glitches that haven't been fixed, like one that happens when scrolling through the backpack. In addition, the way Eridium is just translated into Moonstone is a bit unimaginative, as it serves the exact same purpose, and the story explanation doesn't feel good enough to me. Of all the Borderlands games, this has to be one with the worst bugs. Mobs go THROUGH the floors, walls, ceilings, whatever! At certain parts of the game I had to start areas over because of this as they made completing certain sections impossible. I've read that even you, the player, can fall through the ground but I didn't experience this personally. Sadly zones feel too big and vehicles aren't useable in several zones, and in the ones that they are useable in, they have limited areas you'll manage to use them in. Very few fast travel stations in my opinion, considering how annoying it is to trek around. My biggest issue with the size of the zones though, is that if for some reason I needed to quit the game while doing the story bits in the larger zones, I'd get sent back to a stupid point that was possibly quite far from where I stopped playing.Overall the game was fun to play and the addition of the new element was "cool" (replaces slag from BL2 though) and the grinder added a bit of variety to the way you can go about getting or upgrading gear, although it feels slow and cumbersome, due to the way you will pile up even more stuff than usual in your backpack.But in the end, it feels more like an expansion of sorts for BL2 than an actual new game, still having "old" issues. In addition, the fact that the story content is kind of short makes all of the content in general feel kind of short to me, with all the side-missions being more or less equal to each other than they usually would be in the past. Perhaps things will get better with DLC.I'd like to recommend a "Yes" for this, but I can't. Too many little things.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												TLDR: The next installment in the Borderlands Franchise that doesn't achieve the same level of greatness that its predecessor did while asking for a whopping $70 Australian Dollars. Copied the guns straight from Borderlands 2 but none of the humor or storytelling that made Borderlands 2 a masterpiece. Also the Australian Voices feel really out of place.The main issues with this installment of the borderlands franchise is that it feels really lazy and unfinished in comparison to Borderlands 2 and even 1. With Borderlands 2, the game felt complete and it felt like a massive upgrade to Borderlands 1, the classes were crazy, heaps of new weapons and guns and loot, hilarious story and a blast to play through from start to finish and once you got to the end it felt like an awesome and complete experience and once the dlc came out it was like delicious extras on an already excellent game. Then the Pre - Sequal comes along, asking for $70 Australian Dollars which i believe was more than Borderlands 2 was asking for when it came out and fails to come close with the humor or enjoyability of the previous games, and once i pushed myself to endure the crappy australian accents that don't flow well at all with the characters and feels really out of place and the boring quests that require you to go from A to B to C back to A, I found and excellent end boss that was actually fun to fight and felt like old Borderlands and that was it. I believe that the Pre Sequel is much shorter than Borderlands 2 with a lot of the length coming from quests that require you to go to one side of the map and back again and to add insult to injury, a lot of the weapons are taken straight from Borderlands 2 in both name and design. In the end the game feels dull and boring in comparison the Borderlands 2 and feels incredibly unfinished, future DLC may make the game feel complete and enjoyable but no game asking for $70 or any amout should require DLC to make it fun. Save yourself the cash and wait for the GOTY editon to come out or when some dlc is out and the game is cheaper.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												Overall, a great game. I believe the hate generated to the game is just from the jackasses that think "just because Admiral Bahroo didn't like it, that means I shouldn't as well!". In all honesty, this is a great game, only if you go into the game with a clean slate. I've never watched a preview or had any knowledge of the game before buying it. I played the previous Borderlands, and enjoyed them. When I got TPS, I got it on sale for about $30 (season pass included). The game does exactly what a "Pre-sequal" would do. It goes over alot of the characters and events that have been described in the previous games. The character developement is on an outstanding level. For example, one of the characters is Jack's doppleganger. Every skill tree at his disposal, is very unique and masterfully created to be used to force a playstyle that mimics the very personalities of "the man who would be Jack". All of the characters are a pleasure to play, except Claptrap (I haven't played him yet). The characters all feel very balanced, and because there really isn't an endgame like in BL2, the characters preform well in combat.The story felt much more rich and deep in a way when compared to BL2. This is because of the effort that was put into the individual characters. As the story progresses, Jack's personality changes, some characters like that, some don't. These small details are what determine the mentioned character's fates in a future timeline. If you pay attention to these small details in all of the games, you will recognize that all these details are well fitted into the game in a storyline that would make sense.I can think of so many good things about the game, however, no game is perfect. One of the flaws would have to be the oxygen mechanic and how it interacts with the fire elemental type. Because logically speaking, fire cannot burn without Oxygen. Alot of the combat is done in zero oxygen enviorments, therefore weapons that are fire elemental are less versitile and very situational. Another flaw to the game is the balance of laser weapons. Laser weapons are great, one of my favorite features about the game. The problem is that they are too good. I am not saying remove lasers because they are imbalanced, but I can't think of any situation where a laser weapon would be inferior to any other type of weapon. Another problem would be the story. I enjoyed the story and thought it was very enjoyable, but after playing it over and over again just makes quests that require you to go "fetch" something, that much more boring. The story is amazing, yet it lacks in replay value heavily but in a way, BL2 was the same way, just not as bad. The BIGGEST moment where every logical person claims that TPS loses to BL2, is the endgame. BL2 had better legendaries, it also had better DLC, more raidbosses, and OP levels just to name a few reasons. This is the main problem that people like Admiral Bahroo have with the game. THIS IS OK BECAUSE UNLIKE EVERYONE WITH LIKE 10 HOURS, THESE PEOPLE HAVE MADE IT TO THE "ENDGAME". Because they have made it to the endgame, they understand where BL2 was better than TPS. 2K Austrailia was never really able to keep working the game, because the game was scrapped because of all the negative critisism.Overall, a great game. It does use the same engine as BL2 >:( not something I am a fan of, but just imagine it as a $30 DLC for BL2. Completely worth it in my opinion. The reason why this review is because I genuinely liked TPS and enjoyed playing it a lot. It's a shame that no one will give the game a chance....Wowzers! you made it to the end of my review xd. Here is your reward:
