content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Be careful for spoilers.I was so excited for this game. Borderlands 2 was the first Steam Game I bought on my new account and it was so amazing that I even forced my friends to buy the game too. And they LOVED it. We played together for hours and I met some really crazy and fun people to conquer the Legendary Weapons and bosses together. When there was a new DLC out, I knew it was worth the price and I had to get it. Not because the game was unplayable and you needed the DLC to feel like you had a real game now, like EA *cough*, but because it just made the game a complete new adventure and the whole atmosphere was renewed. The Tiny Tina DLC? It blew my mind. It's my favorite DLC and the complete thing is amazing. So yes, I did pre-order Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. The trailer showed nothing too exciting for me, but the game and the way it was played have always made the Borderlands series what it is now. Borderlands 1? Great. Fast. LOOT. Rare loot was rare. The bosses were innovative. Then, Borderlands 2. Amazing. LOOT. RARE LOOT. Legendary LOOT. The bosses? ♥♥♥♥ing art. But Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel? Not so good. Yes, I was disappointed. A lot. Why, you ask? Well, let me tell you.First I thought the game was alright and I was excited to start, but that didn't work out too well. For me, living in Europe, the game was said to come out on the 16th. Didn't happen. Had to stay up until the 17th 1am to get it. I played for one hour, was level five until the first bug arrived and threw♥♥♥♥♥♥in my face.Couldn't shoot anymore, never gained EXP, didn't level. So I restarted. And everything was good. But the game, it just didn't feel alright. It was slow, enemies literally approach you in slow motion, and the fast, colory shooty became slow and grey. The colors kind of vanished from the world (In- and outside) and the only time you find a really Borderlands 1 and 2 feeling atmosphere is in the very last place. Yes, the very last one. And to get there, you had to somehow play your way through the not triggering dialoges, enemies spawning underground and not being able to continue the quest, loot that flies away, getting thrown off the map and dying, jumping way too slow and far and dying, somehow glitching through the round and dying and enemies that do not care if you're around until you shoot. Not even them. Just, shoot. The AI is crap, but after a while you just gloss over that. But why did the game take me 9h to complete the main story?Well, because the quest-markers were♥♥♥♥♥♥ They showed that an objective was right in front of you, same level. Only to find out that you had to go all the way around, up, press some buttons and then jump down to get it. Without mentioning it. Nice. Took me ages. And that wasn't fun. Oh, and one more thing: If you're like me and you accept side quests to do them later, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. Some Side quests give you a mission weapon, like in Borderlands 2. But not all of the, are marked as mission weapons.That way I couldn't do most of them. Accepted them while doing the main quest or just accepting all side quests to do them later. Nope.The Nova Shield? Not even mentioned. The weapon to get the peaceful enemies angry? Ha, na. And the mission weapons you already used?They stay mission weapons. Forever.Then why did you keep playing it?Oh, well. Even tho the game is not like Borderlands 1 & 2, it's still Borderlands. The dialogs are still cheesy and sometimes make you giggle. The characters feel real and all have their own secrets and personalities. The voice acting is good. The world is colorless but still nice to look at, sometimes. The cutscenes weren't unnecessary and helpful and the shooting everything was fun.And what about the weaaaappoooons? They good?That's another point, actually. The weapon drops from enemies are♥♥♥♥♥♥ But the new elements, like laser and frost, are amazing and can actually make the game easier. Just getting them is hard. If they don't fly away. On the very last quest there is a little boss that spawns other and more enemies. My weapon froze him and it took me not even 5 seconds to get his shield and him down. The loot flew off into space and was never seen again. Win.But it's still nice to freeze your enemies (not forever), or laser them, or just shoot them. The way the weapons look is nothing new or special. Like Borderlands 2. And the story? I mean, did you listen to it?Yes, I did. Only after replaying a level for the 6th time I didn't, because the dialouge from the VERY beginning of this level started playing. Like, when you arrived. Even if you have been there for 24h. The story at the beginning wasn't exciting and only when the "flashbacks" spoke, you knew somethign would happen. In the middle of the game the story SLOWLY evolved. And the only REAL time I was really soaked into the game and didn't want to stop playing was the end.How the bosses from Borderlands 1 & 2 just came together and EVERYTHING, I mean, EVERYTHING was explained. It all makes sense now. All two games before make sense. Moxxie's secret was INSANE, Jack's growing was SO NICELY DONE, and the old Vault Hunters, like Lilith and Modecai from BL1, actually felt REAL if you played them back in the days, because they ACTUALLY remembered and all that. It was great. And the last cutscene, where Borderlands 2 pretty mch begins, just makes you want to reply Borderlands 2 because now you have so much background, it's just mind blowing.And Pro's con's or what?Pros:- Growing story, which was nicely told, but boring at first.-Growing characters and enemies. (Like, when new kinds of Guardians kept appearing, nicely done.)-The first two games being explained and remembered.-Flashbacks were nicely done.-Old characters that were still evolving, even thos they had beenin 2 games before.-New weapon elements.-New enemies. -The moon. Con's:-Bad loot that mostly flies off into space.-AI mostly doesn't care if you are around or not.-GLITCHES THAT MAKE THE GAME UNPLAYABLE.-Invincible enemies.-Enemies making you or your quest items stuck and you have to replay the whole thing.-Leveling is much easier because there are so many enemies everywhere.-The game feels slow.-Oxygen.-Gravity.And all in one? Would you recommend it?The game was good, but the feeling that you got at the end should have kicked in earlier. The "I don't want to stop playing" feeling just didn't exist. Until the last one hour. And then it was over. The story is good and evolving. So are the characters. They feel real and make old memories come back. The loot system is crap, but the new elements make up for it, same with the enemies. The AI is♥♥♥♥♥♥ but the new enemieraces balance that a little bit.The MultiPlayer is again more fun than the SinglePlayer, but that's clear, I guess. /Not anymore.I'd say I would recommend the game, just not NOW. (23.10.14)It's too buggy and I actually stopped playing for some days because it kept killing me for no legit reason. I once had an enemy under the ground and it didn't trigger the next spawn of enemies and I then decided to make my game online for everyone and no one had any idea. Later, some guy threw like a hundred grenades at the ground and he died. Nice.IF the bugs get fixed and you are through the main story line quest, there are TONS of side quests that I have not played yet. But like in BL1 & 2, I guess they will help you make your ingame time worth it.UPDATE: Most of them are bugged or are broken easily and it stops being fun. I didn't like the game until the very end. And that shouldn't and didn`t ever happen in any Borderlands so far. I was disappointed and even stopped playing. But I'd still say that it feels like a Borderlands, just not a complete game. If you are a fan, like me, you need to play it. If not, don't waste your time and money. Wait for a sale.6/10.

												Borderlands : The Pre-Sequel is a great game; however I don't think it's worthy of being considered a sequel - I've finished the campaign in 35 hours solo using Claptrap -(+) Pros(+) It's Borderlands(+) Gunplay is amazing an even smoother than Borderlands 2(+) Everything is connected to Borderlands 2(+) You get to play as Claptrap ( his action skill is not only chaotic and fun, but extremely useful, though sometimes unreliable )(+) Grinder mechanic is a great way to recycle unwanted items(+) Cryo is a great replacement to slag(+) Stingrays are fun to ride(-) Cons(-) Uninteresting world ; I get that it's a moon, but why does it have to be a moon? Everything from the moon surface to the eye of helios is pretty boring to explore(-) Uninteresting characters ; some even recycled(-) Most enemy designs are pretty much the same as Borderlands 2 ( ex. Scavs = Bandits , Torks = Spiderants )(-) 2nd and 3rd bosses are HARD ; however if you manage to beat them, rest of the game is pretty much a cakewalk(-) Platforming and mission designs sucks ( bad missions designs have wasted about 1 hour of my life )(-) Side missions are all errand boy stuff and becomes a chore to do(-) Moon buggies are a disasterIf you could get past all those cons ( which will sometimes frustrate you ) ; Borderlands : The Pre-Sequel is a great game worth trying out and playing for hours on end. Go for it, especially if you're a fan of the franchise < 7.5 / 10 >

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Low-gravity is a gimmick that overstays its welcome almost immediately, much of the game seems to be played in it and it makes the whole thing feel like a bad TF2 server. The low-grav tends to make loot fly into pits and lava hazards and jumping, floating enemies turns everyone into a Rakk for a short while.  Oxygen is a resource you have to manage now but running out of it is hardly an inconvenience, but you still run out of it and a voice tells you to get more of it which makes for frequent exploration interruptions.  Those are the two big mechanical changes and they're both more of a detriment to the shooting and exploring fun of the series' other games than any meaningful addition to the gameplay- now everyone just hangs in the air for a while and you have to breathe more. The early map feels very sparse and empty, which makes sense for being a moon but isn't as conductive to man-clicking as one would hope.  Aside from bandits the earliest mob you encounter is a type of armored skag which tends to soak up bullets from your starter guns, and the badass variant turns into smaller mobs every time you kill it. It feels more like the grindy sort of combat from late-game BL2 than the fun kinetic shooty combat from 2nd-playthrough BL2. It definitely starts out a bit harder but the hard seems to be the "waste of bullets" variety.Overall the mechanics are the same as BL2 with some unwelcome additions and the whole thing feels a lot less fast-and-fun than the actual sequel. Definitely not a $60 game, wait for the winter sale.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												So, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. After playing both the first and second games in the series, this one is definitely different. This game changes quite a lot from the first two. First, SPACE! This game takes place in, [SPOILER!], Space. More specifically, the moon and on the giant space station from Borderlands 2(BL2), Helios. So, that being said, the map isn't terribly large. It's definitely not as large as BL2's map, but being that BL2 was Supposed to have the biggest map, that's to be expected. Now, a lot of complaints I see about it is the low gravity and platforming aspects. First off, the low gravity feels floaty but it does Not restrict combat, it makes it fun by letting you get kills in the air. Trust me, losing the fun low gravity happens a few times in the game and you won't enjoy the loss of mobility that low gravity gives you. As for the platforming aspect, you run and jump. I guess that's platforming, but there's not many other ways to get around on foot to begin with. I've also noted that a few people complain about the slamming feature being required to progress, which is not true in the least. I have only played the main campaign, not the dlc, but there's only two quests I can remember that require it, and they're side quests. Alright, so now that those "problems" are cleared up, let's get back to the good parts that I love about it. One of my favorite changes to the game is the change from level 5 to level 3 to get your first action point. It doesn't seem like a big change, but that's two extra points to go towards the skill trees. They also added a new type of gun, lasers. I can sum them up really easy: either they're awesome or they aren't. The story is kind of short but fun. I like that there's varied voice actors, or at least varied accents. There's some Australian, some British, and of course the normal American. The story is interesting, albeit a bit short, it shows a different perspective to the character Handsome Jack which is what it was supposed to do. The game is just enough like the old ones to make you want to play and new enough to keep you playing. The price, I will admit, is a bit high. Personally, I was able to catch it on a cheap sale, and I recommend you do the same. I don't feel $40 is worth it, (but really, I hardly feel any game is worth more than $20) but for $15 or $20 you'll feel feel that it was a great buy.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												gameplay and mechanics in TPS are miles ahead of Borderlands 2 where it gets boring trekking back and forth over and over again, this is because of a more intuitive map/mission design overall where they tend to give you almost all the missions the first time around rather than sending you back xxx times to a zone miles away.story is not quite as long but i prefer that as it's probably the right length to avoid it becoming a chore. story also feels less contrived to me, while still having it's weak moments, the setting feels a lot more involving. the game world is slightly more linear which leads to it feeling less like a free-roaming game - this would have been very easy to remedy imo.the oxygen and jump boost mechanics are definitely a breath of freshly generated air, making travel on foot more efficient but also more enjoyable as it just gives that bit of extra freedom that allows better traversal of the often jagged landscape that is almost trademark to the Borderlands series. it is very rare for the oxygen mechanic to pose a problem as there are O2 generators everywhere, and when it does, i feel that it adds to the exhilaration, as you desperately sprint to find that precious O2 refill, while your health very slowly ticks down (when O2 is completely empty). i like how managing the jump boost and O2 becomes a balance, as you use O2 to boost and speed your travel whilst trying not to deplete your supplies too much until you see another refill point.new hoverbike plays nicely, brings an alternative utility for a vehicle with it's ability to propel itself upwards for a few seconds. other traditional BL game mechanics such as storage deck upgrades take a more streamlined approach, mostly quality of life improvement to avoid players standing around wasting time for example at the slot machines. new lazer and cryo weapon types are both interesting and effective.the heroes! they are just generally much cooler and more badass in TPS than BL2, and it's not just their look/characterisation, but also the special abilities which definitely pack more of a punch. overall this adds the feeling that they actually deserve their legendary reputations, unlike BL2 where it's more about SAYING how badass they are rather than just simply being badass.by far the worst aspect of this game is the lack of good DLC, as the only real, fully-fleshed DLC is the Claptastic voyage, and while that has novel ideas and style to it, it starts to get dull before too long. this game desperately needs new DLC areas set elsewhere on the moon of Elpis, something i fear it will never receive now.

Posted: October 12, 2016
												A lot of people hate this for various mechanics issues and I can kind of see what they're talking about. The maps involve a lot of running around and it's not THAT bad, but it is inferior to BL2. What is bad is that the story feels forced. It's very difficult to write a villain's descent into madness because readers/players will find it very easy to go, "Dude, can't you tell you're kind of being a♥♥♥♥♥♥right now?" And this game does NOT solve that. People have tried to explain it to me saying, "Well, the characters are flawed." or "Well, he [Jack] was pushed over the edge," but like, none of it is very convincing. All the characters are still fun to play as in various ways so you can just play it as a shooter. However, it is impossible to play this single-player which ultimately earns my thumbs down. There was only one large DLC which some claim is a great analogy for depression but I feel is inferior to Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep from BL2.

number of helpful: 32 of 57 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												I can't give a sideways thumbs-up, so consider this thumbs up as tenative as you can find. I'll start with the bad stuff because of that. I'm going to presume you're familiar with Borderlands already. If not, go start with Borderlands 2 the next time it's on sale if you're interested. It'll take you awhile, and when you're done, come back.It still has a lot of the Borderlands 2 issues - most weapon drops are vendor trash, there's no way to level up a favorite item, quests are full of pointless trekking back and forth and back again, it still has MMO-style boss grinding tedium in the endgame, some of the jokes are super dumb, weapons are repeated from previous games (this may be good or bad, depending on the weapon), the story doesn't make much sense and is pretty disposable, guns often lack that kinetic "oomph" in terms of sound and SFX, the starting vehicles controls like a brick on springs, etc. The Australian gags may fall flat if you don't know crap about Australia, and the moon areas are sparse and kinda samey as well. It you didn't like previous Borderlands games, this will not change your mind in the slightest.On the other hand, moon jumping and slamming is rad and helps use the 3D aspect of the game to actual effect, the classes are more fun and balanced than previous iterations, the humor does have some really cute gags, leveling is linear instead of quadratic, shops now often offer more rare items (and they're leveled to your character properly), you get a lot more dialogue personalized to your class, the second vehicle you get is pretty handy, lasers are fun, ice weapons are way more fun than slag weapons, etc.It's not deviating much from the formula, but if you enjoyed the previous Borderlands games this is worth a go-round once it drops in price. It's not as great as it could be, but all Borderlands games are a mix of joy and dissapointment, and this one at least erred towards the joy end of things for me.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Despite the obvious negativity from the Borderlands community, stating this "isn't a full game/feels more like a big DLC," this game has its charm. At first, I was disappointed as well, but I found as I played it again, I liked the energy it created. I could even so much as say I like The Pre-Sequel over Borderlands 2.The one thing I love most about this game is that it establishes one major essence of the Borderlands series that I didn't fully comprehend until now: there are no "good" guys. Every character has flaws, every character has at least some questionable morals. And they all make mistakes! (A non-spoiler-ish example would be Mr. Torgue, who in this game has absolutely no respect for Janey or for females at all - but you hear present day Mr. Torgue butt in the story to say he apologized for his awful behavior back then. Because people can change, for either the better or the worse--)All the characters, especially the playable ones, are quirky and lovable in their own ways. There are a lot of things in this game that I wished they did in Borderlands 2, either gameplay-wise or story-wise. I hope that they adopt some of the mechanics from this game into their next one (mostly the fact that the characters actually reply with spoken lines, which Borderlands 2 only did in their DLC, because I'm a sucker for banter).Any fan of the Borderlands series should play this game, not only does it add more lore, it adds to the story, the overall gameplay, and to the cast of colorful characters in the Borderlands series. Play it, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												[NO PLOT-SPOILERS TO BE FOUND HERE]Stupid company. The first Mega-StandAlone-AddOn with DLCs ever. We've never had this before! A bright future we're looking into!This should have been more of a big AddOn or gigantic DLC but not a fullpriced "new" game. It's basically BL2 with a new story and some reskinned enemies/cars/weapons/vendormats/etc. It's very hard NOT to see this game as a more-or-less simple cash-grabbing.The good: I can play as CLAPTRAP! (and still there are some claptrap-bots in the game to laugh about) The new story fills some open plotholes Fighting is still funny Bizarre characters and bosses again ("Red and belly sitting in a tree, K I S S....hm, that sounded wrong") Balance! No matter how good my weapons are, how far i level or how i spend my skillpoints, most enemies (in level-range of course) are still a kind of challenge, yet i'm seldomly overpowered by any enemy Nice soundtrack (again) Characters are now addressed as themselves (not only as "vaulthunter") The whole "low-gravity-thing" is quite funny, hopping from pad to pad or using your "jetpack-for-the-poor" to jump around. Yay! I can play CLAPTRAP! 4 New classes, lots of new skills (some of which are just old stuff renamed though *sigh*) The engine's performance is SLIGHTLY better than BL2. Although PhsyX still is a mess. Looks beautiful, drops fps from >140fps to 15fps in an instant. YUCK! Why even include that feature again if it's unplayable even for console-heads?! "Nina nurse you!" (will still get annoying after hearing it for the 1230913rd time) new type of weapons, new type of machine (Grinder, nice...another one armed bandit lol), new misc. equipment new tons of stupid (startled/dying)-enemy-one-liners like "i should've known better" and the like. Always love it new bunch of silly humor not taking itself serious at all. Sometimes it's so stupid it becomes clever again. Even the racial-stereotype-dumb-humor like Russian Nina is hillarious. Just don't take it seriously :-) You're in for some nice funny suprises (*cough* Moxxie *cough) A weapon that will cuss at you (even calling you the rude version of the female primary genitalia) and your enemies with every shot. Hillarious! new cars with added third dimension element (up/down) Did i mention i can play as claptrap? EXPLOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOSIONS! AND LASERSSSSSSsss! Flawlessly included borderless windowed AKA non-exlusive fullscreen (still an issue in 2014 *sigh*) Cooperative online play (what a surprise) Ultimate-Vault-Hunter-Mode is kinda rewrapped in some Tiny Tina-narration. Not THAT much of new content though, but better than just the same thing again.The bad: As said: Way more of an addon than a fullprice game. Screw you Gearbox! Well played Gearbox! First the myriads of DLCs, now that bugger. With DLCs too, and i bet it'll be even more...We'll see. Some missions (or better: the variety of enemies encountered while doing them) become repetitive. Not that it gets boring (if you like the fighting part of BL) but i had wished for some more variety on each map (and overall) Low-gravity-induced bugs. Questitems that comfortably fly right into that lava sea over yonder. Nothing game-breaking yet (considering quitting/reloading is not gamebreaking) Introduction/Tutorial (until first major city like sanctuary) seems quite...boring when done the second time (for testing out the new classes) The engine is pretty much the same. Not the slightest graphical enhancement (beside the performance-improvements). Nothing at all. Even stupid AddOns mostly deliver some enhancements to the graphics. Not here. If you expect a damn nice/interesting/clever/brilliant/refreshing story/plot you'd be dissapointed. Even Tiny Tina's Keep-DLC was way above this generic story which is more of a plothole-filler than anything new. But to be fair, it's not totally uninteresting if you played BL1/BL2 The story will suck if you have not played BL1/BL2. You'd have no clue who is who or why this or that should be funny or is a reference...It's like taking a book with 600 pages and start at page 400. But if it would have been the other way round, fanboys would have been dissapointed. Hard to please them all. Not much settings to really tune the visuals to your machine's capabilities. Should be mandatory for an FPS title, but maybe i'm just picky. This oxygen-thing is quite useless and more annoying than a fun-addition. Mostly you're bombarded with oxygen if you don't need it, but suddenly, while exlporing a secret...Boom! Empty! Meh, gonna search O²... OMG i so much hoped for new one-liners in the vendor-bots, like Marcus' but no, it really started to become annoying in BL2 and now it goes on. But at least there's no more Dr.Zed :-) What really annoys me is the dampened sound if you're in free space. There is no sound at all, why try to be "realistic" there? Things that start to annoy really fast are sentences like "attention, breathable atmosphrere!" (woooow thanks dude, nearly missed that one) Why the f..ork are the controls for up/down different when in a vehicle? FOR WHAT REASON?! Too few quick-travel points. After a quest is done you basically have to walk the whole fricking way back killing every stupid enemy again. Meh. I'm german so i'm expected to say something totally nit-picky: There are SAMs that target me while i'm on the ground. Walking. Ridiculous!The ugly: PhsyX. No really Gearbox, are you insane in the membrane? A professional company with a decent budget working together with NVidia to deliver what? THIS? "Best played with NVIDIA"? Are you kidding me? To quote Nina on this: "No, is joke!". Keep it on low (off) *sigh* This goddam console-interface from hell. The design-decision-team should be all punished for that. "Hey why not make this 33-Inventory-Space a scrollable list of, say, 6 items at once?" - "Superb idea, what about not including anything important in one simple clickable screen for these PC-Users with more than 2 buttons too?" - "AWESOME! Nina nurse you!" They have not even try to enhance it slightly..."But why do you moron recommend it then he?" you may ask.Well, it's one of the very few (are there even any at all?) FPS that have a slight feeling of RPG and are yet stuffed with funny elements and self-referenced humor just on the sharp edge between being plain dumb and hillarious. On top of that it delivers a nice story that keeps you going, and most side-missions are funny and interesting to do. And on top of that it's a well balanced shooter with nice COOP-abilities.A) You've played BL1 and BL2:Loved them? GO GET IT! Have Claptrap ruin your party, have fun :-)They were just "ok"? Wait for the GOTY.B) You've not played BL1 and BL2 yet:If you like FPS mixed with mild RPG-influences (skills, leveling, currencies to buy stuff etc) you should give it a try.But for the love of god (or what's holy to you): Play BL1 & BL2 prior to this. You'll get them for pretty much nothing. BL1 is cool, BL2 is even cooler. If you're in a hurry, just skip the DLCs of both. There's no reason to start with part 3 even though it's called "pre-sequel".If you do like FPS, but are more into the "serious" kind like Battlefield or CoD or the likes and don't fancy leveling for a long time or managing resources and inventories (oh you will do)? Stay away. This is probably not what you want to play.tl;dr:9/10, will play again more than once and will buy most DLCs even if smart-me says "NO!". Haha, screw you smart-me, go read some books!May the Schwartz be with you!

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I can only repeat what everyone else is saying: yes, it has its shortcomings, but if you love the series, you'll probably love this. If you're not a fan, probably nothing here will sway you. I personally love it. The Aussie humour won't appeal to all but I kinda like it. The new weapon-types are pretty cool: laser weapons and cryo elemental damage is well implemented. I like at least something about all the new characters. Athena, Nisha, Wilhelm, Claptrap and Jack (note: at time of writing the final dlc character hasn't been released) all have something going for them, be it tanking, damage or healing. The graphics are pretty timeless due to the nature of the engine and the soundtrack is up to the usual standards. Boss fights are generally fun and the storyline, presentation and dialogue is generally hilarious/appropriately serious but with a few misses. But yes, it does kinda feel like a glorified expansion.To summarise, if you love the series, essential. If it's "like" rather than "love", you'll probably like it but it's not essential to your life. If you're not fussed about the series you probably won't be swayed. If you really hate the series, well, nothing will convert you, I don't think ;)

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Let's see how much content this game has (Assuming you have all DLC):Around 25 hours for the main campaign if you're doing most stuff.There's 6 playable characters (2 of which are DLC), so 25 x 6 = 150.The Claptastic Voyage DLC adds another 6 hours for each character, so 6 x 6 = 36.And there's New Game+ mode for each playthrough, doubling the time.Let's calculate:(150 + 36) x 2 = 372 hoursThis is an insane amount of content, and I'm not even counting the Holodome and playing it in COOP!The game is highly recommended, not only for the ludicrous amount of content you're getting, but because the gameplay is also excellent.

												An honest and short review for Borderlands Fans...This game is enjoyable and fun, you got new features and items like:-Laser Weapons-Grinder-Oz Kits-Double Jump-Low GravityThat will make you feel good in a new Borderlands game, which is awesome!When you start to play the game you enjoy at some point, after you beat the game you will get stuck with only 1 raid boss! Which means this game has no endgame like Borderlands 2. It's lack out of content:- Small Maps.- No Rare Monsters- Like Chests monsters, Rank up Monsters etc...- No Loot Midgets.- Only 1 Raid Boss.- Few Side Quests.- No Side Maps- that's not for story line but for side quests.- Small Bosses aren't repeatable.- Specific Legendary Items drop only from specific "not repeatable" bosses.- Short Game.( I will not mention any bugs! though there's some annoying ones, every new game starts with bugs)In other words, currently the game is short and no content, this is not the Borderlands we used to love!If you want to compare The Pre-Sequel to Borderlands 2- New release to a new release= Borderlands 2 release was way better than Pre-Sequel, with alot more content and endgame.Final review is 7.0Still, i recommend The Pre-Sequel but not now of course! If you love Borderlands games just wait until there's more DLCs in this game. You better play the "endless" Borderlands 2 instead.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Thus far, I've had a very negative experience with this game. Allow me to list a few of the glaring issues I've noticed while playing; - Quest objects frequently get stuck inside walls due to badly designed maps. - The game slows down to 20 FPS during large-scale fights. - The Co-op has broken on frequent occasions; My friend has crashed trying to connect, and on one occasion he connected and the game had removed all of his weapons, with no way to get them back. - If you die and respawn, the AI "turns off" until you attack them.  - The game has thought I was playing multiplayer when I was in a singleplayer game, barring me from progressing when I came to an area where all players had to be together. These are only a few of the major issues I've encountered during my time playing. In terms of what this game has added when compared to Borderlands 2, it really doesn't feel like enough content has been added for this game to be worth it. It may as well be a DLC for Borderlands 2. The story isn't very well done either, as well as the fact that it has ruined Jack. Not to mention this game is going for a full $60. Overall I would say this game is half complete and rushed, and is not worth buying.

Posted: February 13, 2016
												Lets make it clear first, despite all the bad review Borderlands The Pre-Sequel is NOT A BAD GAME.People saying♥♥♥♥♥♥because this game is not as good as the previous 2 games and Pre-Sequel feels like a huge dlc for Borderlands 2 due to the same graphic and similar combat mechanic. The main difference between TPS and B2 are :1. Replacing relics with Oz kit, which is an oxygen helmet because well... duh you're in space. There will be another bar below your health indicating your oxygen so this kinda add more challange to your gameplay because you have to keep an eye on your oxygen too while on moon surface and besides adding oxygen it also provides a boost to stat or bonus just like relics in BL2.2. Replacing slag with cryo, which IMO is a good thing because i'm not using slag too much in BL2. Well cryo is a lot better because not only it adds more dmg when enemy is frozen (not as effective as slag though) the fact that the enemy is indeed frozen (meaning they stopped shooting) is what makes it better especially when encountering badasses.Other than that, there's not much notable difference between TPS and BL2 besides the story and characters obviously, there's maybe a slight difference in skill trees but the HUD, weapons, etc. is almost the same.So overall I think this game is good and worth to get but definitely not on full price. My advice is go get it only when the price dropped 50% or higher. If you are a fan of Borderlands and wanted to know a lot more about the stories especially Handsome Jack's origin, then this game is definitely for you.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												First off, I’ve always loved Borderlands games and enjoyed playing them. When I decided to buy the pre-sequel, my expectations were the same with Borderlands 1 and 2. I was craving some more Borderlands grinding, cool mobs and fun story/dialogs and boy... The Pre-Sequel surely delivered. First, the good stuff:•	Everything you loved from the previous games grinding, mobs, clever dialogs, good level design, all that jazz… they’re still fun.•	The moon adds a new aspect to the game, new mechanics like O2 levels and low gravity. You always have to be aware of your O2 level when you are in a vacuumed area.  Low gravity is really fun. Jumping puzzles are cleverly hidden and feels fresh coming from Borderlands 2.•	There are more guns with different combinations, like railguns and LASERS!!!!1!1.•	The new Vault Hunters are more likeable and they are written better. They have some kind of character now but still I encourage you the buy the doppelganger DLC to play as Jack. He is one of my favorite Vault Hunter, ever (might be after Brick).•	Handsome Jack’s story explains a lot from the second game and makes you love the previous Vault Hunters even more.Now the bad stuff:•	Some missions are still unbearably booooring. “You have to go here. Oh the door is locked? You need to power it the door. Oh, if you want to power it, you need to find the engine... Damn, to go to the engine, you need a key… To get the key you need the kill this boss.” FML!!!!!111!!!!1•	If you don’t like the Borderlands’ humor, nature, sense, personality… This game won’t convince you and won’t change anything…•	The rare currency is changed to Moonstones from Eridium. And its color is light blue. Guess what is also white blue… THE WHOLE ♥♥♥♥ING MOON. So whenever a moonstone is dropped, it’s very hard to see. But thank god they buffed the drop so moonstones drop far more than Eridium.•	The new vehicle, hovercraft, Stingray handles like♥♥♥♥♥♥ Plain horse♥♥♥♥♥♥ I don’t know why they even tried to squeeze it in the game.At the end, the game doesn’t fall short and delivers a great Borderlands experience. If you liked the previous games and you’re a hardcore fan, the game justifies a full price. But you just like to play it from time to time… wait for a real discount like %50-%75 then buy the game. You won’t regret it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I loved the new playable characters.  This is the best set of PCs yet.  None of them are useless for once.  All of them are fun to play, with more than one correct build.Unfortunately, you can only play those characters in this game.  Which means I've stopped playing them.The presequal's maps are trying and failing to make use of the (not actually that much fun) low grav movement mechanics.  It ends up just making maps hard to navigate.  And the quest's have you do a terrible amount of backtracking.  I hate walking sim crap.The jokes suck.  Maybe I just don't get Australian humor.  I was horribly let down.The best part of 2 was Handsome Jack being a♥♥♥♥♥♥  This whole, let's follow Jack's fall to the darkside thing isn't working.  He sucks as a sympathetic character.  He's just not interesting.  And it doesn't do a good job of telling that story anyway since he just goes nuts all in one scene.  There isn't this gradual fall like they were trying to let on.I was also pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off by the fact that they decided to make money a scarce resource.  I've played several hundred hours of Borderlands 1 and 2.  This is the first time I've ever ran out of money.  Until I started picking up guns just to sell (which is some tedious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t) I actually ran out of money to buy ammo.  This is a huge departure from the previous games, where money wasn't actually that important.  And I don't think this new method is fun.This is the worst Borderlands of the series.  I just went back to playing Borderlands 2.  My verdict is, wait until this gets very cheap before you let curiosity get the better of you.  It's worth 5 bucks just to find out how far you can get before quitting in bewilderment at what they've done.  But boy do I feel dumb for having let my absolute love of 1 and 2 convince me to pre-order.

Posted: November 21, 2015
												If there was a mixed choice, I would choose it.This game is particualar bad, but it also isn't the greatest game ever.Like most people would say, this game should have been made a DLC. It seems too short and a waste of money. I only paid $24 + a free Shock Drop Slaughter Pit (cuz I bought the retail ver). This game isn't worth the full price. If you really want this game, buy it during the Steam sales or the retail ver.The story of this game is how Jack rose to power and you help him get to the vault and essentially save Pandora and Elpis. Everything in this game is pretty much like BL2 besides the added cryo element, laser guns & slam damage. The character classes aren't all that great. DLC characters Doppelganger Jack and Lady Hammerlock seem to be better choices. And don't count on new legendaries in this game. They're a direct copy of BL2 legendaries and only a few new ones are added. If you buy the Claptastic Voyage DLC, you get access to Glitch weapons. Which are kinda cool but not really special. The humour in this game is dry, the missions mostly require you to run back in fourth to point A to point B.  Oh and in order to get Vault Hunter Pack up to level 60 (max), you need to buy both Pack seperately. The Holodom is worthless, I didn't buy it but you could just watch the playthroughs on YouTube and the only reason that it worth buying is the dialouge between Axton, Athena and Gaige. Shock Drop is completely worthless, its just another set of slaughter rounds. The game gets boring very quickly becuase of the lack of missions.Its an okay game for people who've played BL2, but if you're just starting out, you're not gonna understand anything the character will be talking about.  /long review, sorry! >_<

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
This is mostly going to be a positive review. I am writing this review after I've reached level 50 with my character and completed almost every quest so I guess I can judge the game as fairly as possible. // 1 //For those who expect too many changes, sorry. This game is very similar to Borderlands 2. Engine, graphics, humor and other key features are very similar to BL2. However, that doesn't mean it's a bad thing. Those who loved Borderlands 2 are definitely going to atleast like Pre-Sequel, if not to love it as well.// 2 //In my opinion, the story was solid, it wasn't too epic, but it was enjoyable. It filed the gaps between BL1 and BL2. Gameplay was amazing, I absolutely enjoyed every aspect of it, especially the low gravity, butt-slams, cryo guns, laser guns, moon surface and much more. They did a great job on this. Soundtrack was solid, but it felt a bit calm in many parts of the maps. Too calm maybe, I sometimes didn't even hear it over the shooting and EXPLOSIONS. The game just keeps doing what Borderlands 2 did great and keeps improving that. Levels are much more balanced, combat is balanced, gameplay improved, etc.// 3 //To not make this review too long, here are my pros and cons about Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel.+ Gameplay+ Story+ Graphics, aesthetics+ Atmosphere+ Shooter elements, rpg elements+ Leveling up, progression of your character+ 4 player coop+ Laser guns of course :D- Repetitive? (for some people, this is a negative thing)- Lack of originality- Lazy re-skinned models of guns from BL2- Soundtrack, not bad, but could be improved much more- PhysX, doesn't work smoothly (60+fps) on majority of high-end computers- No button to autmatically refill your ammo! (ha-ha, iz joke)That's about it, the game doesn't have many negative aspects, nothing that would ruin the game.For a new player to BL series, those negatives won't probably even matter.My score would be 8/10 for this game. It's great, fun and enjoyable, especially with good friends, but could have been much better. It had a lot of potential. But just like any other game, it can not be perfect.~Camper

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Genre - Comedy Sci-Fi FPS/RPGI played through the first two games and this one, both alone and with friends. I enjoy the mix of FPS and RPG and the varied guns you find allowing you to always play for new loot. The story fills in gaps between the first and second games and is enjoyable to playthrough and follow. After a normal playthrough you can up the difficulty and go through it again for even more loot and to reach level 50. I assume ther will be more DLC released that will add more missions and stories so I am in no rush to do this yet. I also find the game just as fun in solo on the first playthrough as with friends. You will need to co-op against the raid boss on the final mission though! The cell shaded graphics look cool and the four characters are varied enough that you could go through the game with each (hopefully there will be a couple more of these coming too). I found the game just the right length, if you do all the missions and I didn't get bored considering I have seen something very similar twice before. So if it ain't broke...

content:
Posted: February 5
												Summary is at the end.After the legend that was Borderlands 2, many people had high expectations for the next game in the series. This has been a consistent problem in the gaming community is that we overly hype a game to such a degree that it would be impossible for the final release to fufill our expectations. Some of this game not meeting the expectations of the fanbase is indeed due to shortcomings of the game/developers. This includes things such as the shorter storyline, lack of a real endgame that made Borderlands 2 have it's incredible replay value, a decent number or reskinned enemies ported over from BL2, bosses not respawn when the game was first released (No longer the case, it's patched now c:), lack of many "Raid Bosses" as seen in BL2, and 2k Australia's death causing this game not getting the 2nd expected content update that was expected for Season Pass holders. Yeah the humor is somewhat different from the previous games but it doesn't particularly bother me, and still gave me a chuckle now and again. I really have no feelings towards the Grinder one way or the other.The movement system in this game took me a while to deem as good or bad. What finally got me to decide it was definately an improvement was when I went back to play the previous installment, I couldn't help but try to do the air-boosts when running longer distances, or doing a butt slams to stop airial movement when knocked about (F**k you Terramorphous) I have mixed feelings about the O2 system, but at worst it was slightly annoying when running out of O2 so it didn't really bother me in the end. The pacing (and ending) of the game is MUCH better and more satisfying than the original Borderlands (which felt difficult to play for long stretches when I first got it), and is at least comparable to BL2 in that regard. Playing as a group of character's which are (for the most part) enemies in BL2 gave a greater appreciation for them in the previous game. Going back and replaying BL2 afterwards actually made the run more enjoyable which was probably an unintentional but nice effect nevertheless. In summary, I believe Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel was a good game. It added mechanics which made sense in the setting and which I felt added to the game. It did not match up with the expectations the previous Borderlands game set into motion and it does have some flaws, but I feel it is a good game and simply could never measure up due to how high our expectation were. If you're new to this franchise, I would personally recommend grabbing Borderlands 2: GOTY Edition first as it (and the DLC's that come with the GOTY edition) are in fact the superior experience. But for anyone who had played Borderlands 2 and enjoyed it: this game does a fair enough job with the tools it was given and does enough to add a great deal to previous installments to merrit giving it a go.Grabbing the Season Pass is up to you, main things in there worthwhile are the two DLC character's (which people like) and the content DLC Claptastic Voyage (which people love).

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												This is not Borderlands. It's the husk of it. The proverbial dead horse being beaten.The Story ...  ... sucks.I mean, we all know how it ends, right? Jack becomes a murdering psycho who enslaves the entire planet. But he actually starts off as a really nice guy who's willing to compromise, wants to save the world, sacrifices himself for others, and places his trust heavily in his "friends".The whole plot revolves around a number of decisions which make little to no sense. Betrayals which the characters lack motivation for, or even worse, is hand-waived based on events which took place "off-screen", before the player came along, and are part of the characters history, but aren't shared with us. What the heck, people?A lot of the major dialogs which lead to Jack becoming a murdering ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ actually have me feeling more sympathetic for him than for the so called "good guys". His shift to "evil" also feels completely unnatural and forced.Even the main characters (3 of whom are not really relevant to the greater story being told - only Athena is) feel very one-dimensional and under-represented. Did you want to find out:  How Wilhelm ended up in that robot chassis?  How Nisha ends up Jack's GF and Sheriff?  How Claptrap ends up stranded in a frozen wasteland, not to mention a completely useless idiot?Well, too bad, folks. The most you'll get to see - if you're patient enough to sit though the credits - are a few sketches poorly outlining those character's story lines. I mean, really? Such wasted potential for DLC content.The Humor ...  ... sucks.No, sorry. It doesn't suck - that's putting it far too mildly. It's absolutely terrible. Obnoxious. Childish. Forced. Over-the-top, and often mired in Australian lingo which simply doesn't resonate with most Western audiences at all.  In short it is disturbingly bad, especially for a Borderlands title.I remember laughing so hard while playing BL2 that my ribs hurt. I had few, if any moments when I even smiled during this game. Mostly I just imagined punching most of the characters into silence whenever they launched into one of their long winded and "humorous" monologues. And one more thing. Many of the short captions introducing important NPCs and bosses? Few were good, almost none were funny, and most simply fell flat.Gone is the witty, snappy humor of Borderlands, replaced with a PG13 Australian version (apparently) written by a failed comedian.The Loot ... ... sucks.Seriously? I remember combing through BL2's maps looking for every hidden weapon chest, and being rewarded with pretty decent weapons. I remember switching out guns as a I found better and better stuff. Now? Thank God for Gold Keys  is all I have to say. I stopped opening chests because there was simply no point. Even white loot drops were remarkably rare, nevermind a decent blue or purple weapon. Other than that the guns are what you already experienced in BL2, except for lasers and freeze rays - which, I admit, are sort of cool, but don't make up for all the other crap. The enemies ... ... suck.Not exactly the brightest of the bunch. I was able to run from one objective to another without having to engage most of them because they're slow to notice you, and don't really follow you very far. It was great when all I wanted to do was get to the next way-point - which they bounce around the map in order to force you to kill as many mobs as possible.Another important point: the game's number one progression mechanic is not to actually go places, but be stuck waiting for a door to open while enemies keep spawning on top of you. The grind is real in the Pre Sequel.The Lunar Mechanics... sort of suck.The low gravity and jump packs can be fun to play with. Constantly having to watch your O2 meter gets old within the first 10 minutes. Honestly, this is the first BL game where I had ZERO interest (see what I did there?) in trying to find the hidden content.   As many others have pointed out, driving the buggy pretty much sucks. The other vehicle type is also incredibly clunky and difficult to "jump" with, which is funny seeing how that's it's entire reason for existence.ConclusionI picked up this game and all the DLC's for a grand total of $20. I honestly feel like I got ripped off. This is not a Borderlands game. It's a travesty of one. It was seemingly made by people who sort of, kinda, understood what Borderlands is and got the lore somewhat right, yet managed to miss the heart and soul of it. This game is a major disappointment.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Contains what some may consider minor spoilers.A decent enough sequel (oh excuse me, PREQUEL) to BL2, it removes some major annoyances of the aforementioned game whilst introducing new ones but it's mostly more of the same, so I'll use BL2 for comparison on several occasions throughout the review.As for the graphics and sound effects - it's mostly the same as BL2. Many voice actors have an australian (or fake cockney) accent which is a nice enough change of scenery. Enemy chatter is not as entertaining as it was in BL2, sadly. Combat's not nearly as fun without people shouting "SEEEEEEEEMEEEEEEENNNN" while rushing towards you.The story feels like it takes relatively little substance and elongates it forever. The idea of documenting Handsome Jack's rise to power (and descent into psychopathic megalomania) is good but their approach to it is a bit too heavy-handed and melodramatic in places. I do like some of the little foreshadowing references to the events of BL2.There are several new gameplay mechanics which make the game feel fresh even though the core gameplay is still pretty much the same. The new things include:○ Limited oxygen: many areas of the game don't have a breathable atmosphere so your O2 supply will drain at a slow rate there. Boosts and butt slams drain oxygen at a noticably increased rate so you need to ration it well because you'll start taking damage when you run out (unless you're a claptrap). This feature can be very annoying sometimes as it artificially adds a sense of urgency to everything - exploration is not that much fun when you've got a time limit. The good thing is that enemies need to breathe too and they'll start taking suffocation DoT when you break their oxygen masks, allowing you to save some ammo.○ Low gravity & boost: allows you to reach places that'd be impossible to get to in BL2 so it takes a while to get used to the new possibilities. And you're going to have to – some missions require well timed jumps and boosts in order to reach the objective. If you really hate platforming, you might want to avoid this game.○ Butt slam: a quick way to get to the ground from mid-air, plus it does good damage and can inflict DoT effects - invaluable for saving ammo, but costs oxygen.○ Laser weapons: they pretty much replace E-tech, you can get various types which act shotgun-like, sniper-like, automatic or like the lightning gun from Quake 3. They're not bad but I found myself not using them much.○ The Cryo element: replaces slag, feels more satisfying to use - you can immobilise enemies then deal increased damage to them. I really wish the player character wouldn't spout cheap ice puns when freezing an enemy though.○ The grinder: insert 3 weapons, get a randomly generated, usually higher tier one. Basically another form of gambling, I got several legendaries from it.There are also new playable classes (which I think may be better than in BL2) and new enemy types, some of which are a real pain in the bottom. Some BL2 enemies make an appearance, but they're not re-used nearly as heavily as BL1 enemies were in BL2.Overall this is an ok game, it's worth playing but definitely not paying the full price for.

Posted: July 13, 2015
												I really do wish to recommend this game but the issue I'm having is whom I would recommend this game to. It is by no means a bad game! I actually do like it. But it suffers from one MASSIVE flaw...The Pre-Sequel is NOT anywhere as good as Borderlands 2.The two factors that made Blands 2 so awesome were it's entertaining story and it's characters which were (for the most part) entertaining to play. The Pre-Sequel does not deliver in both these areas. The story is only okay, and the playable characters are fairly under-whelming, even compared to the original Borderlands game. So I was tempted to recommend maybe playing this game BEFORE Blands 2, but even that leaves a sour taste in my mouth. The fact is, Blands 2 is cheaper. You can purchase it with it's major expansions for less than this game and it has TONS more content, all much more enjoyable.So who would I recommend this game to? The only players who come to mind would be the Borderlands fans (like me) but those gamers should have already played (and been disappointed by) this game. So who else is there? Maybe, just maybe, the very casual gamer who is taking thier sweet time getting to this game, but even them I'd recommend playing all the expansions for Borderlands 2 first, and then probably just starting yet another character in that game (or the original Borderlands) instead.And just FYI, I do own two copies of this game now. I originally purchased on console to play co-op with my son, and now have it on PC because it's the gaming system I prefer. And I will play even more of this game, but I just can't in good conscience recommend anyone else to do the same.So in conclussion, my feeling is if you haven't purchased this game already, then there's really no need to at this point. Either play Borderlands 2 (and it's expansions!) or just wait for Borderlands 3 instead.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
Borderlands The Pre-Sequel ReviewThis is an extremely difficult review to write, because I am very conflicted over this game. On the one side, it's a *fairly* solid FPS shooter with loot in abundance, some good humour and great co-op gaming. One that I am sure you will enjoy playing with a few friends. On the other hand, it feels like an expensive Borderlands 2 DLC and a blatant cash grab (they will be bringing out MORE DLC for this one too, if you are so inclined).ConsAll the little annoyances and bugs from number 2 got carried over, without so much as a look at getting them fixed or changed. I have already experienced sound randomly disappearing for no reason, only to come back after I die (a bug that plagued the previous game as well). I have also had an NPC glitch on the tutorial mission, making it impossible to finish without exiting the game and coming back in. Then there is the horrendous amount of back tracking through the same old levels - surely they could just add more fast travel locations to the game? How about some form of teleport device - since we seem to be able to constantly cheat death and respawn nearby anyway? The menus are still horrendous to navigate - a remnant of it being a console port, no doubt. Boring fetch-this and go-there quests seem as abundant as ever too, I really wish there was a bit more depth to the multitude of side-quests.The new low gravity / O2 mechanic is really just a gimmick and does nothing to improve the game. All it seems to do is make for bunny-hopping gun-fights. The classes are also not that interesting. Claptrap is a completely useless character in single or co-op, Wilhelm is basically Axton from the previous game and the last two characters are nothing special either. Borderlands games have always advertised themselves as a fusion of FPS and RPG, but I was kind of hoping a little more of the RPG side of things would be brought into the games as time went on. This is sadly not the case. Customisation is limited to poor skill trees and throw-away skins that do nothing but change the basic colours of your character. The bad♥♥♥♥♥system is a neat idea, but never really seems to do much for you and I can't help but wonder if more could have also been done here as well.The humour and general feel of Borderlands 2 is here - so it is really just more of the same. This is its biggest problem. It brings nothing new to the table and looks and feels like you are playing Borderlands 2. Most of the points I have mentioned so far could be forgiven in BL2, but 2 years later, to bring out this "expansion pack" and try palming it off as a separate game without addressing any of its predecessors issues is just a bit much. ProsMoving on to the positives: it's more Borderlands, which surely cannot be a bad thing in itself. It's still a great co-op game that gets better with more people playing. The graphics look as good as ever and it has Handsome Jack before he was Handsome Jack - who was always one of my favourite characters in the last game. The story seems acceptable but nothing ground-breaking. It is nice to see previous characters making a come-back to fill in some gaps.The game is still great fun to play co-op, where a full-team of vault hunters is much more enjoyable than wondering around alone. The guns and loot is as crazy and fun as ever. There is also a new laser-class weapon, which is a welcome addition. "Slag" seems to have been replaced with "Cryo" weapons, which is a welcome addition, since Slag weapons became more and more essential as you levelled up in number 2 - and limited your options.SummarySo, to summarise, it's an overpriced, underdeveloped slog through similar territory - a cash-grab by lazy developers. If you can see past this and enjoyed Borderlands 2 then that will be of no consequence and you can ignore most of the cons in this review. If you, like me, expected more, then you have come to the wrong place and should wait for Borderlands 3 instead. Still, this is Gearbox afterall - who gave us Duke Nukem Forever and Colonial Marines - I guess I shouldn't have expected too much from them. It's a fairly decent game that will keep diehard fans of the franchise happy, but you can't help but wonder what more could have been done.My Jimbo Rating on this game will differ based on two important factors, shown below.If you wanted more from the new Borderlands game than a lazy, copy-paste clone:Jimbo Rating: 5/10 - "Not Recommended" If you simply wanted more Borderlands 2 and are a diehard fan that has cash to throw at the lazy devs:Jimbo Rating: 7/10 - "Recommended"For me, this game falls in the first category, making it a 5/10.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												"A Sleeper hit from 2k Australia!"One of the most boring, contrived, lazy and agenda-ridden games I've ever played.I feel like I came away from playing this garbage with more questions than answers but I'll try to explain my reasoning to the best of my knowledge.This game is designed to fit in around after the ending of borderlands 1. While this has numerous plotholes already, 2k Australia decided that this couldn't JUST be on the exact same borderlands 2 engine - They needed to add the most aggrivating low gravity jump platforming and useless o2 meters. The Engine is already deliberately slow - for loot hunting and team gameplay. When paired with low gravity it just makes the game so difficult to navigate. All the enemies also jump around to avoid fire within low gravity, massive parts of the game are made up purely by platforming and they even added jumppads for extra jumping - You can tell, they were proud of this mechanic. This is something they looked at during development and thought "Hey, that is great!". The o2 meter is useless. I don't really need to say more as it doesn't impact the game whatsoever. The game makes it out as if it is something you should always worry about, however, I can't ever remember running out of oxygen whatsoever.The plot is very bare and riddled with holes, as borderlands 2 provides a pretty concise story of events, via echo-logs, character interaction and inferred dialouge, the pre-sequel decides to throw that out of the window and rushes to make an already standard, unseen plot into a cartoony farce. In an attempt to make a fan favourite villain into some sort of hero fallen from grace.The story is also very, VERY insistant on parroting every outdated and cringey internet meme it can muster and goes to great lengths to make almost every character gay. Well over 50% of the women you find will do nothing but loudly declare their disinterest in men, while noteable male characters in the franchise are suddenly very open about their homosexuality and press it on the player.It really does ruin the immersion of the game, as other games in the series didn't do this and it feels very forced. It also goes to extremes to insult, berate and laugh at certain gender groups. It is very apparent that the writing team is able to run rampant and include their personal internet agendas into this. I don't want your social issues. I just want to do quests and find loot with friends. The playable characters are boring, one dimensional smartasses with nothing noteworthy about them. They try to tie them into the game by making some of them the sub-bosses of borderlands 2, however this just feels stupid as you mostly dispose of them with ease in borderlands 2 without a passing thought.Somehow uglier than it's 3 year old predeccesor, with bland, boring enviroments to slowly run around in. Sometimes I got confused as to where I was just because every area looked the same. The moon's surface is exacly that, with reskinned enemies from borderlands 2 roaming the surface. Insides of buildings and areas are grotty, low res technology factories. Even the main city in the game is amazingly similar. The human enemies are all the same reskinned borderlands 2 enemies but with different names and australian accents. The weapons remain virtually unchanged, however they add in laser-weapons. I can count the number of genuinely unique enemies I encountered on one hand.In short, it feels lifeless. It honestly feels so devoid of content that you could show this to anybody and they would claim it is actually very bad DLC for borderlands 2. Even as a fan of the series, I would recomend to save your money. I Bought this for £3.75, and I still feel ripped off. How depressing.________________________________________________________________________________EDIT:I've had some people personally message me and claim that "the game gets better at max level!" Screw that, why can't the game be good from the beginning? Why do I have to slog through this hot mess JUST so I can "experience the full game?" people also berated my hours in-game.I've also had a person message me claiming this review is "sexist and homophobic" If you feel this way, kindly message me, I can block you so I do not have to know you exist.

number of helpful: 18 of 32 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												TL;DR: It's not quite Borderlands 2, but it's still a very good game.The writing's not quite as tight. There are some spots that seem to be written by someone that laughed at Anthony Burch's work in Borderlands 2, but didn't really get it, and tried to emulate that. A lot of the writing's solid. Some is downright hilarious. But some falls flat on its face, and that's sad. I haven't had any moments with the writing that really shook me. "Because that's what heroes do..." in BL2 shook me to the core. This game just about hits those levels. In fact, I think I didn't get the full value of Jack's arc until the second play through. Unfortunately, some of the quests actually devalue that arc quite a bit, and invalidate some of his most important choices from a ludonarrative perspective. These are fetch quest style problems, which can be a problem in any game, but Borderlands 2 managed to make those work well. In Pre-Sequel, they betray the urgency in fundamental ways that damage the narrative. The level design hits higher points, and lower points. Some of the level design is really quite fun. They way some of the fights are arranged, it's a beautiful chaos and keeps you moving. These moments are the absolute best thing Borderlands has done in this regard. However, those are contrasted by entire areas that are rife with♥♥♥♥♥♥design. The Hyperion base is a huge example of♥♥♥♥♥♥design. The game focuses heavily on the new elements, the air, the stomp, and the double jump. The Hyperion base is a very large segment of the late game play, and it makes all those things completely invalid. There's unlimited air, there's full gravity so double jumps don't work, and stomps are useless. By the time I finally get out of that section of the game, I forget about them, and have to essentially relearn those mechanics. That stinks. True Vault Hunter Mode is... really close to amazing. The problem with the replay modes in BL2 is, they tend to ruin what makes the gameplay fun for me. You can't play balls-out, chaotic. You can't shape the encounters with well-placed sniping at the beginning of a fight. Higher level bosses become pedantic exercises in equipment and skill allocation. I hate that. In Pre-Sequel, it's the same thing as the first play through, only more. It's fun, it's hectic. I don't feel overly stressed, just challenged. My sniping stuff works great. I can rush up to enemies and unload. It's very much "Borderlands". Bravo. However, they didn't balance all the game this well, and where they didn't, it suffers immensely. One of the first major bosses is almost impossible in True Vault Hunter Mode, unless you're highly specced out to fight him. You can't level grind to get past him, because he's so early on, you don't have any good grind areas available. There's no opportunities to go find the right loot to make it work, either. So if you get stuck there, you're basically ♥♥♥♥ed unless you finagle getting different equipment into that save file using creative multiplayer ♥♥♥♥ery. ♥♥♥♥ that. This goes doubly so when one of your character choices favors non-elemental weapons heavily, and that boss all but requires an elemental weapon to take down. Sad. Gender dynamics? A++. So good in that regard. Mr. Torgue's friend zone joke was brilliantly constructed. I love hearing the protagonists banter back and forth. I love hearing them react to each others' class skills. I love hearing their different interactions with the NPCs. I worry this is going to make adding new characters to the game that much harder. But who knows? Ice weapons are kind of cool I guess? I don't like them much, outside of shield effects. But then again, Nisha's by far my favorite character, and she heavily favors non-elemental weapons. Stomping is fun. It's a shame they remove the capacity for it in what's probably the single biggest segment of the game. Claptrap's kind of weird as a character. I don't think the benefits of his random effects are comparable to the reliable effects of the other characters, which is sad. Nisha is absurd. Once she gets levelled up quite a bit, she becomes ridiculous and over-the-top, in ways I've never seen Borderlands characters get. I like this a lot. Athena is a fun, solid character. She's got a good range of abilities, and her special supports playing without cover, which I'm a huge fan of. Wilhelm is similarly fun. I like that his support drones kind of take the best parts of playing Axton and Roland, but gives them more complex strategic value and diversity. It's a very solid game. In a lot of ways, it's not quite Borderlands 2. But in a lot of ways, it's better. ﻿

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Would I recommend this game? Absolutely, to anyone who likes Borderlands in the first place. Would I say it was overpriced at $60? Absolutely. But then, I'd say most any game is overpriced at $60. But it is about as good a deal as you'll find in a mainstream 'triple-A' game, and way better than all those 12-hour blockbusters that everyone seems to go crazy for.People say that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel (BTPS?) is just "more Borderlands." True. But that's not a bad thing. Innovation is all very well, but once the basic mechanics are in place, what I'm looking for is more content. BTPS uses the familiar Borderlands mechanics, and dishes up a great big helping of new content. I wish more successful games would do that. If already know I like the gameplay, then more levels, more missions, more game world is exactly what I want.It helps that the new content really is good. The characters are just as clever, and just as well-voiced as before. The maps and quests aren't wildly different, but they're well-designed and they take you to parts of the Pandora system that you definitely haven't seen before. As in previous Borderlands games, the plot is mainly an excuse to fight legions of AI enemies, while you level up your weapons and your skills. It's a perfect challenge-vs-reward formula, and BTPS doesn't mess it up. BTPS does add a few novelties: the need to watch your O2 levels in airless areas; the ability to jump way up in the air; the ability to stomp back down, dealing area damage. These add to the fun, and add a bit of freshness, but BTPS  would still be a good game without them.Is BTPS a good value? I'm up to almost 24 hours of game time, with no end in sight. I've got enough new missions in my list to hit around 35 hours, and I'm sure that there are more core missions I haven't encountered yet. Call it a minimum of 50 hours. (I don't distinguish between story missions and side-missions, by the way. It's all good.) I've found Borderlands games to be pretty replayable, too. Come back for some co-op, maybe. Or start a new type of character and see what's different. Add that in and the dollars-per-hour ratio starts to look amazing.Paying full price for BTPS is a personal decision. If you're a big fan, keen to jump in, you shouldn't be disappointed. Everyone else should definitely grab the game when it goes on sale. (As I type this, the game is on for about half price. Definitely worth that much.) Yeah, it's all pretty familiar stuff, but so what? I think of it like "Season 3" of a TV series that I'm really enjoying. I know the stars, I know the kind of stories to expect. Familar can be great. It's like coming home.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												It's a really fun game, especially for me because I am in love with the characters you get to play as. Nisha, Wilhelm, Claptrap, Aurelia, and Jack are all such solid classes. Athena is okay, but in my opinion she's the least interesting. Anyways, gameplay is a just what you would expect from a Borderlands game: shoot the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything and get tons of loot. Also, if you love the lore of Borderlands than this is a great game for youAs a die hard Borderlands fan, this game hyped me up to extremes. I bought two copies and I honestly was a LITTLE let down. Just a little bit. I'll make a scrambled up list for my own pros and cons for anybody who shares my thoughts. I've bought all of the dlcs so I can try and review them too.BASE GAME:pros- Solid story, it adds a lot to the world they've created.- Motha. Fuggin. BUTTSLAM? Fun as hell dudes.- The Oz kits and air system is a cool add, easy to control like it doesn't exist, but I can appreciate it anyways.-No gravity, you spend the whole time on the moon. When I go back to playing Borderlands 2, I immediately miss flying through the air.- The game is well-optimized. I remember it being pretty buggy here and there at launch but they resolved it quickly.- You get to learn more about Jack, since he's your boss. Same with Nisha, Wilhelm, Claptrap (especially in his dlc) and it introduces new characters like Timothy Lawrence (Jack's body double) And Aurelia Hammerlock, the sister of Alister Hammerlock. It also reintroduces old characters from previous games, such as Nakayama. Jack's #1 fanboy.- Funny and super amusing dialogue from the characters you play as! I'm so happy they have playable characters that can now talk, and NPCs all react differently for each character thanks to their personalities.- If you're a gun nut.... yeah. This game.- Jack's body double. Best. Character. EVER. (Same with Aurelia)Cons- The game raises more questions than answers. I'm guessing they are gonna do a lot in Borderlands 3 though, this definitely hypes for the third.- A lot of the bosses are forgettable. They all seem to have very weak qualities that sets them apart from another. Borderlands 2 had amazing unique qualities to their bosses. - I think this game tries a little too hard to be Borderlands 2, it tries to be wacky, and zany... but the execution left a lot to be desired. -There aren't many character depths, usually when you meet an NPC that's all you get. Borderlands 2 had a lot of awesome npcs and characters that everyone fell in love with, you just don't get that in this game as much. -The only memorable characters this game introduced would be Janey, Pickles, Felicity. That's about all I can remember off the top of my head.- I compare this game a lot to Borderlands 2, which probably isn't fair, but compared to the second game, this game's quests are lackluster. - Wilhelm's class is kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, if you're looking to play someone like Axton. His trees leave a lot to be desired. He was my main for a while and he is WEAK as hell. I quickly switched to Jack' though and don't regret it.CLAPTASTIC VOYAGE:[/b]pros- It breathes SO much life into the game.- It's fun, mesmerizing for a dlc based around CLAPTRAP.- Brightly colored digital world, you get to see a lot of cool stuff happening and it's just hilarious.- The whole DLC requires you to travel inside of Claptrap. It sounds 'wtf' at first but the moment you dive right in, you are guaranteed to have tons of fun. - It's comparable to Tiny Tina's dlc for the second game. It definitely isn't at that godly on a level, but this game needed a good dcl and Claptastic is just that.- That end cinematic though. It made me love Claptrap. This game will probably turn everybody to loving that stupid robot.- Great dialogue, awesome soundtrack.- YOU GET TO REVISIT ZONES FROM THE FIRST AND SECOND GAMES!- This DLC also answers a lot of questions instead of raising them. IT'S WORTH THE MONEY, TRUST ME.cons-Last boss fight is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and I know it's gonna be hard when I do it on UTHM. pray for meThe Holodome Onslaught:[/b]No.Don't buy it. It's awful. The only semi-decent things to come out of this stupid dlc are the skins I guess. Basically you just fight in a big dome, that's it. There is literally nothing to it. It's not the fun kinda fighting, either. The area is TOO big and you have to kill everybody to go to the next level. It's long, tedious, and the rewards aren't worth it. You get some audio logs from Axton and Gaige but that's all that it brings to the table. Awful DLC. Just look up all the audio logs and you'll be up to date on what's going on with them.
