Posted: March 5, 2015
												Would I recommend this game? Absolutely, to anyone who likes Borderlands in the first place. Would I say it was overpriced at $60? Absolutely. But then, I'd say most any game is overpriced at $60. But it is about as good a deal as you'll find in a mainstream 'triple-A' game, and way better than all those 12-hour blockbusters that everyone seems to go crazy for.People say that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel (BTPS?) is just "more Borderlands." True. But that's not a bad thing. Innovation is all very well, but once the basic mechanics are in place, what I'm looking for is more content. BTPS uses the familiar Borderlands mechanics, and dishes up a great big helping of new content. I wish more successful games would do that. If already know I like the gameplay, then more levels, more missions, more game world is exactly what I want.It helps that the new content really is good. The characters are just as clever, and just as well-voiced as before. The maps and quests aren't wildly different, but they're well-designed and they take you to parts of the Pandora system that you definitely haven't seen before. As in previous Borderlands games, the plot is mainly an excuse to fight legions of AI enemies, while you level up your weapons and your skills. It's a perfect challenge-vs-reward formula, and BTPS doesn't mess it up. BTPS does add a few novelties: the need to watch your O2 levels in airless areas; the ability to jump way up in the air; the ability to stomp back down, dealing area damage. These add to the fun, and add a bit of freshness, but BTPS  would still be a good game without them.Is BTPS a good value? I'm up to almost 24 hours of game time, with no end in sight. I've got enough new missions in my list to hit around 35 hours, and I'm sure that there are more core missions I haven't encountered yet. Call it a minimum of 50 hours. (I don't distinguish between story missions and side-missions, by the way. It's all good.) I've found Borderlands games to be pretty replayable, too. Come back for some co-op, maybe. Or start a new type of character and see what's different. Add that in and the dollars-per-hour ratio starts to look amazing.Paying full price for BTPS is a personal decision. If you're a big fan, keen to jump in, you shouldn't be disappointed. Everyone else should definitely grab the game when it goes on sale. (As I type this, the game is on for about half price. Definitely worth that much.) Yeah, it's all pretty familiar stuff, but so what? I think of it like "Season 3" of a TV series that I'm really enjoying. I know the stars, I know the kind of stories to expect. Familar can be great. It's like coming home.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												is this a lot like bl2?yesis that a bad thing?not reallyi found bl2 to be a pretty enjoyable game, and the presequel gave me the same impression. it's fun, and a lot like bl2 to the point i don't blame a lot of people for seeing this as more of an overpriced dlc. really the only reason i ended up getting it so soon after it released (at least soon when it comes to me who gets games at least a year after they come out) was because i got it for christmas. i opened the gift like 'oh♥♥♥♥♥♥i forgot this was on my amazon wishlist might as well play it'.so i did, along with a little bit of research on the way. while i was waiting for it to install, i told my friends i got it and they were like '2k didn't even wanna make this so don't think of 2k as a bad company because of it' even though i forgot 2k was even a company. another borderlands game wasn't supposed to come out until 2016, and hearing that i immediately assumed that the game was gonna feel pretty rushed. while it does, i didn't feel like it messed up the experience too much for me. i like to call this game a very safe release. they wanted to profit off of the ip they already had without screwing it up, so they just recycled the formula from bl2 if i had to guess. if that's not it, i guess it could be used to tide people over for bl3? whatever, either way what i'm trying to say is i feel like the reason why it's basically just like bl2 is because they wanted to make it just like bl2. there are differences, but these differences are pretty minor. these differences are all things everyone knows about: butt slams, cryo, and lazers. lazers would be more satisfying to use if they were more prone to having high fire rates, but unfortunately the vast majority of them seem to have fire rates between 1-3 with the exception of moxxi's vibrapulse. (which i'm really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥about them nerfing. it might just be me but i really don't see the point in nerfing anything that makes the game easier to play if the only competitive option you really have is duelling over loot with your friends.)this is in vast contrast to butt slams and cryo damage which is pretty universally satisfying. (of course, cryo only goes for if you have a high chance of freezing people but that should be a given for any elemental damage.) i especially find it fun to butt slam someone and watch the rag doll physics kick in as they fly off into the void nothingness of space. it's also fun to freeze someone before slamming your♥♥♥♥♥on them so they break into pieces. what's hilarious is slamming into a huge group of enemies telling them to shut the ♥♥♥♥ up and they freeze to death. they're little additions that make the game a bit more fun in some parts, but still overall not much of a difference from bl2.there are a few more things aside from the slow fire rate on lasers that make the combat system a little less satisfying though i gotta say. flying enemies are annoying. rakks were annoying in the last game, and now you have to deal with the bootleg rakks and ♥♥♥♥ing bandits with jetpacks. 'who's shooting at me i can't find them oh it's because they're floating great'. while the immediate instinct is to kill them while they're in the air, again, it's pretty annoying because whatever loot they might drop you have no choice to miss out on because it falls into the many voids of this space place. there are a lot of drops you end up missing, actually. it's usually not weapons, but more likely money or ammo that just floats away after you open any box. but this is zero-gs so i guess that's how things behave in that atmosphere? hell if i knowloot also feels a lot less...invigorating? that word sounds weird to use, let's just say exciting. loot chests feel less exciting to open. odds are what they have is♥♥♥♥♥♥and you can just buy something better in a vending machine. it feels pretty insulting that i'm supposed to be kind of adventuring through the moon looking for these loot chests that have these awesome legendary weapons when i'm only a level 5 and whaddya know there's an orange weapon for sale right here. (adding insult to injury you obviously can't afford these things at these levels like what the ♥♥♥♥)okay last but not least i guess i'll talk about the plot(?). i'm not saying that fps games always have to have this extraordinary plot that'll break my heart, but what a disappointment. i'm not spoiling anything don't worry, kiddos. just saying that the ending was super abrupt. the game felt a lot shorter than bl2. i'm guessing it wasn't but it just felt like it was. it probably just does because in bl2 i was in a 3-player campaign while in pre-sequel i was by myself. i dunno. it was also pretty annoying to hear so many australian accents. i don't have a beef with australians, it just feels pretty stupid to be like 'remember us? we're 2k australia we're the ones that made this game this is our thing we did it with crayons and elmers glue aren't we cool?'.at the end of the day, i'm just gonna say what everyone else is gonna say.don't buy itnot nownot at full pricewait for it to go on sale for like 30 bucks then by all means but until then keep playing the dlc in bl2 unless you're super impatient and you feel like you absolutely have to buy it asap then fine waste your allowance don't say i didn't warn you

content:
Posted: April 26
A Decent Expansion To Pandora's Colorful WorldBorderlands: The Pre-Sequel was a highly anticipated game, especially after the massive success of its gargantuan predecessor. Without DLC's, you play one of four in the band of misfits—most of whom show up as antagonists in Borderlands 2. Each person has their own motive for working as a group; some want to be heroes while others just live for the thrill of it. There's better mobility, new weapon types, money is actually useful to get loot, women who love women, Claptrap, and your excessive collection of guns can actually be used in a vending machine called "The Grinder" to rely on RNG to make a better gun. There are some intuitive changes and upgrades to the game. Skill trees have changed, giving you new abilities such as double jump and the skill to be like Kirby and do a butt slam in order to make a quick descent. Everything I loved about Borderlands 2 mechanics were built into the game—from higher tier modes with great loot drops to fun easter eggs.However, there was a lot wrong too. The writing suffered with the different team, opting for censoring profanity that broke immersion from the coarse world of Borderlands. Some jokes were more cringe-y than funny. The progression is significantly slower because it was padded with boring fetch quests. The new terrain was beautiful but seriously lacking in save points; someone else said it's like the game wanted us to die and restart from the beginning. They hit the nail on the head. Raid bosses were one of the highlights of Borderlands 2—and there was only 1 in TPS that was on a predictable respawn timer. As with any Borderlands game, I also strongly recommend playing this with friends. Otherwise, it will get boring really fast.So did it live up to the hype? Yes and no. It answered a lot of questions but it also left a lot of questions unanswered. If anything, the game is more worthy as an expansion to Borderlands 2 than a standalone game. I'm recommending it if you love Borderlands 2 lore and have a really strong desire for more Borderlands content. I also recommend playing this first if you want to appreciate Tales From the Borderlands more; many characters show up from this game and Borderlands 2.7/10

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												Borderlands is a great game.  Borderlands 2 is a great game.  Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, isn't a great game and that's the problem. Overall Borderlands The Pre-Sequel returns to the hole too many times.  I don't know if it's a lack of skill, a lack of design, or a lack of writing, but the Pre-sequel just isn't that memorable a game. I played through the entire game on PS3, and booted it up again on PC about 6 months later, and to be honest.  What I remember of the game isn't a good thing.  There's innovation here, but it's not good.  The idea of Oxygen is a novel concept but it seems to be thrown out just to change up the pace of the game, not because it's a good feature.  The New classes are weak, and there's really two types of players.  The guys who like Claptrap and play his class (which is interesting though gets annoying) and the people who don't which use the other three classes (plus DLC).  The thing is, the classes in Borderlands 2 were evolutions of the the classes in Borderlands, and that's a safe bet.  I'm sure it's been criticized for not innovating enough, but the thing is, I didn't like any of the classes in this game.  I wasn't drawn to them, except claptrap and even then his skill is a bit too random. The story though is what I feel like is the biggest problem, now Anthony Burch has been funny, but I've found that while I still enjoy the original Hey Ash Series, and Borderlands 2, I haven't really liked anything he's done after Borderlands 2.  I don't know what changed, and it'd be easy to say "he ham fisted social commentary into the game."  and yes he did that quite often.   However, social commentary can be done well, the problem is even when the social commentary isn't being pushed in your face (which does happen).   The script of The Pre-Sequel isn't that interesting.The game revolves around one of the best characters in the series, Handsome Jack.  It even has a doppleganger of Jack as a playable character DLC.  The problem is Jack is never the same as the previous games.  Everyone remembers Butt Stallion, that line sealed Jack's personality as awesomeness. Jack's never there, I don't remember a really good scene or line from Handsome Jack in the Pre-Sequel, and he's there to carry the ENTIRE game.  In the other games, you're going up against him, now you spend more time with him and he's less.  It's not an over abundance of great lines that ruins it, it's that there's not really a great line, that ever makes you like the character as much as you did in the previous games.Of course there's a number of other characters that have completely changed and that's a problem too, the social commentary is placed on a number of popular characters like Torque, and such, but this is a prequel, so the over the top characters, have a conscious in this game, but no explanation why they changed from the touchy feely version of the characters, to the insane characters later in the series. However this isn't a problem of "the writing is bad", because the game itself just.  It's a shadow of the previous two games, and never rises to the heights of the previous game.  Most of the quests are dull, the flow of the game is disjointed, and the final battle is... insanely hard, especially if you try to solo it.Now, if you absolutely loved Borderlands and Borderlands 2, then yes, you should grab the pre-sequel, but personally I would have prefered a second run through of Borderlands 2, rather than playing this.  However I did buy it on the PC, as part of a humble bundle, so I could get the DLC and finally play that.  Though as I do that, I'm reminded that the main game, just doesn't stand up to the other two entries in the series.

Posted: January 30, 2015
												First off, I'm not very good at making reviews and this is the second time I make a review of this game cause I've learned alot since last time, and Im sorry for any spelling errors I make, if there are any big ones and you are a crazy grammar nazi just point them out to me and I'll fix it.The way the game is played compared to Borderlands 2 is quite different but while still keeping that Borderlands feel to it, the new feature of Oz kits and cryo elements make it a bit unique. But gameplay wise, being on the moon and using those Oz kits make it so you can  fly further, jump higher and do butt slams on enemies, it is a big new feature and I like it's in there.Now I have completed the first playthrough with every character (except the newest one) and gotten the Lawbringer to 60 an wilhelm to 50, but I still don't get that kind feel like I did in Borderlands 2 each time I finished a playthrough, don't feel like I've really done anything productive and I don't really know what to do next. That brings me to the dialogue, honestly the dialogue can get quite repetitive and annoying cause you can't skip it and some are pretty long (1 to mention is the side mission where you help nurse Nina find a lover and each time you found 1 you had to wait through the dialogue then pick up the stupid flowers afterwards, many times I started making my way to the next point then realized I forgot the flowers.)Now the DLC, so far the DLC has honestly.... been quite crap, 2 playable characters and 1 level upgrade with a slaughter dome thing. and the season pass promised 4 DLC, 3 have already come out, and on the page is says "all DLC will be released before October 2015, It's just February and they already released almost all of the ones they promised from their season pass. I really hope the last one is an actual playable DLC with a story (and I have heard it's going to involve something about Claptrap)The 4 new playable characters in the game, Wilhelm, Nisha, Claptrap and Athena all have these brand new kind of abilities that are all cool and unique in their own way and also how all the skill trees can effect all kinds of things, like with wilhems you can slowly make him into more of a robot the more you level up, with Nisha in the bottom of the middle tree you can dual wield any pistols you hold in your hands, with Athena there's not much there but you can make your shield do all sorts of cool stuff, and then Claptrap is kind of that main co op character, there is kind of an entire tree just for co op and at the bottom of 1 of them there is a skill where you can high five a player and get some extra stats for some time. Also with the DLC characters making them 6  now with Handsome Jack and Aurelia it makes it so you can play the story way more times and get all these cool new things. (but honestly I'm not a big fan of Aurelia's skill, I just find it kinda meh tbh)The story in this game is pretty interesting, it shows how Handsome jack got to power and how he became a crazy psychopath,  and I do think this game does actually have alot to do with Borderlands 3  That is the guardians of the vault, as you saw in the end scene of the game where the alien looking creature said they would need all the vault haunters they could get cause some mass force is coming, or something like that Though it may seem like I'm kinda just crapping on the game, I do actually really like the game and I'm a bit of a sucker for Borderlands and these kinds of farming games. I probably will keep playing this game, but probably not as much as I played Borderlands 2 cause I just reeeally loved Borderlands 2 and could play that for hours without getting tired of it.Overall, if you are a big fan of the Borderlands series, I would recommend it but be advised the dialogue in like the first 2-3 playthroughs are cool but after that gets kinda annoying. Also if you are looking for a good game to just chill with your friends I definitely recommend this game because this game seems to kinda involve a lot of cool co-op experience at to be honest kinda feels like this game was just made for co-op, though the story is educational for the hard core borderlands fans.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												I heard from a lot of people that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel isn't as good as the first or second Borderlands games, but honestly I'm finding that's not true at all. This game is just as good as the previous two. The class are fun, the story is engaging, and the weapons are just as great. It works nearly identically to Borderlands 2 as far as gameplay goes, with the exception of the additional oxygen feature.I thought at first that the oxygen feature would be tedious, but it's honestly not that big of an issue. There's no micromanaging involved, and oxygen areas are easy to come by. The butt bounce it provides is tons of fun, especially with an elemental Oz kit, and the option of much-quicker resurrection of teammates using your oxygen supply is invaluable in a team setting.There were only a few things I found wrong with the game. The soundtrack isn't nearly as good as the previous titles' soundtracks. Though I haven't yet finished the game, there doesn't seem to be as wide as range of areas to explore, especially compared to Borderlands 2 and its DLCs, but the story is interesting enough to make up for that for me. It's interesting to see the character development that Jack goes through on his descent toward Handsome Jack. The addition of Cryo-- or ice elemental-- weapons is fantastic as well, especially when pared with the DLC Aurelia Hammerlock class, which has a whole skill trees devoted to Cryo damage.Overall, if you loved the previous Borderlands games, this one is a great addition to your collection. Don't pass it up, especially if you can snag it during a sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												A recommendation, but not the strongest one.The characters are much better designed and balanced, boss battles are more interesting, the new weapon type and element are fantastic, the memes are reduced, vending machines are worth looking at, the eridium analogue is easier to obtain, and UVHM is much better balanced. The writing is about on quality with BL2, for better or worse, and the new characters are divisive at best. Unique NPC dialog based on your character is also long overdue. The Claptrap DLC is also some of the best gameplay in the series. This game's "pink" weapons are more easily obtained than BL2's Seraph weapons, and much more interesting. For the players who refuse to Gib, the Grinder provides a fantastic option for turning their terrible legendary drops into something more interesting without farming.On the subject of DLC, the game is free from the cosmetic skin nickel and diming that BL2 suffered from, and the Season Pass is much less confusing in terms of what you get. The only DLC that it doesn't contain is the Shock Drop Slaughter Pit (for some reason), a location that provides standard slaughter arena fare. There's a lack of expansion compared to the four major DLCs of BL2, though the Claptastic Voyage is easily better than all but three, and a strong contender for best DLC of the series.The biggest strikes against the game is the level design and Fast Travel location. There are many places that are too large, or send you back and forth without any quick travel options. There are several locations in dire need of Fast Travel (Veins of Helios and Subsubconscious stand out). The oxygen system isn't bad, though it does lead to some floaty combat that can be annoying. For the completionists, several of the badass challenges are completely awful and give you only a single chance per playthrough to complete. On a nitpicky note, the game really needs to stop censoring its non-robotic swearing.TPS is a good game, one I've happily invested over 100 hours in. I wouldn't call the game better than BL2, though the two certainly belong in the same room. The game is very much worth picking up and playing, though the recommendation only becomes particularly strong when the game is on Steam sale. Just be sure to grab the Season Pass, for the aforementioned Claptastic DLC and two solid characters.

Posted: March 27, 2016
												When I first saw this game, I wasn't sure if it would be good. It looked like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ copy of Borderlands 2, just with lazers and less gravity. And, luckily, I WAS WRONG.STORY (no spoilers)In this game you discover what happened before Borderlands 2, but after Borderlands 1. The reason I put the sentence that way is because it is way more connected to Borderlands 2. You discover how Handsome Jack turned from a low-level guy to a leader. You will see some familiar faces while you do it.GAMEPLAYJust like with previous games, this is a Role-Playing Shooter. So, you can choose which character you want, which skills your character will have, and which swella items will your character use.GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCE]This game, just like BL2 and BL1 uses cel-shading. It's a specifc graphic style that makes everything look cartoon-ish. Not in a bad way, though. It performs really well, even on my old♥♥♥♥♥2007 PC (and my gtx 960 pc)CONCLUSIONAny Borderlands fan needs to get this game. If you haven't played Borderlands before, I recommend you play BL1 and BL2 first. If not, then just BL2.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a sort-of sequel, sort-of pre-sequel follow-up to Borderlands 2. It is made by a different studio, the Australian studio for the development team, and it definitely shows. A lot of people dislike this game, and I'll be honest, I did too at first. I wasn't 100% sure about the accents, but they grew on me and I enjoyed them a lot. The main issue I had was the movement in the overworld before getting the upgraded vehicle. It's a little tedious, and I found myself often falling off of things and having to re-do journeys, which I found slightly annoying. However, that is a problem only for a few hours, and once gotten past, the game was very enjoyable. The story was solid, the characters hilarious and diverse and brought some incredibly interesting backstory to a lot of the characters we knew from Borderlands and Borderlands 2. Plus, the Claptrap DLC is incredibly fun and well made, as is generally all of the story-driven Borderlands DLC.A definite recommendation from me. Nilesy

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												What a disappointment! The game was short, the levels dull, the missions boring, the fights easy,  the cinematics virtually nonexistent and the characters annoying as f*ck.  It's like a really bad long DLC.  Definitely not worth $60!How Gearbox allowed this to be released is beyond me. Oh wait, no it's not; cash grab!In their defense, I've only played through the game once.  It's possible I might find it slightly more enjoyable the second and third time around but I doubt it especially since the game appears to be severely unbalanced;  I reached chapter 12 without dying once, then the game become so difficult I was forced to do side missions or play online. I beat the game at level 27 I believe, meanwhile my main weapon of choice was a level 16 laser gun (the one Moxxie gives us) even though I had a level 22 legendary.. WTF?!All along, while playing, I kept thinking "ah, things will pick up, the next mission will be more exciting" and then I saw the end credits and my heart sank! I seriously thought it was a bug in the game, I could not believe it ended just like that.  THAT was the final boss fight?! LOL!If you're new to Borderlands I highly recommend starting with BL2.  Once you're done that, get ALL the DLC (they're all good, some are amazing) then BL1.  Stay away from this, only get it when you're bored with everything else and need a fix, but even then I would only pick this up if under $20.I'm sorry but the best part of this game was the intro video which can be seen on youtube at 1080p anyway.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Borderlands TPS (The Pre Sequel) isn't a bad game, but it fails at making a compelling value proposition, being unable to justify it's expensive $60 price tag.In my review below, I spend most of my time complaining, and I've given this title a thumbs-down/Not Recommended. That being said, it's still a fun game, and I like the borderland series. It's just an issue of price. This isn't a $60 game, it's a $30 or $40 game. And, until the price comes down, I don't recommend my friends buying this title unless they have plenty of disposable income.TPS is based off of the BL2 code and asset base. The graphics and menu systems are just like BL2. I consider this a positive, as the BL2 engine and game was solid. Not broke, don't fix. Gearbox/2K should have been able to take all of the experience and improvements made to BL2 over that time and apply it directly to TPS. The result should have been an extremely solid game with good graphics and technical capabilities.Unfortunately, it was a different studio (2K AU) who produced this game, and thus much of that learned wisdom was lost.On launch day, BL2 was a solid game with very few issues. The QA process was great and the result was a solid launch day game.Unfortunately, TPS QA was noticably weaker. On day-1, TPS was crashing, corrupting player saves, and there were tons of game-breaking bugs.Even two months after launch, TPS is still crashing, corrupting saves, and some serious bugs have not been addressed. Players (including myself) are running into story progression bugs that break the game. Some issues have been fixed, but many remain, and the scope of problems is so significant that I don't think they will ever be fixed.I've had my own game crash more than I can count (at least 30), while BL2 may have crashed twice in the entire 1000 hours I put into it. Progression bugs, enimies get stuck behind wall/floors/ceilings, player arms get stuck in weird positions, walking near stingrays causes wildly violent clipping, and I fearfully back up my game saves after the number of threads I've read about people having their files corrupted.TPS should have been *better* than BL2 on launch day, not worse.When it comes to level design, there's some good and some bad. The entire Helios station levels are excellent, especially the launching area, which is gloriously loud with it's constant laser fire and cannon launches. Tycho's Ribs and beyond is truely our first real vault with an actual vault, and it is as strange and alien as it should be. On the other hand, the first 2/3rds of the game has a number of issues, including level 3 players being able to find a level 30 Iwajira, a rediculously difficult Deadlift as a level 5 boss and his homing shock orbs of death and desire to ride the same two jump pads back and forth repeatedly, the unjumpable chasms of death, and more.The moon itself is somewhat barren and open, leaving some players to critisize this fact, but I don't see how that's avoidable. These levels look visually stunning and the backgrounds are beatiful, but I agree that something does feel empty about them. I attribute this to the rather non-compelling storytelling and missions during this early period of the game. For those of us who pre-ordered and were supposed to have been blessed with that awesome Abandoned Training Facility, you might be wondering just where it is? Yea, they hid it in some place half way through the game where you probably won't find it except by accident, and it mostly sucks so don't bother. It's nowhere near as good as Fink's Slaughterhouse or the Ore Chasm was. Oh, and there are no other arena areas like Fink's Slaughterhouse or the Ore Chasm in TPS at all.The most significant level design problem, however, is the lack of it. TPS is much shorter than either BL or BL2, and this is ultimately what turned me to give this title a thumbs down. We, the TPS players, paid a lot of money for a lot less game. There are fewer areas, and those areas are generally smaller or more barren. It seems like there are fewer enemies, fewer types of enemies, and overall less content. Remember that most of what makes up TPS came from BL2; they had tons of content like items and props to start with, and yet they didn't add that much to it.By the time I got to what felt like was half way through the game, I was actually near the end.The lack of levels and areas in TPS also leads to another significant problem, which is that the difficulty ramp is too steep, and in several areas players are likely to run into a progress wall where they are suddently fighting enemies which are dramatically more difficult. In all three of the Borderlands games, the first playthrough goes from level 1 to 30, and then the second playthrough from level 30 to 50. This gives you 30 levels to play through on the first go-around, and then only 20 on the second. But since there is less content and areas in TPS, the ramp-up for new enemies in new areas is less gradual. The result is that after you finish the Lunar Launching Station in playthrough 2 with enemies around level 42-43 (and lots of cover), you go to Vorago Solitude and immediately have to deal with level 46-47 enemies (with very little cover). The result is that you die a whole lot, and it's very frustrating.The four new playable characters each offer new gameplay style opportunities which I enjoy. Each has a different set of skills and when combined with different equipment lends to different enjoyable play styles.Nisha, Wilhelm, Athena, and Claptrap are all fun to play and have some great skills which lead to interesting and fun play style. They did a pretty good job here of learning from the previous vault hunter skills and then giving us new skills.Speaking of the new playable characters, the dialogue Improvements made in TPS are awesome. No longer do you have nothing to say for the entire game. Each player has their own dialogue responces to different parts of the story, and to each of the other player characters playing with you. This makes a huge difference in the game, as playing each character actually tells a different story in regards to how they view the world around them. Now you don't just have to play each character for the enjoyment of learning their play/skill style, but because it tells a new story; their story.Laser weapons are awesome, ice weapons are awesome, the grinder is awesome, and low grav/slamming is awesome. Without these four features, TPS would just have been a really expensive BL2 DLC.A number of people have asked me if the lack of oxygen on the moon is a problem Fortunately, it's not. There are plenty of sources to get air, and you are probably never going to die due to lack of O2. I am very positive on how they implemented O2 usage in TPS.In summary: +They fixed the story +Dialogue Improvements +More legendaries in vending machines +The Grinder +Cryo/Ice elemental weapons +Laser weapons +O2 and butt slamming +It's basically BL2  -High price, not worth $60 -They f**ked up the story -Falcon Punch -Shorter game with less content -Huge difficulty ramp-ups -Fewer enemies -First half of game feels slow/boring -GAME SAVE FILE CORRUPTION -Lots of crashes -Lots of game-breaking critical bugs -Lots of other non- critical bugs -Unnecessary cameos of Tourge and Tiny Tina to prop up a boring plot -Gamergate references -More internet memes -Unable to farm bosses and special enemies -Removal of True Vault Hunter Mode and reduction in level cap from 72/61 to 50 -Removal of loot midgets -Deadlift's homing shock orbs are OP

number of helpful: 137 of 264 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Borderlands: 2 with Low Gravity, Glitches, Recycled Material and Boredom.Re-writing now that I've played more. First off, I'm a big Borderlands fan. It took me a half hour to get used to the look in the first game, and I've loved it ever since. Pre-Sequel is a ripoff as a full-price game; it should have been an expansion. Not only because of how short it is, but because of the absolute laziness put into its design. The lack of polish is immediately obvious, and laziness quickly becomes evident when you realize a lot of objects are just retextured bits from B2. I've even heard recycled sounds, as well, not to mention reused dialogue for the vending machines and such.The next thing that quickly becomes obvious is that the OZ mechanic is a complete gimmick; generally all it serves to do is pull you away from whatever tedious quest you're working on so you can rush off an find a few canisters, then trek back and complete whatever you were doing. Sometimes it's cool to shoot an oxygen helmet off of a bad guy and watch it damage his health, but generally it's much faster to just shoot them again instead of waiting for them to die. Low gravity had excellent potential, but the implementation is lacking. There's very little that makes actual use of it; most of the time it just ends up being a way of skipping over parts of a map, except when there's a half-a$$ed platforming section thrown in for no reason. But the biggest problem with the low gravity is that when you kill an enemy carrying a mission-critical object, YOU HAVE NO IDEA WHERE IT WILL GO. I had to restart just a few minutes into a mission because the stuff an enemy was carrying shot into the side of a mountain out of reach. That is dumb. Balance is definitely not as good as B2. Sometimes you'll find yourself painfully outgunned, to the point of frustration (especially in early stages). I don't know how much of my money was wasted on respawns that should not have happened; many of the enemies are far, FAR more powerful than they should be. On the other hand, sometimes you'll find a rifle that can kill a scav in one or two non-critical hits.Pickles makes me want to stab my ears out. And it's particularly jarring to hear a Cockney Brit amongst all the Australians... seriously, why is everyone on Elpis Australian? There are PLENTY of non-Aussie voice actors in Australia! DON'T BE LAZY!!!I'm not homophobic. I believe in freedom. I think homosexuals should be free to marry who they want. But are there ANY non-gay couples in this game??? Seems like every other person has a same-sex partner. Maybe it's something in the OZ...Level design is alright but not very imaginative, and most areas feel tight and constricted, which makes the overpowered enemies even tougher. More problematic is that some of the levels are PAINFULLY long and not very well designed for future side missions, I.E. you'll have to run for an hour killing low-level enemies to make to an objective. It's frustrating and boring.Hitbox glitches are probably the most annoying problem of the game so far. I've run into many instances where I'll fire a full mag at someone without hitting them, at point blank range... then move a couple of feet to the side and start hitting them. It sucks. Driving is awful, but that's to be expected (one of the weak points of all the games). The worst part is that a lot of jumps are not actually possible unless you hit absolutely PERFECTLY, which is frustrating when you're just trying to relax and enjoy yourself. WHY DO I NOT AUTOMATICALLY PICK UP ALL AMMO AND MONEY AND WHY DO I HAVE TO MANUALLY PICK UP MOONSTONES?? Also, be careful opening chests... you might do what I did, not pay attention and spend 40 moonstone to open a chest full of WORTHLESS "loot" when I could have spent it on storage upgrades.These are not all my complaints. But I'm bored of writing about it; that's how dull this game is. Final word: Don't both playing this padded, dragging, dull, boring, buggy excuse for Borderlands.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
Note: Since this game is a sequel, and in many aspects very similar, to Borderlands 2, I will assume familiarity with this and only talk about differences.Many of the reviews, as well as most forum threads, complain about The Pre-Sequel (TPS from now on) being merely a huge DLC to BL2. While this is technically correct - the engine is the same, and the gameplay is not changed so much that it could not have been done in an expansion pack back in the day - I will explain why I still think TPS is an improvement over the (already amazing) BL2 and definitely worth getting.GameplayThe gameplay formula of BL2 remains the same - shoot, slaughter enemies in amazingly creative ways, loot. However, there is one notable new feature: Oz kits and low gravity allow you to jump huge distance, slam down on enemies and even float in the air for short durations - and of course, enemies can do the same. While this may not sound like much on paper, it is a huuge improvement for the game. It really mixes up the gameplay, and to me it feels as if this is really what Borderlands needed all along.Laser Guns dont have all that much of an impact, but it's still a nice addition. Slag is gone and replaced by the (even more powerful) cryo, that still amplifies damage but also freezes enemies.In short: If you enjoyed BL2's gameplay, you'll enjoy TPS as well only more so because buttslam.BalanceEveryone who played BL2 will remember its shortcomings: Exponential scaling that, at higher levels, made every weapon with even 1 level too less and every direct-damage skill useless. Thankfully, this is changed in TPS; although scaling is still exponential, and direct-damage skills still fall off somewhat towards high-level, the effect is much less noticeable and builds based on damage skills are totally viable even in the endgame. As a consequence, the game is much more enjoyable, although the masochists among you might find it too easy at times.Class balance is also vastly improved - all classes can be OP in some way, all classes have unique, interesting skills and multiple ways to play. I consider even the (imo) least interesting class in TPS more interesting than my favorite in BL2.StoryThe story is, as is expected from a Borderlands game, obviously no high literature. But it is well-written and interesting (imo more so than the story in BL2), and the new information gained about Handsome jack's rise to power brings interesting new points of view to the established lore.As usual, there are lots of jokes, which you might find funny or not, but does this surprise you? It's Borderlands.Some people complain about "social agenda" forced into the game. I do not feel that this is a valid complaint, but if you are worried, head to the forums and see for yourself.amount of contentMany complaints are about how this game is much much shorter than BL2. I do not think this is a valid complaint. Yes, the game is a little shorter (as was actually announced before release), but it's nowhere as bad as people make it out to be. Keep in mind that BL2 has 4 big story DLCs and the Headhunter packs - discounting those, the story is not that much bigger.SummaryIn short, TPS is basically more of the same, but better. If you didnt enjoy BL2, you most likely won't enjoy TPS either, the differences are not enough for that. But if you did, get this game. It's worth it.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												So... my review for this game, at the time of writing this i've played for a total of 19 hours and plan on playing much, MUCH more.This new borderlands. for starters. is NOT a DLC of any kind... I questioned it myself for how much of a new game this would be.. how it would play.. and simular questions as quite a lot of others had as well.. but after playing it for myself I can quite happily say, this game is comedy gold.I'm a massive fan of the borderlands series, played though the first and second game many times in almost every way, I completely loved the game, and TPS is no different, it's a perfect mix of the Borderlands gameplay style, with better scaling, more fun weapons, new Oz kits systems that allow so much more in the game.Oz kits is something people feared... it's not a resourse you need to manage... borderlands is a game that is made around having fun, laughing and doing some crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥ they wouldn't add in a new system you have to worry about or die.. no.. you can go for about 2-4 minutes before your oxygen depletes EASY.. and even then, you can barely run 30 seconds without a sourse of oxygen to refill at.. not to mention of you do run out.. you lose about %0.5 of your health pre second.. so theres no need to worry at all... Oz kits just add to the fun of the game.Characters, All the characters are amazing... now some people complained there was no siren and such.. though I like it.. it's a breath of fresh air, new characters, new playstyles, everything about them in different execpt in it's basic aspects, in which they keep though the series...Aussie lingo, now this is something I can say might annoy anyone who isn't Australian.. though I am myself.. and it's the most funny mix between modern and 80 years ago, just listen to the dialog in this game had me and my friends laughing for minutes at a time, not to mentiton the new talking gun.Verticality... now this has to be one of the best new features of the game, in BL1 and partly BL2, the game was flat, it wasn't layed or have platforming all to much, the areas were often closed in, but with this game, it takes the use of the new Oz kits and places verticality EVERYWHERE, any palce in the game you go, there will be enemies all over and at different hights, it's not a simple look to the spawn location of a door and wait, it's try guess where they are going to be, keeps the game more fresh.though for a summary, I'd give this game a 9/10, for me this is almost a perfect game aside from a few bugs in it, though it's still launch week, and they need some time to fix a few things out, but overall I am loving this game, I love the fact they made the game harder, more of a challange this time around.So if you're a borderlands fan, I would recommend this game, I don't really care if people try downvote this due to the massive ♥♥♥♥♥torm that is around Borderlands, without any good reason, people can read this and decide for themself.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												The first week of playing this game I had 90 hours played total so I enjoyed it for what it was but it's not a properly worthy sequel to Borderlands 2. I know that Gearbox wanted to make this as a filler game to fill in gaps and questions fans had about the events that lead up to Handsome Jack's takeover of Hyperion, especially for people who've played both Borderlands 1 and 2, and it shows. This is just here to hold you over until Borderlands 3 comes out.Some people complain that this is just Borderlands 2 in space and they're essentially right. However, I don't see that as a negative thing since I loved Borderlands 2 (I have approx. 400 hours into that game). I expected it to be nothing else actually. It's a Borderlands game. It should look like a Borderlands game and it should play like a Borderlands game, and it pulls that off perfectly. When you go back to BL2 after playing this game you actually realize how much you miss the butt slams and the Oz kit boost ability.Now, the main problem I had with this game is that it felt way too short in comparison to BL2, especially for a game priced as a triple-A full length title. The main quest line felt too lackluster. Again, it's good for what it is but it wasn't worth €50. If it had been priced at €35-40 I could see it being a more resonable price for this game.Another thing I didn't like about this game was that there was WAY too much dialogue where it didn't need any. I'm gonna quote TotalBicuit here and say that "it's the game that likes to hear itself talk". It can become a bit annoying here and there and the plot points they're trying to get across to the player could either be left out completely or just be explained in a much simpler manner that didn't need 2 minutes of NPC dialogue.All in all it's a good game with minor flaws and I recommend you buy this when it's on sale.

number of helpful: 40 of 76 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I can't believe I'm recommending this game.  But I am.After enduring the lackluster, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ writing of Borderlands 2, I was skeptical about the pre-sequel.  I was ESPECIALLY skeptical about the sixty-dollar price tag.  But I'm glad it all turned out well (sort of), in the end.As it happens, the pre-sequel is a more balanced gameplay experience, and much more challenging - but in a good way - than its predecessors.  Gone are the obliterating alpha strikes of badass enemies in BL2.  There are far fewer WTF gear gates and gimmicky asshats who one-shot you regardless of spec.  Now the ride is smooth, for the most part - the difficulty really spikes once you get into True Vault Hunter Mode, and the game will massacre you if you're ill-prepared.  But on the whole, things are way more fun, and ten times more mobile.The writing blows Borderlands 2 out of the water.  I hated the writing in Borderlands 2 for reasons irrelevant to this review.  The Pre-Sequel actually reduces the amount of inane nattering in your ears from characters trying far too hard to be clever (or worse, clumsily TELLING you to care about some problem or issue or person or whatever when no one has SHOWN you why you should).  In BLTPS, instead, it presents you with surprisingly dark storytelling, a nuanced world, and incredible pacing.  This game is intense, and highly economical.  Not a moment is wasted.  It's still got some very funny moments, and I find the Scavs to be far more entertaining than the Bandits of BL2.  Some of these Australians sound so authentic, it's like they're gargling a wallaby for some of these lines.  Just deep, throaty stuff.  Delightful.One of the darkest corners of the plot regards the rarely-trod avenue of artifical intelligences and the ethical treatment thereof.  I won't spoil anything, but it's chilling.The cast of characters is amazing.  Claptrap is hilarious, yet surprisingly poignant and tragic, in his own sideways fashion.  Wilhelm is a refreshing breath of stoic masculinity in a medium plagued by try-hards and wanna-be ubermenschen alpha-nerd projections.  Nisha is at first hateable and seemingly two-dimensional, but unlocking more of her backstory reveals not just a cute 'for funsies' sadist, but an actual born-again psychopath who suffered the kinds of traumas that make modern serial killers.And then there is my absolute favorite, Athena.  In a world starved for powerful, matronly female role models, Athena takes the cake - she is both sexy and professional, modest, yet bold.  She doesn't mince words, and she makes her presence known through minimal effort.  In addition to the characters being stronger, there's also a great deal more individuality on the part of the PCs - your character responds to dialogue, to other characters, and there are plenty of in-combat call-outs geared toward specific partnerships (when one player activates their special ability, the other characters call out and notice).  Little touches like these are what seperate good games from great games.On top of all that, the environments are gorgeous and colorful, and the music is a FANTASTIC retro-future ensemble - think EVE Online meets Bladerunner meets When Mars Attacks!I could go on and on.  The game is amazing.  Why it has a low metacritic score, I can't imagine.  I hated it at first for the difficulty, but once I acclimated, and changed some of my bad habits from Borderlands 2, I loved it.Give it a try.  The price tag is steep, I know.  Maybe wait until it goes on sale.  But if you can afford it?  Go for it - especially if you have friends to play with.

												A pre-review: reduced gravity doesn't mean reduced fun....or does it???  To describe it, it's a lot like tying a helium balloon around the waist of a small dog or cat and ringing the dinner bell. Or maybe more like being with your kids on a trampoline and one of them is trying to throw a water balloon at you. Or perhaps like you're skateboarding down a hill and then you realize that it was uphill instead yet you are still moving for some odd reason.  Or FEDEX delivers your package one day before you order (it can happen with Amazon Prime). Yeah, that's exactly what pre-sequel is like.  One gamer called it cool, then I realized he was simply refering to the temperature on the moon and I was misinterpreting. Sorry, that was bad - I know.  Still if you liked Borderlands 2, this adds an additional fighting dimension on a new verticle axis. If you didn't get Borderlands 2, try that first, it's epic, felt like the devs put more energy into it.  This one is more like an giant DLC in my opinion.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												After completing the second play through in TVHM, I now feel confident that I can adequately post a review about this game.  So, without further ado, lets begin by immediately discussing the pro’s list of this game: Very good storyline that does a great job tying BL1 with BL2, Oz kits are awesome as are the double jumps, new character classes, new weapon types, new ammo types, the Grinder, and the additional commentary by all of the playable characters is hilarious! ("Remember, its not Malware, it’s a feature!") Now, the con’s list: Borderlands TPS main storyline is  very  short in comparison to its predecessors, many of the side missions are very tedious, but most importantly the game has a very… unfinished feel to it. (This can be seen in graphics, countless glitches (characters getting stuck, suspended in mid-air, not to mention the countless times when there are multiple people playing we have noticed that walls and other objects seem to ‘tear’ and you can just pass right through them, in my case (count is at 3 now) in group play I have gotten “stuck” in a locker when searching for loot).Final thoughts: Borderlands TPS has the makings of being another great game, especially with such an imaginative storyline.  However, the short story line, accompanied by a plethora of bugs, fails to truly take advantage of what, at its core, could have been a great game. The take-away from this is to recognize that Borderlands TPS is the result of 2K, and 2K Australia,   not  Gearbox as the primary developer.I would def. recommend this game, but if you have not already purchased it, with “Tales from the Borderlands” coming out in Nov. also, I would recommend waiting until the ‘Steam’ holiday sales.Additional comments:  Many of the new NPCs all have Aussie accents and as a result much of the humor is ‘Aussie-based cultural references/humor,’  not a complaint , just takes some getting used to.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												BL2 with low gravity and more character self mutterings :D They decreased the drops in BL2, with the rares going waaaay down. Now the drops in BLtPS they are almost nonexistant. 3247billion guns in the game doesn't matter if you see the same 10-20 over and over again in 2-3 different levels with 2-3 different variations. With these "more guns" you don't get more inventory space either, defeating the purpose. Also, no good farming places? Concordia sure doesn't have them, atleast BL1 and 2 did. So no good farming spots as of yet. The one I did find was "above my strength level" lets say. Awesome, but disappointing. 7/10I keep adding because things keep♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. There's alot of "death ledges" and open spaces. Which sucks since all your loot seems to fall off there.I have changed from Not Recommended to Recommend ON SALE. More glitches were patched its now not based on glitches but gameplay.Full review here: http://fg-2.com/2014/10/28/review-borderlands-the-pre-sequel-prepatch-review/

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												 Ok, firstly.. whoever thought that adding low gravity into a game based on "killing stuff to gather loot so you can kill stuff faster" is a nice idea - should be fired from gaming industry.. or at least have his/her thoughts sorted into something more reliable.. there's nothing better to see some shiny orange piece flying away from you into open space.. GJ on that.. Secondly, could probably adjust the models animations that's staying the same from, like, the 1st game already? (not even mentioning it looking silly and glitchy at times) Apart of that it's just "the same BL game". Said gravity and some new types of weapons added a little, but not as much for this game to stand out in the series in my opinion. Is it good? Is it worth it? It is, if you're looking for another shooter game to just go and pew-pew without much brains put into the process (which I prefer after a hard working day for instance). Or just to chill with your friends maybe. Can't call this a "must-have" but worth a try or two.

												A very well done FPS/RPG game. Another great entry in the Borderlands series. If you enjoyed either of the other Borderlands you will love this game. I yo haven't played borderlands this is a Decent start point, the classes all play fairly unique to the other games classes. Notably no siren class. 												This game is very fun and is in competition of the previous borderlands. The story does feel rushed, so, you'd need to wait on those dlcs, but if you played this game with friends, then you will not be dissapointed. It is a good way to pass the time, and the capabilitoes of each character make them all reliable, fun to play, and actually useful when trying to grind, boss hunt, or do the raid boss. The previous game had horrendous drop rates, but this one has drop rates are far more superioir, and the possibility of getting any rare item is hightened, making it more fun. The community of this game is very generous and helpful, and you could honestly (from personal experience) gol onto any game, ask for boosting, and most players would be perfectly fine with it, after thay are done with their current objective. The possibility of actually finding a game is lower than before though, simply because not enough people have this game. A suggestion of summer sale would be good, because then many would possibly get this game, leaving room for more cooperation with many other players. Personal review, 9/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												TL;DR - worse Borderlands 2 that gets terribly frustrating and exhausting by the end missions. 4/10.And now the long one. Let's just start with stating that this is still a Borderlands game, so if you enjoyed the previous ones you will most likely enjoy this one too, especially when playing with friends. For the most of it. Then you'll get frustrated and will want to just quit this god damn game.Lets start with the missions. There are some nice ones, some quite unique and fun ones. But that's like 5 out of 40. The rest are all repetitive fetch quests that get unnaturally prolonged, because if not the game wouldn't be the half of what it is now. The worst part is that this applies not only to side missions, which are obviously always lower priority for production, but for main quests as well. Without spoiling, there was a mission that could be literally summarised to:-Go to A-A doesn't work,  you need to go to B then-B doesn't work, ok C will for sure-Well, C ALMOST works, you only need D to make it work-Ok you have D? Now go back to C-Ok C works now? ok go to B and then you'll proceed to the final part of the missionWhere story wise, it could very well and at B and be much more fun. Even worse, by the very end the WHOLE GAME feels like it is being unneccessarily prolonged, without an actual, reasonable explenation why. That leads us to writing.The humor is worse. It's got to a level of stupidity that is actually cringe worthy and embarasing. The one part that they did well - Jack's change - is kind of destroyed by the fact that I can't state my point about it. Obviously, it's always like that in games like this, you have no dialogue choices etc, but the problem is, in other games your character doesn't make a change on it's own as well. SPOILER STARTS HERE: I've started the game as a more or less good guy. I wanted to save the moon with Jack's help or as his help. Regardless, even though I might not be 100% rightous, I was still good. And that's the character I liked and I wanted to play as. Later, when Jack kills 4 scientist because he suspected that one of them was a traitor my character suddenly screams AWESOME. What the ♥♥♥♥? I mean, it was awesome in terms of building Jack's character, showing how voilence is changing him, but I never wanted my character to change with him, nor was I ever teased that it might happen. SPOILER OVER.Next topic. Loot and character progression are both done terribly. Let's just say I've finished the game with weapons not higher than level 22, as a 26 level character, fighting level 28 boss. That's not how you balance loot. I've switched my sniper rifle 3 times during over 20h of gameplay. Also I have not seen a SINGLE legendary weapon, not to mention one I would actually like and want to use. Something that also didn't help with my gear progression is that I lost a TON of items by them dropping into abyss. You'd imagine they could write a piece of code that ensures loot lands on reachable place in a game that's heavily loot dependend.Character progression can be summed up as: start with active ability, put 25 boring stat boosters after and then put an actually cool ability at level 26. Boring as hell. One thing that also needs to be mentioned here - main story balancing, combined with unrewarding loot system, pretty much makes side quests obligatory.My last big issue with the game is it's optimization - on a GTX 780 i had very frequent drops to 30-40 even without maxing all of the settings and with turning off the PhysX. Another wierd thing with it is that even when it was running at stable 60 according to Steam FPS counter, there was TERRBILE screen tearing. G-Sync helped there, but not everyone can afford it. Then, when I switched to GTX 980Ti in the middle, it was still not achieving stable 60. What the hell. Witcher 3 runs at stable 60 in 2K, while also looking much, much better.The other issues are not as big, but perhaps worth mentioning. Gearbox introduced a couple of new gameplay mechanics, for example oxygen in vaccum, lower gravity with booster jump and laser guns. Not a single one of those is actually fun. Oxygen is annoying, because for most of the game you don't care about it, only sometimes you are searching for O2 source nearby in panick. Lower gravity (which means higher jumps) would be fun if not the fact that level design doesn't seem to adjust to that correctly and multiple collisions are just a tiny bit too high to jump on them, even with perfectly timed booster. Laser guns are mostly useless (I found one that I was using for a bit, because it actually shot where I poitned it to, rest shoots wherever it wants).There was also a lot of small bugs, like lacks of collisions or incorrectly placed ones, NPCs falling torso deep into terrain (mostly lunatics after their jump attack), problems with AI - NPCs walking past me peacefully while I'm in combat with their friends or launching a jump attack at a helicopter that's over lava in one of the missions, resulting in killing themselves, graphical glitches like some wierd, glowing mesh being left hanging in the air after killing one of the opponents.To be honest it's hard to say anything good about the game aside from the fact that shooting is fun. But then the last two missions start, you have♥♥♥♥♥♥gear because of unrewarding loot system and you just want this to end, but it doesn't. It goes on and on and on for no logical reason other that boosting the number of hours neccessary to finish the game. I do not recommend this one.

content:
Posted: January 3
Product received for free
												After doing one run, I can really find This game ALOT of fun.I have all the DLCClaptastic voyage review will be on that DLC, Not the official game.To be honest this is very fun, But rather short.This game is a blast, I can never find my self not finding something to do.But lets get the basics which is what you came here for. The Basics The basics of the game are thisO2/OxygenOxygen works in a sense, That If you are Out of Air bubbles, or Oxygen Vents. You will slowly lose oxygen.
After Oxygen is depeleted (You can get OZ kits to help this)
You will start to take health damage, Regardless of shield.
Oxygen damage isn't too bad, Unless you are low on HP already with no near by source.
Using Oxygen, You can revive players.
OR Use it to Rocket boost.

Rocket boosting/Slamming
Rocket boosting gives you Around The same distance as a Grenade jump from BL2 (Which is not existant in this game)
While In the air you can hit "C" To Slam the ground.
And dependant on your OZ kit, This can damage enemies, Stun them, Burn them,Acidize them. Much more!

Weapons

  Manufacture Weapon type   Jakobs -- High damage, tons of recoil  Revolvers,Snipers,Assault rifles,Shotguns    Hyperion -- Accuracy,But less fire rate Pistol,Snipers,SMGS,Shotguns,Lasers    Maliwan -- Wanna melt,freeze,shock them? Get a maliwan! SMGS,Pistols,Snipers,Lasers,Rocket launchers   Scav -- ALL THE BULLETS! But no accuracy... Well,Basically everything except snipers.    Torgue -- EXPLOSIONS!!!!  Rocketlaunchers,Gryojet launchers,Rocket pistols,Torpedo shotguns    Dahl -- Burst,And little recoil! SMGS,Snipers,Pistols,Assault rifles,Lasers    Vladof -- Wanna be  bullet hell? Assault rifles,RPGS,Pistols,Snipers    Tediore -- Explosive reloads!  Shotguns,SMGS,Pistols,RPGS,Lasers Luneshine
 Name Effect  Oxygeninator Coming soon!  Then you have the characters

Claptrap,Nisha,Wilhelm,Athena

-DLC characters-
Jack,The Baroness

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												This game is just like Borderlands 2 on the moon that you see in the games before.Its enjoyable and fun, you can easily get used to the jumping because of the low gravity, and thats one of the thing i really liked about this game, that you can get up to places where you wasn't able to get up before.The new powers, vault hunters are good and unique.The new vehicles are really strange, i don't know because of the new physics of the moon or just because they are new mechanics but they more really oddly and just simply really bad to controll.The game is short but you'll probably play it through more times to get a feel for the other characters, i can't really talk about the DLCs bacause they not intrest me, the only one that i would say that you should buy is the Handsome Jack double, that seems fun.The looting is the same as in borderlands 2, the graphics are mostly the same but theres a few better looking settings and scenes, the new mechanics, such as the cyro elemental is really fun and good, it makes the game way more enjoyable. If you liked Borderlands 2 and you want some more of that game and their characters than this game is for you, if you can pick it up on a sale its a good choice for a good value, but not for a full price copy.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I have played through both borderlands 1 and 2 multiple times with all the characters. And while I still enjoyed this game, it wasn't nearly as good as borderlands 2. It gives you more backstory and helps deveop the characters we know and love; however, it falls short of the greatest of borderlands 2. It has the same mechanics as BL2 but with a smaller world. It is basically a huge DLC for BL2. There is no humorous villian, or exciting boss battles with various abilities. Granted, handsome Jack is in the game and the first few and last boss battles are interesting, and the low gravitiy makes everything pretty awesome but the game is somewhat dull. Most missions consist of: go there, fetch that, fix this, come back, oh it doesn't work so find another way to fix it. Anyway, I am a huge borderlands fan so despite everything I still loved the game and the crazy aussie accents. But if you're new, PLAY BORDERLANDS 2 FIRST. IT IS SO MUCH BETTER IN EVERY ASPECT AND ALL AROUND MORE ENJOYABLE. This game is rather fun, yet boring. It is best to play with friends. Furthermore, it is definitely not worth the $60 or even the $50 right now. I grabbed it while it was $30 and I believe anything $45 or below is worth it for this game. Overall, 8/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												TL;DR - worse Borderlands 2 that gets terribly frustrating and exhausting by the end missions. 4/10.And now the long one. Let's just start with stating that this is still a Borderlands game, so if you enjoyed the previous ones you will most likely enjoy this one too, especially when playing with friends. For the most of it. Then you'll get frustrated and will want to just quit this god damn game.Lets start with the missions. There are some nice ones, some quite unique and fun ones. But that's like 5 out of 40. The rest are all repetitive fetch quests that get unnaturally prolonged, because if not the game wouldn't be the half of what it is now. The worst part is that this applies not only to side missions, which are obviously always lower priority for production, but for main quests as well. Without spoiling, there was a mission that could be literally summarised to:-Go to A-A doesn't work,  you need to go to B then-B doesn't work, ok C will for sure-Well, C ALMOST works, you only need D to make it work-Ok you have D? Now go back to C-Ok C works now? ok go to B and then you'll proceed to the final part of the missionWhere story wise, it could very well and at B and be much more fun. Even worse, by the very end the WHOLE GAME feels like it is being unneccessarily prolonged, without an actual, reasonable explenation why. That leads us to writing.The humor is worse. It's got to a level of stupidity that is actually cringe worthy and embarasing. The one part that they did well - Jack's change - is kind of destroyed by the fact that I can't state my point about it. Obviously, it's always like that in games like this, you have no dialogue choices etc, but the problem is, in other games your character doesn't make a change on it's own as well. SPOILER STARTS HERE: I've started the game as a more or less good guy. I wanted to save the moon with Jack's help or as his help. Regardless, even though I might not be 100% rightous, I was still good. And that's the character I liked and I wanted to play as. Later, when Jack kills 4 scientist because he suspected that one of them was a traitor my character suddenly screams AWESOME. What the ♥♥♥♥? I mean, it was awesome in terms of building Jack's character, showing how voilence is changing him, but I never wanted my character to change with him, nor was I ever teased that it might happen. SPOILER OVER.Next topic. Loot and character progression are both done terribly. Let's just say I've finished the game with weapons not higher than level 22, as a 26 level character, fighting level 28 boss. That's not how you balance loot. I've switched my sniper rifle 3 times during over 20h of gameplay. Also I have not seen a SINGLE legendary weapon, not to mention one I would actually like and want to use. Something that also didn't help with my gear progression is that I lost a TON of items by them dropping into abyss. You'd imagine they could write a piece of code that ensures loot lands on reachable place in a game that's heavily loot dependend.Character progression can be summed up as: start with active ability, put 25 boring stat boosters after and then put an actually cool ability at level 26. Boring as hell. One thing that also needs to be mentioned here - main story balancing, combined with unrewarding loot system, pretty much makes side quests obligatory.My last big issue with the game is it's optimization - on a GTX 780 i had very frequent drops to 30-40 even without maxing all of the settings and with turning off the PhysX. Another wierd thing with it is that even when it was running at stable 60 according to Steam FPS counter, there was TERRBILE screen tearing. G-Sync helped there, but not everyone can afford it. Then, when I switched to GTX 980Ti in the middle, it was still not achieving stable 60. What the hell. Witcher 3 runs at stable 60 in 2K, while also looking much, much better.The other issues are not as big, but perhaps worth mentioning. Gearbox introduced a couple of new gameplay mechanics, for example oxygen in vaccum, lower gravity with booster jump and laser guns. Not a single one of those is actually fun. Oxygen is annoying, because for most of the game you don't care about it, only sometimes you are searching for O2 source nearby in panick. Lower gravity (which means higher jumps) would be fun if not the fact that level design doesn't seem to adjust to that correctly and multiple collisions are just a tiny bit too high to jump on them, even with perfectly timed booster. Laser guns are mostly useless (I found one that I was using for a bit, because it actually shot where I poitned it to, rest shoots wherever it wants).There was also a lot of small bugs, like lacks of collisions or incorrectly placed ones, NPCs falling torso deep into terrain (mostly lunatics after their jump attack), problems with AI - NPCs walking past me peacefully while I'm in combat with their friends or launching a jump attack at a helicopter that's over lava in one of the missions, resulting in killing themselves, graphical glitches like some wierd, glowing mesh being left hanging in the air after killing one of the opponents.To be honest it's hard to say anything good about the game aside from the fact that shooting is fun. But then the last two missions start, you have♥♥♥♥♥♥gear because of unrewarding loot system and you just want this to end, but it doesn't. It goes on and on and on for no logical reason other that boosting the number of hours neccessary to finish the game. I do not recommend this one.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Changing my view on this game now... Far below is my old review... I've changed my view, due to the travesty of UVHM and the lack of good DLC. I am not complaining about UVHM being really hard, but the fact that it is insanely easy. Compared to BL2 UVHM, BL:TPS UVHM is baby mode. I am killing enemies with only 3 pulls of a trigger with a shock Torrent. Then, the enemies have horrible aiming, I'm standing right infront of Dahl soldiers and they miss just about every single shot! Get this game only if you wish to not have a challenge!OLD REVIEWBorderlands The Pre-Sequel... The latest installment of everyone's favourite loot and shoot series.However, it gets a lot of hate for being practically DLC for Borderlands 2. The hate it gets is not deserved, this is still an amazing game, aside from the fact that is the same stuff.Pros & Cons+ Butt Slamming and Oxygen is the best mechanic ever!!!+ Amazing Story+ Funny Writing+ NPCs now recognize you as a certain character, giving you different dialogue...+ Your characters do way more talking (probably a bad thing for Claptrap as he is annoying as)+ The new playerable charcters have interesting skills, branching away from the Commando, Assassin, Siren and Gunzerker sets.+ THE NEXT BORDERLANDS IS COMFIRMED!!!!+ References to thousands of other movies and games!+Nappykins Lunestalker, nuff' said.- Start is really slow- Oxygen drops are probably the most common drop... Please make Oz a little bit harder to get...- About 5 missions take place on Helios (Not included Watch Your Step as it has Zero-G) out of 12 missions in the game... On Helios, there is no zero-g D:... Making buttslams near to impossible to do...- I didn't like most of the Austrailians (Not being racist or anything), I just felt that their writing was poor and they weren't funny at all (I think Gladstone was the only funny one, just by a wee' bit)Borderlands The Pre-Sequel is a must get game, however I'd reccomend playing through Borderlands 2 first as it certainly helps you understand what is going on. If you loved Borderlands 2, then you will certainly love this new entry into the series

In Space.It's fun to shoot thingsGravity slamsLasersSometimes entertainingTalkative charactersBest DLC. Ever. Better than Tiny Tina's from the 2ndWeapons that freeze peopleStoryline has one of the best gaming villains' rise to power (Handsome Jack)Glitch weapons are fun and look coolKilling people with fire is still entertainingMr. TorgueClaptrapCons:Weapons are almost exactly the same as the previous game (even legendaries)Most elemental weapons are only situationally usefulThe AI is lacklusterThere are only a few different enemies (bandits, melee bandits, heavy bandits, flying things with lasers, small flying things, bugs, and midgets)RNG sucks, I consider myself lucky to get a greenRepetitive environmentUnmemorable charactersAwkwardly placed slang, memes and 'vulgar' languageSub-par voice acting on several charactersGlitchy terrainInsta-kill pits everywhereLack of save pointsAn UNGODLY amount of runningAN UNGODLY AMOUNT OF BACKTRACKINGSimplistic missions (run here, something happens so you have to run over there to lower that bridge, then back across the zone, then back to the bridge)Several unlikable charactersStoryline is subparAtlas STILL just up and disapeared after the first game, where did all their badass guns go?

												The people at gearbox had a lot to live up to after borderlands 2. They KINDA delivered.pros-Same awesome artstyle-great soundtrack-same design and gameflow-badass rank and other features are the same-same menu style and mechanics-grinder-moxxi, lilith, and roland please note that MOST of the pros are related to being the same as borderlands 2 cons-not compelling to finish story-bland and unvarying terrain-bland and unvarying enemies-bland and unvarying side missions-less control over movement-oxygen-less intriguing characters / action skills-normal mode more difficult (bad for newer players)-UNFARMABLE BOSSES-returning legendaries that cannot be farmed (have to get them from grinder/vendor)This game did so many things right in the fact of staying the same as borderlands, but got a lot of key things wrong. content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												An interesting addition to the series. It still follows the cookie cutter design of previous Borderlands titles with the exception of having low gravity environments and laser weapons in the mix. Handsome Jack, Nisha and Wilhem's a**hat origins are explored in this game while Claptrap and Athena get fleshed out more. The diversity of characters is great compared to previous titles, especially considering most of the Elphis' (the moon) inhabitants are all Australian and reflect elements of Australian culture; Janey Springs comes to mind and she is a bad♥♥♥♥♥lesbian mechanic who adores Athena.Overall I loved this game but it's boring to play solo and should definetly be enjoyed with a friend or two.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Well, the newest Borderlands game squares up fairly well to the games of its kind but does it really all add up to make a good game? I'll list a simple pro/con list to this game.Pros:-Fairly unique and new worlds. Nothing too copy/paste.-New characters, all unique as well.-Enough to explore on Elpis.-New laser guns are a great addition.-Probably the most fun gameplay in the series. -Interesting backstory and questionable moments.-Leaves you thinking.+/- Austrailian accents? +/- Laser guns. (Some people actually hate the feature)-Not as funny as BL2 or BL. Didn't. Laugh. Once.-Nothing has really changed in customization/badass ranks.-Short if you're not a completionist-Story just....drags.....on....-In this game, it seems like the characters are not treated equal. There are some starting characters better than others.In 2 sentences:Borderlands The Pre-Sequel seems second rate to Borderlands 2, however, it is extremely worth it at a lower price than 60 USD. If you're a die-hard Borderlands fan, pick up at a lower price then have fun!

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												This is essentially a shorter, space-themed version of Borderlands 2. Taking place and tying-in the gap between the first and second game. A lot of people and things you'll recognize if you played the first two games. It plays nearly identically to BL:2.... except now you can: Grind sh*tty weapons into (hopefully) better ones, ride around in the 'Stingray' (cool little new vehicle), Butt-slam people as you hop around in Zero-G (pretty fun) and shoot laser weapons (also pretty fun). Not any revolutionary changes really, but it's more than just Borderlands 2 with a moon-themed skin slapped on like a lot of people imply. Just about everyone is Australian too... Yay?All in all, If you enjoy the Borderlands universe I'd say this is worth looking into. It's a lot shorter than the first two games, so I'd wait for a sale if you do buy it. Unless you're a huge Borderlands fan... or you are feeling overburdened with money ;)
