content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												What makes a good man? That is what ‘Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel’ asks of you in the last 10 minutes, as the avalanche of betrayals, heartbreak, and madness culminates in the creation of one of the finer video-game villains in the last few years. But, is he really the villain? He certainly believes himself to be the hero of this yarn. I guess, in the end, it is left to the Vault Hunter him or herself to decide upon the matter in a way they them self see fit. Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the prequel (and, of course, sequel) to one of the finest shooter games of last generation, and the origin of Handsome Jack.Getting in to the meat of this look-back on this game, we shall start with game play. If you played Borderlands 2 (or the first Borderlands, for that matter) you already know the gist of how this game works and plays. You shoot enemies, you collect loot, and you kill more enemies. Subsequently, you also get more loot (and so on, and so on…). The Diablo-esque loot system was already refined in BL2, and did not require much in ways of improvement in TPS. The addition of laser-type guns is a fun one, and is a great addition to the stock experience. The beauty of what makes this system work is of course what every player loves-to-hate, RNG. Do you get a purple VLADOF sniper rifle that shoots corrosive bullets, all the while playing Mozart’s ‘Requiem’ in a solemn remembrance for the hundreds you have (and will) kill? Or do you receive a six shooter, which in a true Joker fashion doesn’t even shoot bullets? RNG at its finest.The general game play, which is pretty much copy-and-paste from BL2, is enhanced by the addition of zero (almost) gravity. Jumping around has never been more delicious, and the fact that you can kill your enemies by butt-slamming on to them is just pure awesomeness. As fun as it is to just jump  up and down, all around, whilst breaking necks and taking names, the addition of platforming proves to be a two-edged sword. Whilst it does give a certain sense of exhilaration, going higher and higher, and exploring the countryside, when you get knocked back by an explosion or a ‘Lunatic’ (TPS’s Psycho) landing right next to you, or (as it happened many times to me) you just accidentally walk off of the edge, yer dead. And it’s back to the last save point for ya! This happened in such a rarity to me in early game that it didn’t prove to be more than an annoyance. But as the game progresses in to the late-game parts, especially in the purple-land-of-go-f***k-yourself, I could swear the developers were playing a practical joke on me.The moon of Pandora, on which this game unfolds, is called Elpis. And hot-damn! How beautiful it is. As much as I loved BL2, one thing that always annoyed me (which was kind of bad, it being the most important part of it) was the world of Pandora. There just were too many browns, and reds, and just purely dull colors. Elpis, on the other hand, is a lot of…white. White ground, white walls, black sky. But look just over the horizon…and you’ll see some damn awesome backgrounds. The beauty of the space, mixed with all kinds of stuff that comes out of the ground, just makes the view very pleasing to the eye.But, enough with that chatter. Let us enter the REAL meat of this review (and my favorite part of the whole game): the story, and characters. I personally hold these 4 Vault Hunters (Athena, Nisha, CL4P-TP, and Wilhelm) to be the best VH’s from the past 16. Maybe it’s the fact that we FINALLY get some interaction from them in regards to what happens in the story. Or maybe it’s how awesomely these 4 fit with the story of BL2. (*slight SPOILERS FOR BL2*) If you played BL2, you must remember Wilhelm, the slaughterer of New Haven, and someone, of whom even Angel was afraid of, and Nisha, the iron-fisted ruler and sheriff of Lynchwood, and Handsome Jacks’ girlfriend. They, of course, are one half of the VH quadruplet that saves Elpis. The second half is (oh god…) CL4P-TP (or Claptrap), and Athena. Claptrap you’ll know from the beginning, and entire game, of BL2, who heralds your ability to walk as being “…Handsome Jacks’ downfall!” And Athena actually comes from the first Borderlands, from the DLC ‘General Knoxx’s Secret Armoury’, as well as the EXCELLENT Tell-Tale’s ‘Tales from the Borderlands’ game (which actually happens after TPS).To complement these excellent VH’s, you have Mad Moxxi (of course), Lilith and Roland, a new character called Janey Spring’s (who actually also appears in ‘Tales...’), and of course, Jack. I do not want to spill anything, but this game made me despise Lilith EVEN MORE than I already did, and made me love and feel sad for Jack (EVEN MORE than I already did).  Let’s just say that Lilith is kind of a (huge) ♥♥♥♥♥, who may have single handedly caused things that happened in BL2 to be as bad as they were. I actually rooted for Jack (duh, he’s one main characters) the entire game, and it this had been a completely ‘choose-your-self’ game, I would not have blinked a single eyelash before joining forces with Jack, and sticking a hot skewer through Lilith’s eye. But, alas, it is a fixed story, and I, playing as Athena, walked away from Jack, saddened that the man who was a Hero, who saved hundreds of people, descended in to madness.Now, the final thing; the score. I personally loved the game, and I bet anyone who has had even a vested interest in BL2 will love, or like, this game as well. But for someone who is brand new to the franchise, Borderlands 2 is a much better starting point (even so than Borderlands 1). Though I loved the game, the last chapter of the game, which happens as you fight your way to a vault, was one of the most infuriating and skill-demanding levels in any game I have ever played. I, myself, play solo completely, and thus I had no help whatsoever as I faced a wave after wave of some of the most infuriating enemy types and mini-bosses. The level represents, in my honest opinion, a HUGE rise in difficulty. And it will be VERY infuriating. But, once you have finally gotten to the end, you can’t help but smile. ‘The Pre-Sequel’ is a great game, from a now defunct studio, and one that any self-deserving Borderlands fan should experience. 8.5/10

My next big problem goes with the airborn problem as ALL the enemys seemed to fly or were at my feet on the ground. Get ready to aim at your feet to kill the 10000000 torks and other creatures that spawn or spray into the sky as every scav/bandit flys and sometimes for way to long.I bought on sale for $20 and i think that was a little too much but as i loved borderlands i can live with the purchase (id be really upset if i bought at full tho) sooooo I want to say MAYBE but ill hit yes just because my two biggest problems arent game breaking more just annoying aspects and i loved borderlands since me and my friend played it back in highschool.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Plot:I have to say I was a little worried when I first started playing this. I stumbled upon the Borderlands series accidently and started with Tales From the Borderlands. i actually been working backwards and have yet to play BL1, but am a huge fan of BL2. I saved up so I could play presequal, I was so excited for more background on some of the charectors I already loved.At the beginning things didn't feel the same. I knew they weren't supposed to, but I was missing the old charectors, scenery, and familarity I felt with BL2. But as the game went on I fell in love with the story line. Handsome Jack, who was already an all time favorite charector of mine, was well done, and dynamic. His charector is constantly chaning and you really get to know the man behind the mask and what makes him who he is. The final cut scenes had me on the edge of my seat. I flipped out, they were truly amazing! The only thing I wish was that we got to know Angel more, or even more about his back story as a programmer and after the amazing final cut scene there didn't feel like there was any closure. To me it felt like the needed to add one more something to really connect presequal to BL2. Game was beautiful though and as an Artist I so appreciated the coloring, style, and overall look and feel of the enviorment.Gameplay:Has all the feel of the orginials. The only difference being these new lazar guns, the jumping, and oxygen. Guns aren't bad, the game didn't really need them though. the oxygen was way more fun then i thought it was going to be and the double jump really helps you feel like you are in a new enviorment. The Moon curency is a little hard to see versus the stark purple Eridium. The final boss battle just wasn't like Warrior though, that was the only dissapointment. Depends on the person though, if you like the very alien side of Pandora, you'll love it, but if you like the less-explained more resonable (if you can even say that about an alien dragon) you might be a tiny bit dissapointed like me, it just won't have the same feel. Also Concordia is no Sanctuary and I didn't appreciate the passive agressive political views. Violent, probably would recommend for a more mature aduience because of language; but humor is on point and well done.Overall Presequal was amazing and I hope the next borderlands comes out soon, don't know if I can wait three more years!

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Borderlands: The Pre Sequel is definitely a fun experience. Overall, the game is well made and I really can't stress how entertaining it is. But, is it worth the price tag? The blunt answer is no. Luckily I did not pay full price and got it bundled with the season pass for $20. $20-30 is the most this game should've asked for. While it has quality content there isn't much. The story itself takes maybe 15 hours at most. The world is much smaller, the story is shorter, less sidemissions and fewer interesting personalties than in Borderlands 2. The vertical leveling was also quite annoying and made finding your way around or find missions or mission objectives a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥The story is pretty solid, with some entertaining bit sprinkled in and a few returning faces. The huge problem I had with the story was I didn't have any sense of urgency. In BL2 you feel this urge to defeat that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Handsome Jack who is threatening Pandora. In BLPS you can't really get that connection to any of the "villains". Zarpedon is the closest you get to that and she really isn't an intrecate part of the story. You might hear her shout something to her soldiers like "Blow this up!" or "Stop him!" but that's where it ends. Some of the plot is really confusing too. Why are we following Athena's point of view when you're not playing Athena? Even in multiplayer it will show Athena in cutscenes and not the entire group.The characters were okay. Janey Springs was well done, so was The Meriff, of course Crazy Earl and that little kid I can't really remember. I've heard a lot of people complain about Janey and they're usually sad sap loonies. There weren't an awful lot of characters and none of them really have anything terribly intresting about them unlike the ones from BL2 we all loved. The player characters were excently done though, and interact with Jack and other NPCs differently and actually talk. I thought the different abilities were pretty nice, escpecially the DLC ones. Enemies on the other hand weren't done so well. The scavs and lunitics really aren't as good as their raider and pyscho counterparts. They never really say anything intresting or have much variation other than charcter models. Other than that, the UI is basically the same, there's moonstones (which is basically eridium), laser weapons which are pretty cool, Australian accents everywhere, butt slamming, cyro weapons and Mad Moxxi.Don't buy on full price, wait for a sale and you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I'm going to be disgustingly critical with this game, in only the best effort to sound and thorough.  Compared to BL2, this game is akin to that of another DLC. It's ridiculously short, story wise. and everything else wise. I can load up BL2 and find things that are totally new to me, while in this, nothing is new. After about 4-5 hours one can effectively complete every single quest in the game, and take out the "hidden" bosses with relative ease. Honestly, the only reason I actually load up this game anymore is because of the new "Claptastic Voyage" DLC, which I'll get into in a second.  The humour, has been utterly destroyed. Honestly, the only thing that remotely makes me laugh at this game anymore is when Racist Hot Dog appears. That's about it. The story itself is pretty meh. You arrive, and just as quickly, you leave. Sudden surprise enemy "oh no gotta kill that ♥♥♥♥♥ with no backstory!!!!1111!" is the quickest trope. (I mean, yes there are scattered Echo logs about Zarpedon, but they don't reveal who she is or her background, only that she works for Dahl, and that she used to operate the ship that the Bosun has now taken over.) You then find Janey Springs who is a homosexual. She helps the character throughout. She is also a homosexual. She resides in Concordia with her own shop. Did I mention she was a homosexual? This is honestly how her character feels to have been introduced. Flatly, she's a flat homosexual, who's only real character trait, is that she is a homosexual. You meet the Merrif, who spoiler alert, is a traitor!!!111!!11 ZOMGNOWAI?! What a curveball! Then, the defining moment in whether or not I believe this is a good story or not, you meet Felicity. Poor ♥♥♥♥in' Felicity, man. If I ever met a character that didn't deserve what happened to them, it is Felicity. Felicity, who in an actual decent curveball, turns out to be an AI unit, who runs the Drakensburg, and who also ran it when Zarpedon was in control. She has a very fond dislike for killing, and all she wants is to be copied. That's apparently too much to ask. Poor Felicity, my god did you not deserve that. No one does. That is why this story does not sit right with me. Borderlands is a roughly light-hearted game. That, and for lack of better words, is describable only as "entirely ♥♥♥♥ed up." It doesn't belong in a Borderlands-esque setting. I mean, "yeah we're trying to prove that jack is ♥♥♥♥ed up here blah blah blah" but Jesus christ that wasn't necessary. Killing Gladstone and his buddies were more than enough to prove that point, but honestly that may just be me. Though, they did manage to kill off the only character with any sort of depth whatsoever. Speaking of Gladstone, you're then tasked to help in the manufacturing of the first "constructor", or murdered Felicity. You're sent on a quest to do the single most annoying thing on the planet, and that, is to damage multiple enemies without them dying. Overleveled? ♥♥♥♥ you. Powerful weapons? ♥♥♥♥ you. That's honestly how this quest feels. In an effort to ditch this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ quest, I managed to break one of my saves. Gr8. The game ends with you storming Helios and taking it back and blah blah blah generic plot♥♥♥♥♥♥ Also, Moxxi tries to kill you. That twist is commendable, though virulently hinted at through the last couple segments. It's also hilariously obvious if you have any sort of technological knowledge at all. BUT!!!!!11111!!11 because there needs to be a raid boss, theres an open vault and you go and kill the big scary monster and Jack sees the vault thingy and gets his face burned and blah blah blah. THE END! Honestly, it's a 7/10 story. Better than what most major companies make nowadays. The graphics are the same, which sits pretty with me. Borderlands is a sobel shaded game, and it's pretty cool what they manage with it. The weapons are one of the highlights. Now, I can use my favorites from 2 again. You want new ones? Nah, ♥♥♥♥ that. LASERS!!!!!! Which, is a cool addition, just lazy if you're going to not add new weapons.  DLC!Why, oh why, did the Devs decide, "YOU KNOW WHAT WOULD BE GREAT? MORE VAULT HUNTERS! YOU'RE SAYING THE GAME LACKS CONTENT? MORE CHARACTERS!" I mean, yeah they're cool and all but they have no depth. Timothy has slight depth but other than that they're all as flat as a board. Aurelia is shunned by Hammerlock because she kills things. How sad. She's rich though. The skillsets for these characters are nice though, and I don't have much to bicker at. I have to say that Aurelia is a really well done sniper class, though I may be biased because she's what I main. Speaking of the vault hunters... they're all great. But, yet again, lack of development hinders them greatly. The continuity is nice, with them all being some part of BL2, but other than that, eh. Claptrap has character, only because he's been in all three games thus far. Claptastic Voyage. Something that FEELS like Borderlands. FINALLY. I honestly have nothing really to gripe about except for one thing: That last boss fight is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Fix that♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Butt slam your way across the moon of Pandora, Elpis! Some of the franchises most beloved characters return as NPC's and a NPC from a DLC of the first game is now playable. And the most galvinizing (I made a funny!) NPC of all is now playable: Claptrap! Whether you love him or love to hate him he's the most recognizable character in the series. If you like the prior games you'll love Borderlands: TPS. It keeps most of the same formula but adds just enough new things to keep it interesting.This also is 2K and Gearbox's first game to see simultaneous cross platform release. The PS3, Xbox, Mac, Windows, and Linux versions all released at the same time. Pity I have but one thumbs up to give this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Let me start by saying this: If Steam had an "on the fence" option for reviewing games, then I'd pick it for Borderlands: The Pre-sequel. Unfortunately, it does not. I'll list what's good about it first:-I'd be willing to try out most the characters, since they have a good design and cool abilities (accept one, which even the game itself shuns time and time again.)-The new combat mechanics added for zero gravity handle well and are enjoyable to use-Laser weapons are effective and enjoyable to use-Shops have rares for sale on a regular basis through their timed deals-You can combine three weapons of the same rarity into a new weapon with the same rarity or higher, and you can choose to add in moonstones (the game's special currency) for a special buff and finish on it.-The new cryo element is awesome-The new vehicles are great and handle wellOk... *deep breath* now the bad stuff:-Most (if not all) of the dialogue could've been written by a typical teenager-Characters like to move as little muscle as possible during cutscenes, and have mastered the art of speaking without the movement of lips-I encountered a glitch where I was permantly slowed, and the only way to fix it was to restart the game. It doesn't sound too bad, but...-Points where you can respawn are stupidly scarce. There are checkpoints, but you can't teleport to them... If you need to quit for whatever reason, you've got a lot of walking to do. (Enormous waste of time)-Most enemies are re-skinned enemies from Borderlands 2 with the complete lack of funny quotes. -They pulled the menu system straight from BL2 without fixing the infamous "scroll glitch"-The map is still lacking a Z-axis, making navigation to different altitudes long and frustrating-I've passed through multiple solid objects, and fallen through the map, killing me. (Which means more walking!)-Leveling up still takes forever-Quests=running a lot-It's basically overpriced DLC if it isn't on sale. So if you actually bothered to read this far, thanks. If you still want to get this game, buy it at 75% off and have some friends to play with.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												The third game in the Borderlands series and still going strong!  Only 1/2 the length of Borderlands 2, but a worthy game nonetheless.  Still maintaining its top notch voice acting dialog and gameplay.  Not much has changed graphically from Borderlands 2, but the game still looks fantastic.  The main difference in The Pre-Sequel is it takes place solely in space and you'll have to worry about oxygen as a life resource.  Having oxygen does hinder you somewhat.  Especially in long drawn out fights or just exploring.  You'll find your oxygen tanks low or just on the brink of empty a lot of the time, but there are quite a few oxygen hubs located throughout the entire game. Everything you loved about the previous Borderlands games is here including multiple characters to choose from, skill trees, transportation vehicles and of course the ever loving witty dialog!  Having only spawning 1 story driven DLC this time around the game doesn't offer as much as Borderlands 2, but if you're a fan of the series it's a must play.  New lazers, space ground stomps, ice grenades and so much more kept this game going strong until the end.  And ohhh boy.. the ending boss was great.  Good fun!  Recommended.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												I can honestly say, that the pre-sequel has the best gameplay out of all the Borderlands games. Some could argue that Borderlands 2 is the best game of the series and in a way they would be correct. Story and overall progression wise Borderlands 2 is better and the environment is more diverse. But Pre-sequel takes every aspect of Borderlands 2's gameplay and makes it better. For example the skill trees in Borderlands 2 are way more unoriginal and overall stale than in the Pre-sequel.The loot drop rate is also handeld better. In Borderlands 2 I felt lucky if I found a blue loot and extremely lucky if I found a purple loot, and don't even get me started on legendary items. This issue is well solved in the Pre-sequel by making rare loot more common and with the introduction of the grinder. With the grinder you can grind loot you don't desire and get something more desirable.Of course there are issues with Pre-sequel. First even though the pacing right at the begining of the game is better than any other, putting you in the middle of an invasion, the rest of the game is paced extremly poorly. There are times when I don't want to start new characters or start on a new game +, because the begining of the game is extremly tedious. Also Legendary farming is difficult with some loot due to the fact that they don't have a specific boss they drop from.Overall The Pre-sequel beats Borderlands 2 in the gameplay section but otherwise Borderlands 2 is the better game. If you expect an epic story from this game you will be sorely disapointed, but should you just pick up this game with a friend and play it for the experience you wouldn't be dispointed. the game get's a solid 8/10. (also probably should wait for the game to go on sale, overall the games worth with ALL the DLC is about 40-50€)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Okay, I've been putting off this review long enough- but there's definitely quite a lot I want to say.I hear a lot of negativity about this game- saying it's the worst Borderlands game yet, that it should just be a DLC, and that it's not wroth any semblence of money- some people even claimed it was the worst Borderlands game of all time. Personally, I think the game is- in some ways- an improvement, and in others a step back. Let's start with the negatives.The worst part of the game is certainly level designs (this is in the main game). Every level seems to be 'moon with large metal building' or 'moon with blue sky' and my personal favorite 'moon with purple sky'. Levels seem repetive, and variation doesn't exist. The Claptrap DLC, on the other hand, is fantastic when it comes to environments, having some of my favorite level design in any Borderlands game. So, I'm blaming Austrailia for this point (Sorry, mates.)Second, the 'plot twists'. Though some of the plot twists were well handled, others seemed very AREN'T YOU SURPRIIIIISED! I know you're surprised, OH the plot twist. One of my personal favorite of these comes near the beginning (mild spoiler- go to the next paragraph if you don't want it) when you shut down the Jamming Signal on Elpis. You arrived, and go to talk to The Meriff. He avoids you, refusing to speak to you. He's very obviously part of the problem, as he stops you from leaving the town, and his speeches to the town are shifty at best. But then you learn (in Jack's worst performed line yet) that "UGH! The Merriff's been working for Zarpedon the whole time? GAAAH!" Real deductive, Jack. Reeeeally deductive. Overall, the story has some fantastic parts *cough* Zarpedon *cough* and some... less fantastic parts. Borderlands 2 wins on story by far (See profile picture of Angel for reference).My final complaint (don't worry, the review gets optimistic in a second), is the minus of killing off new characters. Two characters are introduced, and then subsequently killed in terrible ways. Though their deaths are fantastic, it gives the minus of them never giving us sidequests- the developers best way of showing us characters personalities and backstories. Pickle's "Another Pickle" quest, for example, or the infamous tea party in Borderlands 2. It doesn't make the quests as powerful as they could have been. But so it goes.Onto the optimism! Firstly, the characters. All six characters are fun to play, and none of them are unable to hold up at the max level. Characters work well together- Claptrap's boosts to reload speed work perfectly with helping Nisha and Timothy/ Jack to fire like there's no tomorrow, and there's definitely more exciting combos to come up with. There are very few pointless trees, and I actually prefer the selection to Borderlands 2.The biggest thing that made the characters come to life are the changing dialogue. Sure, each characters says the same basic idea, but just having the characters say things at all brought you into the experience. With those dialogue trees, we learned that Aurelia hates Roland's hat, watched Wilhelm become more and more of a monster, say Nisha and Jack's 'love' blossom, built up Timothy as one of my favorite Borderlands characters, got some serious feels with Claptrap, and then say the story from Athena's now protaginistic perspective. The game changed enough so that it rewarded a playthrough on every character- where I can't do another playthrough of Borderlands 2 alone.Control wise, the serious also improved. Double jumping is the best. The gameplay keeps energetic and alive the entire time, and gives movement a new importance that I can never seem to match in Borderlands 2. The Oz kit system is a bit annoying, and I wish the oxygen reserves gave a 25% warning rather than a 50%. But even if you do run out, the worst thing that happens is that you're unable to boost for a second, and then you stand on an air vent and you're fine in five seconds.Overall, I enjoyed this game quite a bit, and I'm likely going to continue levelling up characters and try and get these last two achievements (fricking Ghostbusting...). However, $60 dollars plus DLC price (American Style here) is quite a pretty penny- so I suggest waiting for a sale. It's a big name game on Steam, just wait long enough and you'll be fine. If you're rolling in dough up to you neck, though, no harm in dishing out all the cash. Or maybe handing some to me.Either way. The long short is, story is okay but nothing special, gameplay and characters are fantastic, and Jack's decent into Handsome Jack's awesome, Lilith's a prick and I hate her, Brick and Tina narrate True Vault Hunter mode and have a tickle battle, and it's not as bad a game as people make it out to be.Also there's a Space Jam sidequest. So we have that now.BASKETBAAAAAAAAAAAAAALL!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												I've read a lot of detailed reviews that get many things right on the good side, but I have to disagree to some extent on the negativity.  The levels do seem boring at first and they are more boring than BL2 overall.  However, my biggest complaint was getting around early on.  The game takes awhile to offer you fast travel and vehicles to speed things up.  Well, BL2 did also, BUT the levels weren't so repetitive looking to start.  They do get better over time, but the first several levels of the Pre-Sequel are pretty boring.  Yes, the game is a hand-me-down and so one would expect more time on levels since there was less time needed to develop the game instead.  This is clearly a money/greed kind of issue (overpriced at $60, but probably worth it when on sale at $25-30) combined with a rush to get a sequel out faster.  However, at least the game is based on the totally awesome BL2 and less so on the original which I've started playing, but find it hard to get into due to point-of-view issues that can be hacked, but never truly fixed along with any kind of mini-map making it a PITA to navigate, horrible guns early on that are hard to easily compare, etc.  It's just painful to play, yet reading reviews on here that paint it as the second coming while the pre-sequel is total crap for not giving you farming farming farming farming BOREDOM action for the first 161 days, well... I can only conclude that some people see VERY different things in this series than I do.Generally speaking, I don't really farm the first two levels of BL2 or the Pre-Sequel.  it's totally 100% unnecessary.  You can get by quite handily with purple and even blue weapons with a reasonable skill tree.  In fact, the skill trees are vastly more fun, at least with Athena compared to Zero.  I love the Tron-like "disc" she has and how you can build it up to do all kinds of interesting things and serve as a secondary shield, making her character able to survive solo in situations some characters would have trouble with.  I thin Zero was vastly more fun for the first two difficulties for actual melee as he could rush enemies with a skill tree option while stealthed and then take out multiple more enemies.  This worked great in True Vault Hunger Mode, but he couldn't generally do enough damage in Ultimate mode whereas Athena's skills with some stack skills added seems to scale much better in that regard.  That brings us to Legendaries.  They were pretty much a MUST in Ultimate on BL2 if you wanted to play alone for any length of time as trying to spray enemies with slag and then kill them is a pain.  It works better in team mode, but there isn't always someone available to play when you need one.  The problem is BL2 was super stingy with them.  I did see them in the occasional vending machine and almost all the time in the DLC 'token' machines (unlike some that have played longer than I have) and I probably got around six playing alone through the first two skill levels (normal and true vault), all without all that boring farming (with the exception of farming for the Bee to try it out and that didn't take long at all with Hunter Hellquest).  You had two choices as your level went up.  You could spend ages farming for a higher level version, trade/clone or use an editor to level up your weapons to match your current level.  I played around with all three over time, but ultimately found it easier to just level my weapons so they wouldn't be useless and I wouldn't have to farm forever.  The game should have a leveling quest or option, IMO.  The Pre-Sequel, however, adds the grinding machine.  This pretty much offers an alternative to straight farming.  You can pick up lots of white, green and blue weapons and combine them to get each level in turn.  I got like four legendaries in a row this way, believe it or not.  In fact, the game was INCREDIBLY STINGY for almost the entire first difficulty level and then suddenly around level 24, I got like 6 in one session.   I've since found another half dozen in TVHM.  But once again, leveling becomes an issue.  The grinder will make new items from leveled lower items, but there is no way I know of to level your existing weapons (shame once again).  I typically play straight for the first two difficulties and then save frustration by simply using an editor to level the ones I like every five levels or so.  This saves me hundreds of hours of mind-numbing farming and grinding.  I want to have fun, not go insane.   You could find legendaries regularly against The Warrior in BL2 and it's an EASY boss even on Ultimate (I could take him down single handedly with the right weapon in less than 15 seconds in TVHM and about 1 minute in Ultimate without overpowered weapons).  That's fast, but not much fun.  I'd rather be playing Tiny Tina DLC or something amusing.  That brings me to the #1 complaint I have about The Pre-Sequel.  The lack of raid bosses and DLC content in general.  With all the DLC for BL2, you had a nice choice of places to go with friends and take down a really hard one.  Here you have ONE and it's pretty much the same regular end-boss, only a bit harder and I do mean a BIT (i.e. not that hard, but it does take longer than the Warrior which is a pushover and SOOO disappointing after the game making him out to be a bad dude, but then the Warrior is an end-boss, not a raid boss despite people treating him like it.   Claptastic Voyagae came out not too long ago and its end boss is almost downright infuriating in solo play, but it's doable.  THEN there's all these weird "kind of sorta" boss matches you can set up with some controls.  Some of those are pretty intense, but I've found it hard to find people at this time to play it with since many people gave up on this game and never bought that DLC (I gather the first DLC sucked and I've never bothered with it from the reviews).  Even so, Claptastic Voyage is highly amusing but it's nowhere near as funny as Tina Tina, but then I used to play a lot of D&D so it was extra funny for me.  Overall, the biggest problems with this game are not the levels or the re-used legendaries.  Yes, it would be nice to have more variance, but ultimately, people tend to settle on their favorite gun and strategy after awhile, anyway.  The biggest problem is that BL2 was enormous with all the DLCs added (and with regular sales, you could get it ALL for under $15 for over a year now).  Here, it seems that Claptastic Voyage is likely the last DLC and so the biggest problem is less replayability as you run out of quests faster (and I don't mean those boring side quests that aren't as good in BL2 as some make them out to be).   Even so I find myself missing Athena in BL2 for her skills and the high gravity jumps and thrusts and butt slamming.  So clearly the game does have its more fun points, even so.  I think for a lower price, it's a nice addition and if there were some more DLCs like Claptastic Voyage, it could be awesome.This game was made in Australia and I find that it's hard to laugh when you don't get the reference.  I need sub-titles on there just to see what they're saying half the time.  I love doing an Australian accent to team mates during the game, but I say things that are funny to non-Australians and emphasize things differently (e.g. when the Kraks attack, I'll say something from an old movie I saw like, "Oh no, not another ruddy dingo!" and people I've played with have told me that single line was funnier than anything the encountered in the entire game.  In other words, they play straight Aussie humor and you have to be Aussie to really enjoy it.  I caricature the funnier things (to me) I've heard from any given film, etc. and non-Aussies "get" that better since they've likely seen/heard those references in films, etc.  Thus, I think this is why many don't find the humor as funny outside of Australia.  They don't have the background for it and have never heard those "jokes".

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Having completed Borderlands 1&2 including DLC- investing both wallet and time into the universe of Pandora i was ready and waiting for the next BIG thing in the series. Hearing of the Pre-sequel i hastily preordered awaiting release hoping to be the first in a new era of borderlands, Boy does this game fall short. Filled with Aussie accents, poor character development and the added playable clap trap gimmick. This game adds nothing fresh to the already vibrant and rich experience of BL2. This story takes place on the moon acting as a back story to why Jack became 'Evil' as you play as one of the members of his task force helping him to.... i actually forgot ! Heck the plotline is forgetable, all i can say is the ending teases the idea that BL3 will bring back aliens and that will be the premise for the team to fight on a much bigger scale. This game is nothing more than a high priced standalone DLC. Hopefully this is the last we seen of 2K Australia. On a random note, any die-hard Borderlands fan should not acknowledge this as a triumph-its an actual travesty although if you love the series your probably gonna buy it anyway, the added laser rifles are redeemable and the oz suits can add a certain flow to the gameplay, giving the player the aspect that they are feeding off the environment. 2K Australia has still managed to capture the beauty in the series but has failed to create dynamic and memorable range of characters. I hope the predecessor will bring forth an original experience to both this and the last, as its safe to say palette has run dry.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												This game was surprisingly great. Was it on the level of Borderlands 2? no, but it was actually a really great great game. I would highly recommend it if you are a fan of the series. I would have missed out on a great extension of the series. It was fun to see the same characters and delve into some of the background - a must have for fans of the series.Controllers are as you expect, the machines actually give you great gear like the first did (and the 2nd had failed to do). Gameplay was seamless like I had just picked up from Borderlands 2. There was no reason to complain other than ... I didn't like almost ALMOST feeling bad for Handsome Jack! Oh, the one thing that was a pain in the rear was running out of Oxygen, unless you play the Robot. But you eventually do get used to it. The jumping and fighting in low-gravity almost made up for the pain in the♥♥♥♥♥of running out of air. Grab the Baroness if you were a fan of the Sirens, you won't be dissapointed. I miss my midget!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Only buy if you are a diehard fan of the series and have friends to play it with. For me playing this game has been a drag. Gameplay and mechanics are the same as BL2 and that doesn't bother me - BL2 gameplay was solid enough that it carries well into this game. But the pace, game length, loot system, and in general what was promised to us just didn't deliver. The Pre-Sequel has moved far and away from the space-western that was the first game and just feels smaller than the previous two games. BL2 was 25~ chapters compared to the Pre-Sequel of 17~. The majority of sidemissions are some variety of fetch quests. The new moon cast is largely fogetable, and there is the 'apperance' of Marcus (what, you couldn't come up with an alternate moon arms dealer?). The attempt to spice up the combat in the Pre-Sequel was done lazily - adding more bandits and monsters to fight doesn't change that the AI is terrible and predictable (the flow of combat came to the point where I could predict which cover the enemy would lock into and which side they would pop out of). Character dialogue is increased but its not streets ahead of BL2. An unimaginative end game raid boss. The list goes on. But my main gripe now comes with the latest DLC, Lady Hammerlock. Bear in mind its not her as a character I object to, its the fact that the 3rd DLC is another character class. Track time, the first 3 DLC for each game: BL1: Docter Ned's Zombie Island (expansion), Secret Armory of General Knoxx (expansion) Miss Moxxi's Arena (arena)BL2: Mechromancer (character) Captain Scarlett and the pirates booty (expansion) Mr. Torgues Campaign of Carnage (expansion)BL TPS: Handsome Jack (character) holodome Onsalught (arena) Lady Hammerlock (character)Three DLC's in and the game hasn't gotten bigger, just the cast of characters. The only thing I can guess that the Pre-Sequel did right is make the loot system not force you to keep swapping new guns every single level, allowing you to enjoy a gun for a handful of levels at least. It just feels as if the Pre-Sequel was handed off to a less capable team - sure they tried their best but their best wasn't good enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I gave it a shot and wasn't all that impressed with it. If there were better DLC's and a more of a storyline other than watching the downward spiral of a character who was from the start, a jerk (I'm being kind here) I would have enjoyed it more.  I was excited for this game at first. After two full playthroughs and testing some of the other new characters out, I had this feeling inside that wanted something bigger for all the hype I had read about. Pros:I did like the new laser weapons and the butt-slam ability, it was different. I often found myself trying to butt-slam in BL1 and BL2 and facepalming later. The playable characters were a bit of a surprise. Most of my playtime was with Athena however. Cons: Austrailian humor? Yeah sorry folks, a lot of the stereo-typed voice acting/jokes were a total turn off.Didn't really need a backstory to a character that I didn't particulary care for to begin with in BL2.So it's totally okay for one character to just completely forget about part of their past in one game..then in this one they are demonized terribly and everyone seems to hate them now? Huge failure on the writing team. Good job making your storyline sound like it came from a bad fanfiction site. Bottom line: I wanted to enjoy this game, I really did, I've recently un-installed and tried to forget about it. If there is going to be a BL3..I'm going to be wary of it after this fustercluck. I've seen too many other reviewers saying they are jumping ship on the BL fandom. They need to bring back the writing styles of the BL1 team and get rid of that Burch guy! He's a t-w-a-t. If you're still wanting to pick up this game, wait until there is better content and when it's on sale for like $25 or so, as it stands right now, it really is not a 60 dollar game, way too short, poor content and it left an ache in my already dark husk of a heart.

												I am making a positive review for the game but keep in mind the price does not represent the game in this review, as you should try to pick it up on sales. The Pre-Sequel runs the same as Borderlands 2 but with different characters, some new weapons, and well... you're in space. I love this game but I agree with most reviews that there are quite a bit of problems with the game such as the lack of the iconic boss grinding for legendary loot that we all love in Borderlands as a franchise. It does have its own plusses though as it stays true to the series in its humor and its gameplay. If you were looking at buying this game as your first Borderlands though or have not gotten Borderlands 2- turn around and buy BL2. It is better than the Pre-Sequel and has a lot more worthwhile side quests to do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												So, after playing absolutely tons of Borderlands 2, I was hopeful this was going to equal or exceed it - unfortunately, it did neither, falling far short of both. The humour seemed a little off and I never laughed out loud once. The missions also seemed to keep taking me back to the same area time and time again - at one point you go through a level, to get to another level, to complete an optional mission and then come all the way back again, only to get given another mission for the same place. Poor design? Maybe. Overall though, my biggest gripe with the game is what it has done to a couple of the well established goodly characters who at one point stand by and watch four peeps get murdered with barely a moan. A little consideration of canon and those same characters could have simply left the room first. But hey, it's Borderlands and does some stuff right. Lasers are cool, but roll on Borderlands 3. This one just feels like a wonky wheel. It gets you there but it isn't as fun a ride.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												After 2 playthroughs as Athena and now playing as Nisha, with 50+ hours in the game I'm finally ready to give the Pre-Sequel a positive review. I'm a huge Borderlands fan; BL 1 - Finished the GOTY edition multiple times on PC, PS3 & XBox, BL2 - 300+ hours spent mainly as Maya having purchased every conceivable peice of DLC available (yes even the headhunter packs). Therefore I had high expectations of the third entry in the franchise.Upon first viewing it really does present as a re-skin of BL2, or as many have suggested, simply a substantial add on pack. The difference between BL2 and Pre-Sequel were nothing compared to the leap we saw in from first game to it's arguably superior sequel. As you progress through the campaign however, the apparent minor changes actually serve to present quite a different style of game. The low gravity combat and slower player movement is a huge change that drastically alters the pace of the gameplay, at least it feels like it does to players familiar with BL2 speed. Combine this with the unecessary O2 game mechanic and the initial impression is that 2K Australia took a wrong turn. However, after persisting with this change I found it simply meant that I had to approach the game from a different angle and as soon as I stopped trying to play in the style of BL2 or even BL 1, I began to have a lot more fun. This is quite a different beast and the comments that it's too similar to the previous game are actually incorrect. It's vastly different in gameplay. The space setting on Elpis is a big change from the deserts of Pandora. The Australian accents play a big part in making this feel like a completely seperate environment. The new weapon and elemental types are a welcome addition that most people cited as a positive. The story, while not quite as engaging as BL2 is still interesting especially for people who've been invested in the universe from the beginning. The playable characters and their respective skills are arguably the most interesting and varied we've seen in the series and for the first time I feel a desire to try them all out. Overall, this is different than expected though utlimatley another satisfying entry to the franchise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Although I used to adore this series, I've recently become somewhat disenchanted with it. I'm finding all of the combat a bit "samey" and the level design all too predictable. The humour is still great, don't get me wrong. I've spent more than my fair share of time roaming Pandora in Borderlands 2, and the commentary given still earns a chuckle out of me from time to time.I think the biggest issue I have with the series is the first game. Not because it was bad, but because it was good. It was original. It was new, fun, exciting. I dare say there was nothing quite like it on the market when it came out. Borderlands 2 fixed some of the very infrequent issues with the first title, such as melee being obsolete past a certain level threshold. Borderlands 2 was still a great game, and I'll always look back fondly.When the Pre-Sequel was announced, a friend and I went nuts fangirling over it. We screamed about moon physics and CL4-TP being a playable character for hours on end. I, of course, pre-ordered it. I was so excited for its release, just around the two month bend.And when it came out, and I started playing it, it felt familiar. Too familiar. It felt identical to Borderlands 2. I tried to push that thought away and enjoy myself but there was the constant nag in the back of my head. The very same nag of Saint's Row IV. Whilst I played at least a hundred hours of the first Borderlands, and an ungodly amount more of the second, this installment left me feeling like I was at a Skag-steak dinner, and I'd over eaten with my numerous servings of Borderlands, and I didn't want anymore, but it would be impolite to my host if I didn't finish what sat on my oversized plate.I feel like I'm betraying myself, but here I am, not recommending this game.

												Overall: 6.6/10In its current state, I'd reccomend you buy Borderlands 2 instead. The game is nearly identical to the previous (Same guns, same mechanics with a few minor new ones added on (O2 for example)), but it just doesn't have the amount of content to justify its price tag. The game is a fair bit shorter than BL2, and the DLC is nowhere near the quality of the previous game. There will supposedly be a 5+ GB story DLC being added fairly soon, but I am not sure that will convince me to reccomend this. In the first 30 minutes of Borderlands 2, I was hooked on the game, but for The Presequel, it just wasn't the same.Also, if you don't like or understand Austrailian humor, a lot of things in the game will go over your head. 2K Austrailia poured a lot of it into this game, and a lot of the voice actors have Austrailian accents. I had no problem with this (even though a few jokes went over my head), but if you have an irrational hate for Austrailians, you might want to pass on this.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I gave it a shot and wasn't all that impressed with it. If there were better DLC's and a more of a storyline other than watching the downward spiral of a character who was from the start, a jerk (I'm being kind here) I would have enjoyed it more.  I was excited for this game at first. After two full playthroughs and testing some of the other new characters out, I had this feeling inside that wanted something bigger for all the hype I had read about. Pros:I did like the new laser weapons and the butt-slam ability, it was different. I often found myself trying to butt-slam in BL1 and BL2 and facepalming later. The playable characters were a bit of a surprise. Most of my playtime was with Athena however. Cons: Austrailian humor? Yeah sorry folks, a lot of the stereo-typed voice acting/jokes were a total turn off.Didn't really need a backstory to a character that I didn't particulary care for to begin with in BL2.So it's totally okay for one character to just completely forget about part of their past in one game..then in this one they are demonized terribly and everyone seems to hate them now? Huge failure on the writing team. Good job making your storyline sound like it came from a bad fanfiction site. Bottom line: I wanted to enjoy this game, I really did, I've recently un-installed and tried to forget about it. If there is going to be a BL3..I'm going to be wary of it after this fustercluck. I've seen too many other reviewers saying they are jumping ship on the BL fandom. They need to bring back the writing styles of the BL1 team and get rid of that Burch guy! He's a t-w-a-t. If you're still wanting to pick up this game, wait until there is better content and when it's on sale for like $25 or so, as it stands right now, it really is not a 60 dollar game, way too short, poor content and it left an ache in my already dark husk of a heart.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Where to start...I'll go through my pro's: Fart blasting people Cryo weapons were amazing The game is more fun with a pack of friends than solo Grenades, Torgue, the usual Playing Claptrap was actually hilariousI love the Borderlands series... wholeheartedly adore it. Mordecai was my favourite hero in the existence of RPGs. Then came Borderlands 2, where I fell in love with the Mechromancer and Axton. Now, I pre-ordered this game with the same kind of childhood glee you'd have seen back when Pokemon first came to Gameboy. I started off as Wilhelm, I enjoyed it, I also played around with some Claptrap . I found the stereotypical Bogan voices quite grating, but that's probably because I'm Australian and deal with enough Derro people day-day. I made it through the whole playthrough, and tried to rerun it, but found I couldn't physically bring myself to completing another playthrough. It may have been the quests, it may have been the zones, it may have been the bosses, or it may have simply been the terrible scripting (some of the jokes were great, but nothing like the hilariousness that came from BL1/2).I found it pretty evident that the game itself wasn't really made for the community that so enjoyed the first two titles, but more for a bone thrown to the Australian devs in 2k. I'll finish by stating this the game is great for a time, but it's hard to get the motivation to play through each of the heroes you may be interested in without having your ears bleed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I personally found this game more enjoyable then Borderlands 2, and I put several hundred hours into that verison. While I feel that the replay value on this is a lot less, it's still too early to tell with the DLC coming if it will be more enjoyable. But in my opinion I feel as if the new features add a to the series and leave me with great hope IF a Borderlands 3 shows up! I thought the ice element was a great touch, and adds new level of combat with freezing and using explosive weapons to shatter. I personally am glad that the Eridian weapons are gone, because they were always the best and without then it adds the balance of weapons back from Borderlands 1. The Oxygen feature can be troublesome at first, but later on in the game you will find it doesn't play that much of a factor, and you can get some nice stat boost from the O2 kits themselves. Overall, if you are on the fence about getting the game I feel that I got my moneys worth, but I will add back to this with further assessments from the DLC to see how it changes things.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Really addictive game.Having played the first two games on console, I can't say this is the game I enjoyed most. But it is still tons of fun.Pros-collecting 10000000000+ different weapons (slightly exaggerated)-fun multiplayer mode-fun dialogues-it is a sand box that isn't empty-a lot of side missions to do-personally I think all the achievements are achievable and relatively easy(??)-jump pack. Yeah! everyone's favouritebut when you think about it...cons(as in the previous games)-weapons aren't 'unique' which means you constantly have to get rid of your old weapons for new ones because the dmg that a weapon causes depends on the level of your character when you pick it up, so any guns you collected before lvl70 will need to be thrown away somehow-grinder, yes grinder, where you combine three guns or shield or whatever together to forge a new thing. Totally depending on luck.-multiplayer seems to be a race of who's gonna grap the better guns first-did I mention a thing called the shift code? You can find a lot of it online- basically it allows you to open a chest and grap a better item, so what's the point of collecting weapons from enemies? (given that you haven't reached the highest level)In conclusion, it is definitely worth trying if you have plenty of time to spare.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												It's fun, but it's not Borderlands 2. Don't expect this to be as good as Borderlands 2...It's a good game, just not a great game. I guess one of its main flaws is that its predecessor was a masterpiece.The story is pretty bad for almost the entire game, but the ending makes up for it tho.The level design is bad... like pretty bad... you might get pretty mad sometimes.Vehicles are still buggy. Terrible and unimportant bosses in the game, with the exclusion of the last boss fight(s). Loot is pretty bad, but they made a new system: you get a GRINDER in which you combine 3 weapons (of the same quality) to get a better weapon.The classes are very fun, it really feels like they invested a lot of time in developing their action skills and talents.I'm afraid the characters don't have as much personality as the main characters did in the previous games.I played the first Borderlands game for about 150 hours (PS3+PC), Borderlands 2 for about 260 hours (PC), I like this game series a lot, but I was as bit disappointed by BL:TPS.7.0 - Play it if you enjoy the Borderlands universe and story. It could've been better, feels like they rushed the production...

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												If you like Borderlands 2, This game is for you.It has some improvement since Borderlands 2, that is, there is no slag.In previous game, Slag was a elemental effect.When enemy is under the effect of slag, the damage to that slagged enemy is increased.It was powerful, that was the problem. Under the presence of powerful slag, game was balanced for that.The result, enemy's HP is so high which makes using slag almost mandatory.Slag was powerful, but using the slag wasn't that fun.You equip a weak damage but slag weapon just for slagging enemies,then switch to high damage weapons to finish it off.Borderlands has only 4 weapon shortcut slot, and switching weapons takes some times makes using slag stressful. Since there is no slag in TPS, enemy's health is lower than B2.The only things I don't like in TPS are just 4 weapon slots and switching weapons takes times.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												This game, unfortunately, is markedly inferior to Borderlands 1 and 2.  Despite using pretty much the same game engine and recycling much of the assets from Borderlands 2, the design of the enemies and levels just aren't at the same level of quality.  The combat rarely rewards careful tactics, instead often degenerating into disorderly brawls - not that this didn't exist in Borderlands 2, but in that game it was usually your choice how to engage the enemies.  Frequently, enemies don't spawn until you're in the middle of a room, then they spawn all around you, and the cover would be ineffective.  Maps are often confusing and lacking in distinctive landmarks.  Boss fights often take place in arenas that are awkward to maneouver or just entirely devoid of cover, again rapidly degenerating into clumsy brawls.  The story is irritating - you work for Handsome Jack, and he's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ - but that is more or less constrained by the story laid down in Borderland 1 and 2.  The humour is, well, Australian.  If you like it, you like it.  If you don't, it'll annoy you.  The one redeeming quality is the final boss fight, which is the only part of the game that, for me, felt like the quality I expect from a Borderlands game - the one part of the game that received the care and polish deserving of the Borderlands franchise.  Basically, what I'm trying to say is, go play Borderlands 2 instead.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Overall a really great game, especially since it was meant as filler to satisfy fans until Borderlands 3.The new mechanics in this game are done very smoothly, low gravity in general is just super fun. Cryo weapons have become a favourite of mine as well, and just feels satisfying. It really feels like the developers just had a lot of fun making that, which transfers so well into how fun the game itself is. The playable characters actually have dialogue with the NPC's now, which made the experience a whooooole lot better.Unfortunately though, this game is EXTREMELY buggy. Some of the bugs are hilarious, but many are just frustrating. For example, when you get slowed due to an enemy cryo weapon or something in the environment, there is a chance you will stay slowed until you quit to the main menu. I've also experienced several issues with the Fight For Your Life system, which makes playing on your own a serious pain.I still reccommend this game, even with all the bugs theres just so much fun to be had.

												Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, on a first time completion, is near brilliant in my terms.The comedy may be lacking compared to the other games, and it may be too heavily pushing the Australian accent thing.But in all honesty, I thoroughly enjoyed the game.The one thing that makes this game brilliant, is that it's a connector. A game in which many questions are answered, a game in which makes you think and look at the other games and go "Wait, is that guy from this game? Did this lead to that? Oh, that's why that happened." And so forth.And the lasers, oh my sweet jesus. I freaking love lasers.My overall opinion would give it an 8/10 for it's storyline and how it incorporates itself into the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												The Pre Sequel is the game between borderlands one and two. It changes what the definition of a borderlands game can be. This game was over-priced in my opinion, but it was still a lot of fun. I loved the Claptastic Voyage, but the holodome played like it was just slopped together in a short amount of time. In the past, a borderlands DLC has had more success when not outsourced and made in-house. I really like the moon background and art design. The characters have a lot more mobility options than previous games. Sadly, to this day, lots of main bosses are not farmable. I do not find this very smart because in the past the games have thrived on the mechanic that you can farm for loot out of bosses. Between the characters and the feel of the game, I certainly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Of course the game does not live up to Borderlands 2, but once you create such a game like that it is impossible to live up to the hype created by the predecessor. Admittably, the homey borderlands nostalgia does not strike as much as the second addition, the world feels a bit lacking, and a first playthrough left me feeling slightly offput. However after coming back to the game, i found myself quite happily playing through all over again.  To anyone who has played Borderlands 1 or 2, i strongly reccomend this game to you. Although it is a bit lacking in charisma, the gameplay is fabulous, and the enviroment is one of a kind.Pros:                                      Cons:-Gameplay is superb             -lacking in humor, and nostalgia-Wonderful enviornment      -Not enough content-Valuable storyline               -Bland NPC dialogue-Unique expirience               -Not much good DLC produced-polished features from bl2Regardless of whether it seems like a let down, it is an enjoyable playthrough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												This game, unfortunately, is markedly inferior to Borderlands 1 and 2.  Despite using pretty much the same game engine and recycling much of the assets from Borderlands 2, the design of the enemies and levels just aren't at the same level of quality.  The combat rarely rewards careful tactics, instead often degenerating into disorderly brawls - not that this didn't exist in Borderlands 2, but in that game it was usually your choice how to engage the enemies.  Frequently, enemies don't spawn until you're in the middle of a room, then they spawn all around you, and the cover would be ineffective.  Maps are often confusing and lacking in distinctive landmarks.  Boss fights often take place in arenas that are awkward to maneouver or just entirely devoid of cover, again rapidly degenerating into clumsy brawls.  The story is irritating - you work for Handsome Jack, and he's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ - but that is more or less constrained by the story laid down in Borderland 1 and 2.  The humour is, well, Australian.  If you like it, you like it.  If you don't, it'll annoy you.  The one redeeming quality is the final boss fight, which is the only part of the game that, for me, felt like the quality I expect from a Borderlands game - the one part of the game that received the care and polish deserving of the Borderlands franchise.  Basically, what I'm trying to say is, go play Borderlands 2 instead.

												I like Borderlands more as a franchise than this game in particular. The style and playstyle are fun and captivating. That being said, this is almost exactly the same game as borderlands 2. WHich if thats what you're looking for it is great, but if you are hoping for something different or changes to features you will be disappointed. The changes are minor yet clunky. The gravity thing is awkward and is not a part of the game when it would be most useful. Lasers replace slag weapons in a way, but still have unique elemental effects. I mainly got this because I lost borderlands 2 and didn't want to rebuy the same game so it works in that regard. I'm hoping the play style will flow better once my steam controller shows up and I can play it on my big ole TV

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												When Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel first came out it has scored quite a number of negative reviews along with 7/10 on metacritic. Whereas BL2 is almost 9/10. I have picked it up a few month after the initial release at 55% discount for TPS + Season Pass edition... and after playing a few hours simply abandoned it for almost half a year. Why? I was bored out of my brains by the first two-three chapters. To be honest, this game should have been named 'Borderlands 2: The Pre Sequel', because yes it's a ♥♥♥♥ing DLC. A pretty good one though, but dlc nonetheless and playing it right after spending almost 200 hours in Borderlands 2 was too much.Yet now, six month later, I'm on my second playthrough. It's also worth mentioning that the pre-sequel feels slightly more difficult to play solo than the sequel. After all I'm pretty happy with it and highly recommend it to everyone who enjoyed other Borderlands games, but I'd suggest picking it up during a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												I can reccomend this game with a lot of asterisks on the end and only to specific people. Also let me start out this review by saying that this game isn't worth 60$ +30$ for DLC, even if you really liked BL2 this game is not worth the full asking price and this reccomendation is based solely on the prospect that you buy this game on sale for 30$ or less.Lets start with the negatives here because for some people(roughly half of the people who saw my BL2 review) this is what they'll care about.The first is that Vehicle handling is TERRIBLE and in the game you'll be on them a lot. Jumps just plain don't work half the time and as best I can tell its random wether they sent you where you want to go or into an instant death pit. I cannot stress how terrible the vehicles are.This game is VERY CLEARLY an expansion pack thats been stretched out into a full game and it shows, my god does it show. The writing is there but so is the padding, fetch quests abound. If you're looking of a repeat of BL2's story, just no. NO.Some people may say Handsome Jack has been... comprimized and let down from his fantastic role in BL2.Most of the legendary guns in the game are brought over from BL2, again expansion pack stretched into a full game.Talent trees are more restricted than they were in BL2, more similar to the Mechromancer Anarchy skill tree in that there are more things that you HAVE to spec into to progress.Clap Trap is a playable character in the game, if you have a friend that doesn't like you rest assured they'll play him.Now let me get into the things I liked about this game:Somebody thought to balance the guns here, so reload times are better overall and assault rifles with minigun barrel attachments will actually get up to a decent firing rate before you have to reload them. In addition it feels like more guns are viable than they were in BL2 and if you ran around using whatever you pick up off the ground you won't find yourself getting your face mashed into the dirt.Vending machines scale to your level and can actually have decent loot in them once again. So money actually has a point in the game and if nothing interesting drops you can still pop in at a vending machine and pick up an interesting gun or two.The loot is better than in BL2 and I felt like I was picking up enough useful new guns to keep me looking for more, however the economy seems to revolve more around selling guns than picking up money so I would reccomend picking up backpack upgrades early.The lasers are cool and have a good amount of vareity to them: Beam, Railgun, Shotgun, Automatic and I think they add a lot of variety to the game and add more elemental weapons outside of just Maliwan and Torgue.The oxygen Mechanic feels well thought out and effects not only you but your enemies as well, combined with the low gravity jumps and butt stomping the movement in BLP is very satisfying and flows. You can also get an OZ kit that lets you jump around and fire more accurately while jumping around.I think Cryo damage adds to the game a lot more than Slag did to BL2. Slag just felt like a numerical bonus that you were punished for not using and Cryo just feels like its own thing. In addition if you freeze an enemy mid air with cryo they can drop to the ground and shatter.The special abilities in BLP feel... weak? however you can use them a lot more often than in BL2 and I feel like I'm getting more use out of them since they recharge so quickly.So overall I feel like BLP is an overpriced expansion pack for BL2 that improves on gameplay in a number of significant ways but may try your patience if you're here for more story by sending you around for too many fetch quests. So if you're in it for the loot Diablo style I'd wait for at least a 50% off sale and pick it up, if you're in it for the story I'd wait for at least 75%.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Now, I have to make something clear. You really get the most out of this game if you have played Borderlands 1, General Knoxx DLC, Robot Uprising DLC and Borderlands 2 GOTY. In a way, this is a fan service game. It's filled with jokes and characters that you can really only understand if you are a fan of the series.I played this for  the story, and frankly, it's great. Even though the game takes place before Borderlands 2, it's told in a way that it still kinda extends the story forward. There are, of course a lot of fan favourite characters, as well as few new ones. The new "replacement" for Scooter, Janey Springs is probably the one you interact with the most and I have to say, she is one of the best written characters in the series. Overall, the writing is fantastic, funny and fits the universe perfectly.The gameplay, however, has a few problems. The zero g combat is fun, lasers are fun, oz-kits are fun. Actually, all the new additions are simply great. Even though the game is still basically an extension of Borderlands 2, it's fun and works very smoothly. There is this sort of flow, which makes the game feel weirdly serene. The problem is not really in the new additions, it's in the pacing.There is a lot of running around. Some of the side quests are quite boring and require you to use hours and hours just travelling back into places you've already been numerous times. Now, this is a problem only if you are a completionist like me, and you want to do every single quest in the right order. If you just care about the story and the gameplay, it's gonna be no problem, but I felt really frustrated in the final few hours, when the game spammed long♥♥♥♥♥side quests, when the story started to get intense.But that aside, I found Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel an enjoyable RPG Shooter that really expands the Borderlands IP well. The game gives a background and answers for a lot of questions from the first two games. A must have for a fan of the series. If you are new? You should play the previous games first.

												I think this is the best borderlands yet. the Oz kits are awsome, the actoin skills are better in this game than Bl2, (in my opinon,) the laser wepons are one of the best new things in the franchise. the only two problems are that there isn't really a endgame, where borderlands 2 had a great endgame with alot of raid bosses to farm. But that really is not a problem with casual players who play one run of this game. Another new thing they added was a element named,"Cryo". in this game, it replace's borderlands 2's,"Slag" element. In my opinon, this a alot better than slag because cryo will freeze enemies in place, making them take more critical hit damage. That all the info I got. I give this a 10/10. the problems are few and far between. It would be nice they would add more Raid bosses thou.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												It's fun, but it's not Borderlands 2. Don't expect this to be as good as Borderlands 2...It's a good game, just not a great game. I guess one of its main flaws is that its predecessor was a masterpiece.The story is pretty bad for almost the entire game, but the ending makes up for it tho.The level design is bad... like pretty bad... you might get pretty mad sometimes.Vehicles are still buggy. Terrible and unimportant bosses in the game, with the exclusion of the last boss fight(s). Loot is pretty bad, but they made a new system: you get a GRINDER in which you combine 3 weapons (of the same quality) to get a better weapon.The classes are very fun, it really feels like they invested a lot of time in developing their action skills and talents.I'm afraid the characters don't have as much personality as the main characters did in the previous games.I played the first Borderlands game for about 150 hours (PS3+PC), Borderlands 2 for about 260 hours (PC), I like this game series a lot, but I was as bit disappointed by BL:TPS.7.0 - Play it if you enjoy the Borderlands universe and story. It could've been better, feels like they rushed the production...

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Overall a really great game, especially since it was meant as filler to satisfy fans until Borderlands 3.The new mechanics in this game are done very smoothly, low gravity in general is just super fun. Cryo weapons have become a favourite of mine as well, and just feels satisfying. It really feels like the developers just had a lot of fun making that, which transfers so well into how fun the game itself is. The playable characters actually have dialogue with the NPC's now, which made the experience a whooooole lot better.Unfortunately though, this game is EXTREMELY buggy. Some of the bugs are hilarious, but many are just frustrating. For example, when you get slowed due to an enemy cryo weapon or something in the environment, there is a chance you will stay slowed until you quit to the main menu. I've also experienced several issues with the Fight For Your Life system, which makes playing on your own a serious pain.I still reccommend this game, even with all the bugs theres just so much fun to be had.
