Posted: December 19, 2014
												Butt slam your way across the moon of Pandora, Elpis! Some of the franchises most beloved characters return as NPC's and a NPC from a DLC of the first game is now playable. And the most galvinizing (I made a funny!) NPC of all is now playable: Claptrap! Whether you love him or love to hate him he's the most recognizable character in the series. If you like the prior games you'll love Borderlands: TPS. It keeps most of the same formula but adds just enough new things to keep it interesting.This also is 2K and Gearbox's first game to see simultaneous cross platform release. The PS3, Xbox, Mac, Windows, and Linux versions all released at the same time. Pity I have but one thumbs up to give this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												The third game in the Borderlands series and still going strong!  Only 1/2 the length of Borderlands 2, but a worthy game nonetheless.  Still maintaining its top notch voice acting dialog and gameplay.  Not much has changed graphically from Borderlands 2, but the game still looks fantastic.  The main difference in The Pre-Sequel is it takes place solely in space and you'll have to worry about oxygen as a life resource.  Having oxygen does hinder you somewhat.  Especially in long drawn out fights or just exploring.  You'll find your oxygen tanks low or just on the brink of empty a lot of the time, but there are quite a few oxygen hubs located throughout the entire game. Everything you loved about the previous Borderlands games is here including multiple characters to choose from, skill trees, transportation vehicles and of course the ever loving witty dialog!  Having only spawning 1 story driven DLC this time around the game doesn't offer as much as Borderlands 2, but if you're a fan of the series it's a must play.  New lazers, space ground stomps, ice grenades and so much more kept this game going strong until the end.  And ohhh boy.. the ending boss was great.  Good fun!  Recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Borderlands: The Pre Sequel is definitely a fun experience. Overall, the game is well made and I really can't stress how entertaining it is. But, is it worth the price tag? The blunt answer is no. Luckily I did not pay full price and got it bundled with the season pass for $20. $20-30 is the most this game should've asked for. While it has quality content there isn't much. The story itself takes maybe 15 hours at most. The world is much smaller, the story is shorter, less sidemissions and fewer interesting personalties than in Borderlands 2. The vertical leveling was also quite annoying and made finding your way around or find missions or mission objectives a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥The story is pretty solid, with some entertaining bit sprinkled in and a few returning faces. The huge problem I had with the story was I didn't have any sense of urgency. In BL2 you feel this urge to defeat that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Handsome Jack who is threatening Pandora. In BLPS you can't really get that connection to any of the "villains". Zarpedon is the closest you get to that and she really isn't an intrecate part of the story. You might hear her shout something to her soldiers like "Blow this up!" or "Stop him!" but that's where it ends. Some of the plot is really confusing too. Why are we following Athena's point of view when you're not playing Athena? Even in multiplayer it will show Athena in cutscenes and not the entire group.The characters were okay. Janey Springs was well done, so was The Meriff, of course Crazy Earl and that little kid I can't really remember. I've heard a lot of people complain about Janey and they're usually sad sap loonies. There weren't an awful lot of characters and none of them really have anything terribly intresting about them unlike the ones from BL2 we all loved. The player characters were excently done though, and interact with Jack and other NPCs differently and actually talk. I thought the different abilities were pretty nice, escpecially the DLC ones. Enemies on the other hand weren't done so well. The scavs and lunitics really aren't as good as their raider and pyscho counterparts. They never really say anything intresting or have much variation other than charcter models. Other than that, the UI is basically the same, there's moonstones (which is basically eridium), laser weapons which are pretty cool, Australian accents everywhere, butt slamming, cyro weapons and Mad Moxxi.Don't buy on full price, wait for a sale and you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I'm going to be disgustingly critical with this game, in only the best effort to sound and thorough.  Compared to BL2, this game is akin to that of another DLC. It's ridiculously short, story wise. and everything else wise. I can load up BL2 and find things that are totally new to me, while in this, nothing is new. After about 4-5 hours one can effectively complete every single quest in the game, and take out the "hidden" bosses with relative ease. Honestly, the only reason I actually load up this game anymore is because of the new "Claptastic Voyage" DLC, which I'll get into in a second.  The humour, has been utterly destroyed. Honestly, the only thing that remotely makes me laugh at this game anymore is when Racist Hot Dog appears. That's about it. The story itself is pretty meh. You arrive, and just as quickly, you leave. Sudden surprise enemy "oh no gotta kill that ♥♥♥♥♥ with no backstory!!!!1111!" is the quickest trope. (I mean, yes there are scattered Echo logs about Zarpedon, but they don't reveal who she is or her background, only that she works for Dahl, and that she used to operate the ship that the Bosun has now taken over.) You then find Janey Springs who is a homosexual. She helps the character throughout. She is also a homosexual. She resides in Concordia with her own shop. Did I mention she was a homosexual? This is honestly how her character feels to have been introduced. Flatly, she's a flat homosexual, who's only real character trait, is that she is a homosexual. You meet the Merrif, who spoiler alert, is a traitor!!!111!!11 ZOMGNOWAI?! What a curveball! Then, the defining moment in whether or not I believe this is a good story or not, you meet Felicity. Poor ♥♥♥♥in' Felicity, man. If I ever met a character that didn't deserve what happened to them, it is Felicity. Felicity, who in an actual decent curveball, turns out to be an AI unit, who runs the Drakensburg, and who also ran it when Zarpedon was in control. She has a very fond dislike for killing, and all she wants is to be copied. That's apparently too much to ask. Poor Felicity, my god did you not deserve that. No one does. That is why this story does not sit right with me. Borderlands is a roughly light-hearted game. That, and for lack of better words, is describable only as "entirely ♥♥♥♥ed up." It doesn't belong in a Borderlands-esque setting. I mean, "yeah we're trying to prove that jack is ♥♥♥♥ed up here blah blah blah" but Jesus christ that wasn't necessary. Killing Gladstone and his buddies were more than enough to prove that point, but honestly that may just be me. Though, they did manage to kill off the only character with any sort of depth whatsoever. Speaking of Gladstone, you're then tasked to help in the manufacturing of the first "constructor", or murdered Felicity. You're sent on a quest to do the single most annoying thing on the planet, and that, is to damage multiple enemies without them dying. Overleveled? ♥♥♥♥ you. Powerful weapons? ♥♥♥♥ you. That's honestly how this quest feels. In an effort to ditch this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ quest, I managed to break one of my saves. Gr8. The game ends with you storming Helios and taking it back and blah blah blah generic plot♥♥♥♥♥♥ Also, Moxxi tries to kill you. That twist is commendable, though virulently hinted at through the last couple segments. It's also hilariously obvious if you have any sort of technological knowledge at all. BUT!!!!!11111!!11 because there needs to be a raid boss, theres an open vault and you go and kill the big scary monster and Jack sees the vault thingy and gets his face burned and blah blah blah. THE END! Honestly, it's a 7/10 story. Better than what most major companies make nowadays. The graphics are the same, which sits pretty with me. Borderlands is a sobel shaded game, and it's pretty cool what they manage with it. The weapons are one of the highlights. Now, I can use my favorites from 2 again. You want new ones? Nah, ♥♥♥♥ that. LASERS!!!!!! Which, is a cool addition, just lazy if you're going to not add new weapons.  DLC!Why, oh why, did the Devs decide, "YOU KNOW WHAT WOULD BE GREAT? MORE VAULT HUNTERS! YOU'RE SAYING THE GAME LACKS CONTENT? MORE CHARACTERS!" I mean, yeah they're cool and all but they have no depth. Timothy has slight depth but other than that they're all as flat as a board. Aurelia is shunned by Hammerlock because she kills things. How sad. She's rich though. The skillsets for these characters are nice though, and I don't have much to bicker at. I have to say that Aurelia is a really well done sniper class, though I may be biased because she's what I main. Speaking of the vault hunters... they're all great. But, yet again, lack of development hinders them greatly. The continuity is nice, with them all being some part of BL2, but other than that, eh. Claptrap has character, only because he's been in all three games thus far. Claptastic Voyage. Something that FEELS like Borderlands. FINALLY. I honestly have nothing really to gripe about except for one thing: That last boss fight is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Fix that♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Let me start by saying this: If Steam had an "on the fence" option for reviewing games, then I'd pick it for Borderlands: The Pre-sequel. Unfortunately, it does not. I'll list what's good about it first:-I'd be willing to try out most the characters, since they have a good design and cool abilities (accept one, which even the game itself shuns time and time again.)-The new combat mechanics added for zero gravity handle well and are enjoyable to use-Laser weapons are effective and enjoyable to use-Shops have rares for sale on a regular basis through their timed deals-You can combine three weapons of the same rarity into a new weapon with the same rarity or higher, and you can choose to add in moonstones (the game's special currency) for a special buff and finish on it.-The new cryo element is awesome-The new vehicles are great and handle wellOk... *deep breath* now the bad stuff:-Most (if not all) of the dialogue could've been written by a typical teenager-Characters like to move as little muscle as possible during cutscenes, and have mastered the art of speaking without the movement of lips-I encountered a glitch where I was permantly slowed, and the only way to fix it was to restart the game. It doesn't sound too bad, but...-Points where you can respawn are stupidly scarce. There are checkpoints, but you can't teleport to them... If you need to quit for whatever reason, you've got a lot of walking to do. (Enormous waste of time)-Most enemies are re-skinned enemies from Borderlands 2 with the complete lack of funny quotes. -They pulled the menu system straight from BL2 without fixing the infamous "scroll glitch"-The map is still lacking a Z-axis, making navigation to different altitudes long and frustrating-I've passed through multiple solid objects, and fallen through the map, killing me. (Which means more walking!)-Leveling up still takes forever-Quests=running a lot-It's basically overpriced DLC if it isn't on sale. So if you actually bothered to read this far, thanks. If you still want to get this game, buy it at 75% off and have some friends to play with.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I have never. EVER. Been more dissappointed in a sequel. This is the laziest, cashgrabbing, mess of a game I have in my library. I think I can safely say I'm never buying a game from 2k australia again. If this wasn't made in part by gearbox I would call them thieves as well as lazy. Borderlands 2 was a wonderful sequal. It had new everything. UI, weapon designs, weapon sound effects (a big thing for me), hud, brand names, level designs and best of all nearly every enemy character is voiced by an entirely new cast, who just so happen to be the same voice actors that did DBZ. I lost my♥♥♥♥♥♥when I heard Mr Satans voice for the first time (mr torgue). Lost it even harder when he announced he was holding a tournament. This game has none of that. The moon environments are all white and bland, the hyperion city is Opportunity stuck in permanant dusk, the extremely hyped laser weapons are almost always worse than conventional bullets and to top it all off the most prominantly advertized feature: the "huge" amount of your characters ingame dialog is almost nonexistant. If your lucky you might get a voice clip once per mission and that gets rarer and rarer as the game goes on. Remember how the quotes your character makes whenever they get a crit kill would get annoying after a while? Well 2k aus seemed to look at this problem and say "I know what would make this better: if the character said something stupid every single time they get a crit, that won't make headshots annoying at all!"Please dont get this game. The dlc is considered to be the worst in the series and is shamelessly promoted ingame. The season pass gets you access to something that was given away for free to the GOTY edition of BL2, there are only 7 different enemy types and 2 of them are just copied from BL2. Please, PLEASE, just save your money and buy borderlands 2, its so much better and has so much more to offer. Dont encourage this kind of lazy, bland, greedy game design.EDIT:  "The game that killed its makers" 2k aus is dead and everyone that bought the season pass has lost out on about 70% of the content they were promised. 2k australia is dead: no relocation to another city/ country, no giving its employees jobs in other departments, no refunds for the people who trusted in them to un♥♥♥♥ this horrid, lazy mess of a game. Its just stone cold dead. And now with the dissapointment that is Battleborn gearbox is looking kinda ♥♥♥♥ed. This might just go down as the beginning of the end for one of the most amazing game series I have ever played. 1 was good, 2 was amazing and now... now the dream has died. Borderlands 3 will either be an amazing comeback and start of a bright future for gearbox and shooters in general or the last gasp of a hillarious fish dying in a brown pond filled with dust and gravely voiced meatheads in hallways behind cover.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I will update this review as time goes by and as I progress through more characters and DLC launches etc.Right, I have finished the game 4 times now, on 4 different characters, so I'll give out my final review:THE PROS:-Lasers. Borderlands does guns well, so it was no surprise that Lasers would be fun and easy to use. Athena can take full advantage of them, seeing as she rocks Elemental damage more.-Character Classes. A big step-up from BL2, is how competitive each and every character can be. Nina was a solid choice for Beginners, whilst Claptrap allowed for some fun but still powerful builds. IMO Wilhelm has a lot going for him, and might be THE top dog.-Vehicles. The new vehicles are a nice refreshment from the older ones in BL and BL2.-Plot. The plot is thoroughly enjoyable. The ending was a really nice way to tie in the BL2 game chronologically, whilst still showing Athena's narrative of the events on the moon. Borderlands 3 anyone?THE CONS:-Voice Acting. You think giving everyone Australian accents is a good idea. It was. For 5 minutes. And then Pickle comes along and singlehandedly out-trumps Jar Jar Binks in annoyance levels. Even then, I wanted some really outlandish and crazy Ozzie to be used, but sadly, the enemies are duller than BL2.-Orange Weapons+: As many have stated before, Orange Weapons are farmed by either Vending Machines, or by Grinding in a Grinder Machine. The chances of actually finding one from a dead boss is SLIM.-Long Intervals of Play: Because you spend so much time in the air, in buildings, or just running to Oxegyn, you'll find yourself passing 5/6 minutes alone in getting to destinations. Coupled by how long it is before you get the first vehicle, the grind seems longer and longer. Not only that, missions usually set their completion areas a fair distance from them, prolonging the actual length of the game.-Length. This game was originally planned as a big DLC for €30, and with the short story and limited interesting quests, you can see why. The only long bit of BLTPS is navigation. Fighting is fast paced and iconic of the older iterations.So can I reccommend this? Not at €55. At that price point, I expect a solid 20+ hours of story and even more in optional side quests. Also, with the amount of DLC available for the game, BLTPS suddenly hits the €85+ mark. But, if in a sale, like €30, then this game is well worth it, and longtime fans will feel their purchase was justified.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												The pre-sequel is noticeable but not necessarily an improvement upon Borderlands 2. I personally like the Character Classes better and I love the new double jump/ground slam combat mechanics. The game keeps most of the good features and builds upon them.Cons-Death Pits everywhere (Lava pits, holes in the ground etc. These obstacles leave little room for error and take away from the little amount of gold the game allows you to salvage)-Not enough save points leading to long travel times if you die (death Pits)-Micro objectives within objectives just to make the game longer. This is one of the most frustrating parts of the game. Side missions and Main missions alike will tell you this is a point A to B then return back to a kind of mission; however along the way they always create two or three other unneeded problems that waste a lot of time. Most missions will have you running across several maps, slogging through hordes of guys you have already killed several times, to obtain the item and then you have to go all the way back. Outcome-Gameplay is fun Classes are better-Transportation/travel time sucks and there are lots of death pits -Money is scarce and Rare’s from vending machines are overpriced and not as good as they should be-Lots of repetitive filler in missions that takes away from the otherwise enjoyable gameplayLove the game but sometimes it tries my patience!

												Instead of creating Borderlands 3, the developers decided to narrate a little more about what happened before Borderlands 2, just to re-use the beloved villain Handsome Jack. Feel the endless solitude in your hearts as no one accepts your high-five request!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
Note: Take my positive recommendation with a pinch of salt. Read before you make a decision.Short version: An action-FPS-RPG game with the same humor and loot that has made the Borderlands series famous.  For $60 though, it's not worth the buy unless you're a big fan of the Borderlands series.  Wait until it's on sale (at least $30 or less). Since there's almost nothing new from BL2, 5/10.Long version: (Update: Dec 3, 2014) From what I've heard about recent hotfixes, The Pre-Sequel's end-game is basically dead (very improbable loot farming) because Gearbox/2K Aus is not listening to their fanbase.  I've also heard legendaries are almost exclusively found in the Grinder (seriously, wtf? no drop source?).  Here's Admiral Bahroo's video/rant on the issue: 


YouTube™ Video: Borderlands: Gearbox Nerfs Farming and Guns @GearboxSoftware WHY DO YOU DO THIS? 

			Views: 156,923		

			https://gearboxsoftware.zendesk.com/entries/57683810-PC-Update-Hot-Fix-Information ► Subscribe - http://www.youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=bahroo6 • Follow Me ► Twitch -...		

(Original review)This game is obviously marketed towards long-standing fans of the Borderlands series.  If you like Borderlands you'll enjoy The Pre-Sequel.  Unfortunately, if you don't enjoy farming for loot or the style of humor in this series then this game is NOT for you.  Most of this review is a comparison of The Pre-Sequel (which from here on I'll refer to as "TPS") and Borderlands 2 (which I may refer to as BL2).TPS is, canonically, the prequel to Borderlands 2.  It focuses on the story of the Vault Hunters hired by Jack (yes, THAT Jack, from BL2) as the anti-heroes save Elpis - Pandora's moon - and the Helios Space Station - a large Hyperion-based space complex located within orbit of Elpis.  (Note: this is before Jack becomes the main antagonist for the series.  This game helps players understand how he came to be the crazy nut-bag that he is in BL2.)  The dialogue and writing for this game is clearly the work of 2K Australia, but the humor just didn't seem to tickle my fancy this time around.  (In fact, some of the dialogue made me cringe a bit)While the game is almost exactly a carbon-copy of Borderlands 2 - complete with (nearly) identical HUDs and reskinned enemies - TPS brings a few new things to the table, including the Cryo element (which replaces Slag, even though Jack seems to know about Slag in this game), kraggons (the new resident creature of Elpis), low-gravity environments (read: moon jumping), ground pounding (read: butt slamming), and O2 kits (read: Oz kits - these things replace Eridian artifacts from BL2)In essence, TPS seems like a re-skin of Borderlands 2  (Or, if anything, a "standalone" expansion pack).  It's not going to attract any newcomers to the scene, but those that like Borderlands 1 and 2 will definitely enjoy The Pre-Sequel.  I personally think this game is alright, but at the full $60 I can't recommend this game at all (I got mine for $40 when it was on sale on Amazon).  If it goes on sale - say, 50-75% off - then I would think it's an decent buy.Oh yeah, and don't forget all the DLC that Gearbox always releases with these games.  Season Pass is recommended IF you want all the DLCs.  The base game is okay and it has a decent amount of content with it.  Also, Steam says I've logged 5.5 hours at time of writing but that doesn't count the time I've played offline (so, including that, my game time is closer to 15 hours)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												You've explored enough of Pandora in Borderlands and Borderlands 2, so now, welcome to Elpis, Pandora's moon. Borderlands the Pre-Sequel is the third game in the series, and like its predecessors before it, is equally random and filled with craziness. The plot revolves Handsome Jack and his fall from hero to villain, along with new Vault Hunters that play minor roles in Borderlands 2 (considering the events of the pre-sequel happens before that). The story is engaging enough, and the Vault Hunters have a lot more lines of dialogue during quests, which is a nice addition and breathes more life into your characters. It is also quite amusing that all citizens on Elpis pretty much have an Australian accent, because the Pre-Sequel was developed by 2K Australia. Gameplay is enhanced with the introduction of the Oxygen system in the pre-sequel, considering you are on the moon, and you can now leap into the air and crash down on your foes in a low-gravity atmosphere. This is affectionately called "butt-slamming" by the citizens of Elpis. This new Oxygen system also enables you to reach places that you otherwise wouldn't be able to, by leaping tall structures in a single bound. While all these are great additions to this game, Borderlands the Pre-Sequel does have some flaws. The side quests in this iteration of the series do not flow very well, usually requiring you to return to the same areas dozens of times, to the extent of a fair bit of annoyance. The sheer amount of side quests that suddenly pop up also bring you away from the main plot of the story, which does reduce the engagement and impact of the plot. In some ways, it does not feel as polished as Borderlands 2. To some, this makes Borderlands the Pre-Sequel seem more like an expansion to Borderlands 2 than a standalone game, but the Pre-Sequel has enough new additions to stand out on its own, yet stay true to the Borderlands series. Here's looking forward to more DLCs!

Though, i never figured the moon would be populated by brits and aussies.Should you buy this before BL:2? No. You'll get spoiled if you watch the intro. Which, btw, i would scold Gearbox/2k about. They really should have ran the story like a new Borderlands title, rather than a "expansion"Also, it seems they decided to stop being so rude with the humor as well, sadly. "Midgets" are "'Lil" and they don't say funny things like "So cold! So cold!" or "Here lies midge midge!", though, they and the Psycho's/Scavengers do still have quips.So in summary, get this game if you want to know what happened up there on the moon and what Jack was up to from BL1 to BL2 and prepare to treat this game like a BL:2 expansion.

												I've purchased the original Borderlands 4 times... on various platforms. BL2... I bought twice.. PS3 and PC. I've probably played both games around a total of 800hrs. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Borderlands pre-sequel was designed to fill in the details between BL and BL2.  Based on Elpis, the moon of Pandora, and Helios space station you meet Jack and discover how and why he changed into Handsome Jack. I thought the story was pretty good but depressing in some parts. Loved the Aussie accents and their little quirks and sayings which might explain why many people hate those parts of the mission. Loads of references to Aussie culture, like the snicket game, the swearing, the foul mouth gun Bognalla, janey Springs and her three words of wisdom, the swagman , Oz kits, the Dahl respawn station quotes, Red Belly and many more.The gameplay is a lot easier than BL2 where tens of millions of damage were needed to defeat enemies. Cryo guns, and butt slams are so much better than slag but corrosive and fire less so understandably as there is little oxygen on the moon. Was possible to progress in the game with guns five levels below the mission level and a lot more legendaries from vendors.However, some of the badass map achievements are mission related so fail to get it means you can not return unless you reset. Others only allow one person to complete the rank per day. At the moment only some of the DLC has been released and thats only been arenas which I am not fond of. And Jacks body double which I loved playing cause he did and said stuff I so wasnt expecting. Some of the boss fights are annoying too like DeadLift and his impossible Dead Weight badass achievement.Can I recommend this? Definitely, but wait for a special and try and get BL 2 as well because then the pre sequel will make a lot more sense. Already spent over 350 hours here and will spend a few more as more stuff gets released.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
Note: Take my positive recommendation with a pinch of salt. Read before you make a decision.Short version: An action-FPS-RPG game with the same humor and loot that has made the Borderlands series famous.  For $60 though, it's not worth the buy unless you're a big fan of the Borderlands series.  Wait until it's on sale (at least $30 or less). Since there's almost nothing new from BL2, 5/10.Long version: (Update: Dec 3, 2014) From what I've heard about recent hotfixes, The Pre-Sequel's end-game is basically dead (very improbable loot farming) because Gearbox/2K Aus is not listening to their fanbase.  I've also heard legendaries are almost exclusively found in the Grinder (seriously, wtf? no drop source?).  Here's Admiral Bahroo's video/rant on the issue: 


YouTube™ Video: Borderlands: Gearbox Nerfs Farming and Guns @GearboxSoftware WHY DO YOU DO THIS? 

			Views: 156,923		

			https://gearboxsoftware.zendesk.com/entries/57683810-PC-Update-Hot-Fix-Information ► Subscribe - http://www.youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=bahroo6 • Follow Me ► Twitch -...		

(Original review)This game is obviously marketed towards long-standing fans of the Borderlands series.  If you like Borderlands you'll enjoy The Pre-Sequel.  Unfortunately, if you don't enjoy farming for loot or the style of humor in this series then this game is NOT for you.  Most of this review is a comparison of The Pre-Sequel (which from here on I'll refer to as "TPS") and Borderlands 2 (which I may refer to as BL2).TPS is, canonically, the prequel to Borderlands 2.  It focuses on the story of the Vault Hunters hired by Jack (yes, THAT Jack, from BL2) as the anti-heroes save Elpis - Pandora's moon - and the Helios Space Station - a large Hyperion-based space complex located within orbit of Elpis.  (Note: this is before Jack becomes the main antagonist for the series.  This game helps players understand how he came to be the crazy nut-bag that he is in BL2.)  The dialogue and writing for this game is clearly the work of 2K Australia, but the humor just didn't seem to tickle my fancy this time around.  (In fact, some of the dialogue made me cringe a bit)While the game is almost exactly a carbon-copy of Borderlands 2 - complete with (nearly) identical HUDs and reskinned enemies - TPS brings a few new things to the table, including the Cryo element (which replaces Slag, even though Jack seems to know about Slag in this game), kraggons (the new resident creature of Elpis), low-gravity environments (read: moon jumping), ground pounding (read: butt slamming), and O2 kits (read: Oz kits - these things replace Eridian artifacts from BL2)In essence, TPS seems like a re-skin of Borderlands 2  (Or, if anything, a "standalone" expansion pack).  It's not going to attract any newcomers to the scene, but those that like Borderlands 1 and 2 will definitely enjoy The Pre-Sequel.  I personally think this game is alright, but at the full $60 I can't recommend this game at all (I got mine for $40 when it was on sale on Amazon).  If it goes on sale - say, 50-75% off - then I would think it's an decent buy.Oh yeah, and don't forget all the DLC that Gearbox always releases with these games.  Season Pass is recommended IF you want all the DLCs.  The base game is okay and it has a decent amount of content with it.  Also, Steam says I've logged 5.5 hours at time of writing but that doesn't count the time I've played offline (so, including that, my game time is closer to 15 hours)

Overall would recommend for fans of the Borderlands games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												Advance notice: there will be spoilers herein.  I'll hold off until I'm safely into "read more" territory.I've played through normal mode twice now, as Claptrap and Doppelganger Jack.  Having 500+ hours logged on Borderlands 2, I watched TPS for a while to grab it soon as the price dropped.  I grabbed it for about what you'd expect to spend on a decent expansion pack, expecting that it'd play pretty much like a decent expansion pack for Borderlands 2.  And if you want the short version of this review, it pretty much did.  If you liked Borderlands 2 you'll probably like Borderlands the Pre-Sequel because in just about every way that matters it's the same game.  The best comparison I can make for it is to the Captain Scarlett expansion for Borderlands 2, both in good terms and not so good.Yes, there are some differences.  Aside from ice replacing slag in the elemental table, which is a bit of a tactical shift, they're minor.  Having a whole new class of guns in the Borderlands universe which is already swimming in them really is a lot less noticeable than you would think.  It does seem that lasers are on the overpowered side in Normal mode, and I wouldn't be surprised if that's intentional, but other than that they're not much different than Maliwan sub guns from BL2.  Since Borderlands relies heavily on having a decent gun or couple of guns to make the game hum along, it is kind of nice to expand the field of possibilities a bit.  Oz kits just replace relics and while the gravity slam is nice to have as an option, its usefulness doesn't go far beyond being surrounded by kraggons or torks.  Air supply is not a huge issue (especially if you play Claptrap) and really the main practical use of double jumping is to try to execute some of the annoying jumping puzzles that crept their way into this game.  Really, Gearbox?  Jumping puzzles?If you're familiar with Borderlands 2, this game leaves you feeling a bit like something's missing that you can't quite put your finger on.  And no, it's not threshers (who only make a cameo here, thankfully).  I thought for a while it was just burnout on the Borderlands universe but after playing some BL2 again the other day the magic is still there.  The translation of the Psychos, Marauders, Nomads, and Goliaths of Pandora to the Scavs and Lunatics of Elpis may have been little more than a skin and voice change, but it lost something in the process that's apparently more important to the ambience than you might think.  Also, the Aussie accents don't make up for the comparatively sparse and not-really-funny things the NPCs say.  Just sayin'.Mechanically, I have a few minor grumbles.  The vehicles suck.  Seriously.  I never liked the skiff you were given to drive around Oasis with and while the reskin for the Stingray looks pretty badass it's still almost the exact same lemon underneath.  Also, TPS is much too quick with the respawns.  You can run headlong into repops on your way out of moderately small areas after just doing your quest business, not even poking around or exploring over much.  This was an annoyance in the first Borderlands that seemed corrected in BL2 so I hate to see it go backwards.  On a more positive note, side quests tend to appear earlier than they did in BL2.  Instead of finishing the story mission and getting the option to go back to the area you just finished for a milk run, you can see most quest givers on the map as soon as you arrive and can detour to them before you go on with your primary objective, saving yourself a fair bit of backtracking.  I'm neutral on the jump pads.  They walked right up to the line of overusing them in my opinion but didn't quite cross it.  Speaking of crossing lines, possible SPOILERS past this point.If there's anywhere TPS outright falls down it's in the supporting characters.  BL2 gave us a brilliant cast of background personalities topped off with one of the very best archvillains since Megatron.  In BLTPS, it's hard to pick out any character unique to this game that isn't just...really annoying.  It's possible, but hard.  Our archvillain Colonel Zarpedon is as colorless as she is relentless, far from the constant foil Handsome Jack was in BL2.  And don't get me started on Pickle.  Tiny Tina was genius in BL2, Pickle was an obvious attempt to recreate her that shoulda been strapped to a badonkadonk.Which leads us to the story in general.  Are we far enough in from the spoiler warning yet?  Ok.  If you liked the story of Borderlands 2 and don't want to see it messed with, then do not play this game.  Of course if you liked BL2 then you're probably way more interested in hanging out some more with Jack than you are in preserving the story, but you've been warned.  The way most of the game plays out, you can start to understand what would drive Jack to go from the hero on Elpis to the way he was on Pandora, then a thing or two happen that almost seem like the writers suddenly remembered they needed Jack to do something bad and/or crazy to get his descent into barking madness back on track.  It really doesn't work, and only results in the game feeling badly written in those spots.  The out-there "here's an evil thing for Jack to do" moments seem like last-minute afterthoughts bolted into the plotline and sticking out awkwardly, and don't keep you from reaching the ultimate conclusion that Jack was right all along, and Lilith is the real bad guy in the Borderlands universe.  Told you not to play if you didn't want the story turned on its head.So to summarize, as a game, it doesn't measure up to BL2.  In fairness, that's a tough act to follow.  It's still a good game in its own right and viewed as an expansion to BL2 rather than a standalone game it's fantastic.  I know I've been kind of negative here but if you're already familiar with BL2, then telling you it's like an addon for BL2 should cover all the positives.  And if you're not...start with BL2.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												I have played Borderlands enough that I have become intimately familiar wih its various strengths and weaknesses as as series, and Pre-Sequel as a lot of both. An interquel that reuses the engine and assets of Borderlands 2, Pre-Sequel nonetheless manages to reinvent the series tried-and-true, shoot, loot, rinse and repeat gameplay primarily by the introduction of low gravity- moving around on Elpis and the Helios spacestation is infinately easier then being stuck in Pandoran gravity. It brings to mind the low-gravity mutator of Unreal Tournament. Combat additions of cryo-element weapons and lasers are also welcome. I had a lot of fun as Athena the Gladiator, whose elemental tree gives her a hefty punch and whose Aspis denies a huge percentage of incoming damage, giving her incredible survivablity that the entirety of the Borderlands 2 cast lacked- most egregiously Salvador, who in the course of playing I spent an inordinate amount of time as with my face in the dirt waiting to be revived. I had a chance to sample the other characters, including Doppleganger Jack and Aurelia but most notably Wilhelm the Enforcer, whose autonomous drones are a big help in combat. The game is well-written for what it is, though if you are bothered by an excess of memes and references then it will rub you in much the same uncomfortable way that BL2 did. The combat in pre-sequel, I would say, the most refined in the series, and actually feels reasonably balanced, but the level design leaves much to be desired- the mazelike decks of Helios station in particular left me dazed and vexed, and had I not had my friends to guide me I would surely have needed to look at a guide to find my way around. The moon also has its share of navigational difficulties, with twisting, identical-looking crags and instant-death lava pits. For the geographically challenged player like myself, Pre-Sequel can be very annoying, but once you can actually find the battle, you'll have a lot of fun. The DLCs, few as they are, are solid- the holodome providing some of the most dynamic arena battles of the franchise, and Claptastic Voyage offering excellent music and asthetics, as well as a very epic final boss and game changing "glitched" guns. Pre-Sequel is a solid continuation for the series and also I think, a good entrypoint to the franchise for newcomers. I'm expecting more improvements in future entries.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												This last summer I got into the Borderlands series thanks to the sale as did many of my friends and we had an absolute blast with it, so when the pre-sequel came around I was looking forward to playing it. First and foremost I will get this out of the way: for the most part the gameplay is just like the predecessor, but considering that it was awesome I dont really find that to be detrimental, plus it is freshened due to the enviroment you are in with the lack of oxygen and the lower gravity, and butt slams. It manages to have more personality than the previous one as the vault hunters actually say stuff now, they have actual character, speaking of character development the guy everyone loves to hate, Handsome Jack, gets a ton of it. I'll avoid major spoilers and just say that it becomes a lot easier to say why he is the way is is in Borderlands 2. Another thing is it makes Claptrap, at least the playable one quite likable and fun to play as.Overall when it comes down to it, it' more Borderlands and if you had fun with the previous ones, you'll have fun here

												9/10When compared to the other Borderlands games, Borderlands the Pre-Sequel might actually come up on top. Despite it's expensive price tag, the Pre-Sequel is special in its own way.Having more story rich elements than the other Borderlands games, the Pre-Sequel also has this great Sci-Fi feel to it. This was an annoyance in the first Borderlands that seemed corrected in BL2 so I hate to see it go backwards.  On a more positive note, side quests tend to appear earlier than they did in BL2.  Instead of finishing the story mission and getting the option to go back to the area you just finished for a milk run, you can see most quest givers on the map as soon as you arrive and can detour to them before you go on with your primary objective, saving yourself a fair bit of backtracking.  I'm neutral on the jump pads.  They walked right up to the line of overusing them in my opinion but didn't quite cross it.  Speaking of crossing lines, possible SPOILERS past this point.If there's anywhere TPS outright falls down it's in the supporting characters.  BL2 gave us a brilliant cast of background personalities topped off with one of the very best archvillains since Megatron.  In BLTPS, it's hard to pick out any character unique to this game that isn't just...really annoying.  It's possible, but hard.  Our archvillain Colonel Zarpedon is as colorless as she is relentless, far from the constant foil Handsome Jack was in BL2.  And don't get me started on Pickle.  Tiny Tina was genius in BL2, Pickle was an obvious attempt to recreate her that shoulda been strapped to a badonkadonk.Which leads us to the story in general.  Are we far enough in from the spoiler warning yet?  Ok.  If you liked the story of Borderlands 2 and don't want to see it messed with, then do not play this game.  Of course if you liked BL2 then you're probably way more interested in hanging out some more with Jack than you are in preserving the story, but you've been warned.  The way most of the game plays out, you can start to understand what would drive Jack to go from the hero on Elpis to the way he was on Pandora, then a thing or two happen that almost seem like the writers suddenly remembered they needed Jack to do something bad and/or crazy to get his descent into barking madness back on track.  It really doesn't work, and only results in the game feeling badly written in those spots.  The out-there "here's an evil thing for Jack to do" moments seem like last-minute afterthoughts bolted into the plotline and sticking out awkwardly, and don't keep you from reaching the ultimate conclusion that Jack was right all along, and Lilith is the real bad guy in the Borderlands universe.  Told you not to play if you didn't want the story turned on its head.So to summarize, as a game, it doesn't measure up to BL2.  In fairness, that's a tough act to follow.  It's still a good game in its own right and viewed as an expansion to BL2 rather than a standalone game it's fantastic.  I know I've been kind of negative here but if you're already familiar with BL2, then telling you it's like an addon for BL2 should cover all the positives.  And if you're not...start with BL2.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Whether or not you should buy this game depends on a few things. I have to say upfront, that I enjoyed playing this game with my friends, but that probably has to do with the fact that I wasn’t expecting anything. A few of my friends that preordered and were really hyped absolutely hate this game with a fiery passion and will never touch it again. First, if you are big on story and characters, do NOT buy this game. The story and characters pale in comparison to BL2. To my memory, the game was advertised based on story and the game doesn’t really live up to that. When playing with my friends, the story seemed to be over way too quickly. If you are buying this game for gameplay, then there are both good and bad things. If you are buying NOW, the game finally has respawnable bosses fixing some of the end game stuff that the game lacked at first. It doesn’t totally fix it though and lots of end game stuff is still missing. I am no expert when it comes to that so go to a different review. What it adds for gameplay fits really well. Why haven’t we had double jumps, grinders, and lasers before? The gameplay is very close to borderlands 2. The enemies are not diverse in the slightest. In all, as a casual fan of the borderlands series who cares mostly about playing with friends, I enjoyed it. Know what you are getting into and buy it at a discount as there is not nearly enough gameplay as BL2 which was also $60. If you are looking for more borderlands 2 or to spice things up, look up Admiral Bahroo’s randomizer video on YouTube and try that first.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												I have played Borderlands enough that I have become intimately familiar wih its various strengths and weaknesses as as series, and Pre-Sequel as a lot of both. An interquel that reuses the engine and assets of Borderlands 2, Pre-Sequel nonetheless manages to reinvent the series tried-and-true, shoot, loot, rinse and repeat gameplay primarily by the introduction of low gravity- moving around on Elpis and the Helios spacestation is infinately easier then being stuck in Pandoran gravity. It brings to mind the low-gravity mutator of Unreal Tournament. Combat additions of cryo-element weapons and lasers are also welcome. I had a lot of fun as Athena the Gladiator, whose elemental tree gives her a hefty punch and whose Aspis denies a huge percentage of incoming damage, giving her incredible survivablity that the entirety of the Borderlands 2 cast lacked- most egregiously Salvador, who in the course of playing I spent an inordinate amount of time as with my face in the dirt waiting to be revived. I had a chance to sample the other characters, including Doppleganger Jack and Aurelia but most notably Wilhelm the Enforcer, whose autonomous drones are a big help in combat. The game is well-written for what it is, though if you are bothered by an excess of memes and references then it will rub you in much the same uncomfortable way that BL2 did. The combat in pre-sequel, I would say, the most refined in the series, and actually feels reasonably balanced, but the level design leaves much to be desired- the mazelike decks of Helios station in particular left me dazed and vexed, and had I not had my friends to guide me I would surely have needed to look at a guide to find my way around. The moon also has its share of navigational difficulties, with twisting, identical-looking crags and instant-death lava pits. For the geographically challenged player like myself, Pre-Sequel can be very annoying, but once you can actually find the battle, you'll have a lot of fun. The DLCs, few as they are, are solid- the holodome providing some of the most dynamic arena battles of the franchise, and Claptastic Voyage offering excellent music and asthetics, as well as a very epic final boss and game changing "glitched" guns. Pre-Sequel is a solid continuation for the series and also I think, a good entrypoint to the franchise for newcomers. I'm expecting more improvements in future entries.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel seems to improve on everything that was wrong with the first two games in the franchise in the gameplay department, but sacrifices the charm and comedic elements as well. Let's start out with gameplay. It is the same old Borderlands gameplay that you know and love, but with a new twist. On Pandora's moon, Elpis, there is low-gravity, which allows for new gameplay mechanics, that make the experience fresh and new. There are also new vehicles, which add for more diverse travels between different players. The game also runs fantastic, and look gorgeous. Some locations had beautiful settings with pitch perfect lighting, scenery, and even had lots of action going on with enemies, and still ran smoothly on my laptop. On the flip side, the game has several downsides. For one thing, the story falls short of my exoectations. If you have ever played a Borderlands game, you will laugh or chuckle at leasto nce every few minutes. In this installment, I only laughed 3 or 4 times, which was really a dissapointment. The story would have been acceptable if there were interesting characters, but there are very few. All in all, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a great game for lovers of RPG's, Shoot Em Ups, or loot and farming games like Diablo.                                                                      FINAL VERDICT   8.75/10

The combat is as hectic as ever and the new classes introduced are incredibly fun! The variety of weapons is AWESOME and it just feels like a solid Borderlands game all round. In the end I would give this game a 8/10 and reccommend it to anyone who likes the series and especially those who just love to shoot, kill and loot just about everything you see.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												I will be editing this review as I play with my thoughts over time. I'm doing this mainly because at the time of writing, I can't wait to review this game.3.1 HOURS: This is already starting out better than the other games did, and I loved both of them immensely. A good part of that quick start is the Action Skill available at level 3, rather than the usual level 5, meaning you get into the real heart of the game a lot more quickly. I chose Athena, with my friends being Nisha and Claptrap. Athena's action skill, Kinetic Aspis, makes for a very interesting weapon. It is a shield that blocks and absorbs attacks, then is thrown at enemies to deal damage. It deals more damage based on how much it absorbs. My friends like their own action skills as well. vaulthunter.exe is perfect for someone who wants something different every time, and Showdown is a good skill to have if you don't want to be precise all the time. But I think all of our favorite parts about the action skills is their quick reset time. Athena's and Nisha's abilities have a base cooldown of only 16 seconds (!!!). Compare that to the 42-second cooldown that Axton (my main in BL2) starts with, which can only be lowered to 21 with the best possible class mods and investment in a specific skill. As a result, the game feels a lot more fast-paced and fun. (Wilhelm is the exception with his own 42-second cooldown, but none of us have played him, and his action skill could be fun to make up for it.)  One of the other fun features is lowered gravity (note: the lower gravity does not apply to vehicles, as myself and one friend figured out). It's a lot of fun to be able to enjoy "parkour" again. In the first game, exploration was heavily encouraged by free loot at the top of the tallest buildings and most inconspicuous locations. The second game had very little benefit to exploring beyond easter eggs. Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed finding the Minecraft section and experiencing the double rainbow with Claptrap, but loot lasts longer than laughs (there's no reason we can't have both, right?). The dialogue is more interactive than ever before. The characters respond and interact differently based on who's present. At the very start of the game, Claptrap begs the players to get moving. At the drop pod, Jack flirts with Nisha. Once you hit the moon Janey flirts with Athena. The characters never interacted like this before, and it makes it seem much more like you're playing people rather than robots (except Claptrap, who IS a robot. Let's ignore that for now). Currently, this game seems to be well worth the money.8.9 HOURS:Started a game as Wilhelm. I think I prefer him to Axton already. Wolf isn't exactly the most helpful, automatically killing the small enemies I need to revive myself during boss battles, but it's better than a stationary turret that can't follow the boss if he goes around a corner. Saint is proving to be useful. He recovers my health and draws enemy fire, so no ill effects there. Other than that, so far there isn't much else to say. Until I get the perk that lets me fire while running, I don't rally have much else to add.11.7 HOURS:Started another single-player game with Claptrap this time. I'm not certain how I feel about him yet. I'm level 9, which is normally the time rolls of the dice start to become more minor (until TVHM). The skilltree I went down (the least useless for single-player) makes RNG more important than ever. Random "subroutines" make specific weapon types more powerful and the rest less powerful, or increase shields/health and make ALL weapons less poweful. The subroutine chosen is random, and changes every 100 ticks. It's a great fit for Claptrap, since his Action Skill is also chosen by RNG (as well as certain criteria). My favorite part so far has been beating Deadlift in less than 5 seconds when I had The Funzerker skill active, the Vault Hunter Loyalty shotgun, and the Shotgun subroutine. He stood no chance that attempt. My last 2 attempts were not so lucky, with Blightbot senselessly flying through walls, doing next to no damage, followed by Miniontrap being accidentally thrown to the most useless and secluded corner (Thanks, jump pad). But that third time, he didn't stand a chance! Jokes aside, that is a perfect example of how you can expect the whole game to go as Claptrap. Random numbers can make you go from useless to overpowered in the span of 10 seconds. Ridiculously dependent on numbers. That said, it was a ton of fun and I want to do more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												I have played quite a few games again which I initially did not like, and either still disliked them, or found a way to dislike them even more. However, it's incredibly rare that I revisit a game and find myself really enjoying it upon trying it again. I did about 1.5 playthroughs of the Pre-Sequel (which is kinda funny, since the game is "1.5" in the series, so there's that), and simply did not enjoy the game. I thought it felt like Borderlands 2 in a crappy setting, and never wanted to play it again. Someone insisted he wanted to play it again, and, wanting to have something to gripe about, I offered to play through it with him so I could complain about the game some more. However, I ended up doing three whole playthroughs of the game, and would like to do more.What changed? The only thing I can think of that's any different is my expectations...and I didn't play as Claptrap. Although a lot of people find him annoying as a character, period, I actually really like him. However, as a vault hunter, I didn't like his skill tree all that much. Of course, my half-playthrough was as Nisha, and I think most people enjoy playing as her, so I don't know. As for my expectations, though, Borderlands 2 had an amazing plot compared to Borderlands 1, and the maps had a lot of environmental variation. In The Pre-Sequel, however, the moon is rocky...all over. There's not a lot of map variation, so that is still a negative, and the plot, though decent, wasn't as good as Borderlands 2.Gameplay-wise, though, I played through the normal difficulty and True Vault Hunter mode with Athena, and the normal difficulty with the Baroness (DLC character who makes cryo element wonderful), and loved my time as them. Their skill trees and skills were a ton of fun, and the guns in this game are great, because...well, because they pretty much did copy-paste everything from Borderlands 2 about the guns, then added a laser gun type and called it a day. The low-gravity jumping and quasi-double-jumps were fantastic, and I would actually love to see something like that in the next Borderlands game. Although a lot of stuff felt lazy in his game because it's identical to Borderlands 2, getting new vault hunters, a cryo element that's way better than the slag element it replaces, and various nice gameplay features make this a really enjoyable game.It's rare that I change my mind from severe disappointment to high appreciation, but it happened here. Thank you for existing, The Pre-Sequel, and I'm sorry I hated on you before. <3

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												First I got to say:Accents - 10/10This game has the best accents ever heard in video game history. It is a monument to the beauty of the English language. You've got your americans, your brits and of course 20 different flavours of Australian (since the game's setting basically is space Australia), all delivered perfectly by top-notch voice actors and equalized to perfection. So, for all this game's flaws, the accents make it worthwhile to pick up anyway.Otherwise, the maps are under-utilised and empty, the story is simply "go to next place, push trigger, repeat" - while somehow helping Handsome Jack rise in power - and the enemies dull and uninteresting (Shugguraths are cool tho).The guns are the same as in Borderlands 2 with the addition of laser weapons because, you know, space, so if you liked the guns in that game you'll like 'em here. Gameplay is the same (shoot things 'til they die), but some♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥has opened the console and lowered the gravity. The writing is contrived and mostly focuses on trying to create memes and failing. For example; you know how Mr. Torgue being a feminist was kinda fun? Well, they run that into the ground until it's not fun anymore.But still; them accents tho. 10/10 would eargasm from the Skipper's voice again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This game is... meh. It's good, but not BL2 good. Out of the 4 "DLC", only one was actually missions and content. 2 of them were character packs (there isnt really any point in replaying this if you have BL2 which can be replayed many times) and the other dlc is just an arena. Kind of lame. The story is "okay" at best, as is the humor as well. You don't see any orange weapons until the last 30% of the game, and then they're so abundent that they're not that special anymore. The bosses aren't difficult at all really, i only went down once or twice with even the final bosses (keep in mind i had 0 orange weapons). And to add on to that, 80% of the orange weapons are exact copies from BL2, name/design and all! Kind of lame if you ask me. I would never pay full price for this game. But even with all these downsides, it is still a borderlands game, and it is still fun.TLDR: The game isn't worth full price. Wait till it goes on sale for 20$. It is nowhere close to the godliness of BL2, but it is kind of fun. Also the low gravity feature makes the game worth 20$ (if you get bored, just ♥♥♥♥ around with double jumping xD)

												To put this review into one sentence: This game is great, but it really should have been a DLC for Borderlands 2.Although, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is generously shorter than Boarderlands 2, it truely does capture the same atmosphere as the rest of the saga. content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												Oh hey, Borderlands 2 got an expansion. Wait, it's a full priced game? With it's own Season pass to boot!? Oh Gerabox you silly...Now, based on that you ight think that I hate this game, but I don't. It's more Borderlands and I like Borderlands. All the stuff that worked before still work here. But the game adds nearly nothing into the Borderlands formula, except for zero-g jumping and (nearly pointless) oxygen tanks. The jumping is a great addition and I hope that they keep that in the future games, but besides that, I don't think this game does anything better than Borderlands 2.I didn't find it to be quite as funny, except for a few missions. There are no stakes in the story because it's a prequel so you know what will happen.Most of the time they are merely filling in some blanks, or retconing the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of things. Also, Claptrap is able to go up stairs, which is simply wrong. The game is also far shorter than BL2. They did have a pretty nice variety of different locations, but even that pales in comparison to BL2.This game is NOT worth a full price release. It should have been a 30€ at best. Gearbox is simply getting too greedy at this point. Still, even with all of it's faults, I did have a pretty good time playing through this game in co-op. If you like the Borderlands games, you will most likely enjoy this one too. If you don't, this game will do nothing to change your mind. I can't comment on the quality of the dlc's(those have been really good in the past) because I have not played them, and I'm not exactly eager to buy a season pass to something that propably should have been a standalone dlc in the first place!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												If you liked any of the previous Borderland games then hold onto your seats becaue this one could possibly be worse than the others.  In saying that I do love the game as I am a massive Borderlands fan and have enjoyed every game in the series. However, Gearbox Australia has put their own twist on the humor in the game and needless to say it falls quite flat. There are references to classic Austalian icons but for some reason us Aussies (i.e. me) did not find in nearly as funny as the other games. A laugh was had here and there throughout the game but coparing this to Borderlands 2 this falls short of being funny. That is about the only bad thing I can say about the game. The combat is as hectic as ever and the new classes introduced are incredibly fun! The variety of weapons is AWESOME and it just feels like a solid Borderlands game all round. In the end I would give this game a 8/10 and reccommend it to anyone who likes the series and especially those who just love to shoot, kill and loot just about everything you see.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel seems to improve on everything that was wrong with the first two games in the franchise in the gameplay department, but sacrifices the charm and comedic elements as well. Let's start out with gameplay. It is the same old Borderlands gameplay that you know and love, but with a new twist. On Pandora's moon, Elpis, there is low-gravity, which allows for new gameplay mechanics, that make the experience fresh and new. There are also new vehicles, which add for more diverse travels between different players. The game also runs fantastic, and look gorgeous. Some locations had beautiful settings with pitch perfect lighting, scenery, and even had lots of action going on with enemies, and still ran smoothly on my laptop. On the flip side, the game has several downsides. For one thing, the story falls short of my exoectations. If you have ever played a Borderlands game, you will laugh or chuckle at leasto nce every few minutes. In this installment, I only laughed 3 or 4 times, which was really a dissapointment. The story would have been acceptable if there were interesting characters, but there are very few. All in all, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a great game for lovers of RPG's, Shoot Em Ups, or loot and farming games like Diablo.                                                                      FINAL VERDICT   8.75/10

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Technically, and design-wise, this game is better than Borderlands 2. Better jumping. Better guns. Better balancing. Better characters and abilities. Where it fails... Is that there is less of it. Smaller maps, smaller levels, shorter missions, a story that is padded to hell... It's a great story, but the padding is very obvious. See, Borderlands 2 had so much content that you could spend hours in it. Especially in bonus after game content. The Pre-Sequel has none of that. Only one real expansion pack is out, and it's good. But it's only one expansion pack. The rest are characters and an arena mode. You'll find a good game here, but after 2 playthroughs, I garuntee you'll have done everything the game has.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Borderlands 2 set a high bar for the series; it combined raunchy humor, infinite variable and fun weapons, multiple unique classes with three seperate specializations each, a lovable villain, fun and interesting characters, and a straightforward but complex story. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, unfortunately, did not live up to its predecessor. Much of the raunchy humor that made 2 and the 1's DLC so memorable is missing, the playable characters are bland (though still fun to play as), a forgettable villain, boring NPCs, and less of a story than slightly guided wandering.However, much of the gameplay that makes the series so memorable is still there, and the game provides a backstory to the main villain and one of the side villains of Borderlands 2. It's still fun, the oxygen mechanic is interesting and useful, and the new laser weapon type can mimic every other weapon type, with its biggest advantages being the obscenely large amount of ammo and the extra damage when in oxygen. The Cryo element is also a welcome addition, as it is the first elemental type dedicated to something other than doing more damage.Final Score: 7/10. Feel free to try it, but don't expect it to be as good as the last one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is the third official installment in the series, and definetly more interesting(not necessarily better) than the other two games for multiple reasons.Before we begin, if there is one thing you should know about BPS right off the bat, it is that this game is a very "samey" sequel. If you thought that Borderlands 2 didn't bring enough new things to the table when it came out in 2012, then you will most likely not enjoy this game.On that note, I also didn't find the BPS as enjoyable as B1 or B2. BPS doesn't bring the same charm or luster as the other entries in the series. Once I beat the campaign, I didn't feel the need to come back to this game.Yet, this game still does bring some cool new things to the table. The oxygen system was an good concept, and I often found myself missing the Butt Slam ability upon revisiting B2. Not to mention Laser Weaponry is possibly the best addition the series has had so far.In the end, BPS is still a fun game; but for right now, I can only recommend this game if you are a fan of Borderlands. It is more worth your money to get either of the first two games if you want to try out the series. If you are just dying to know how the story continues, feel free to give this game a shot. If not, consider it again when this game goes on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This game is... meh. It's good, but not BL2 good. Out of the 4 "DLC", only one was actually missions and content. 2 of them were character packs (there isnt really any point in replaying this if you have BL2 which can be replayed many times) and the other dlc is just an arena. Kind of lame. The story is "okay" at best, as is the humor as well. You don't see any orange weapons until the last 30% of the game, and then they're so abundent that they're not that special anymore. The bosses aren't difficult at all really, i only went down once or twice with even the final bosses (keep in mind i had 0 orange weapons). And to add on to that, 80% of the orange weapons are exact copies from BL2, name/design and all! Kind of lame if you ask me. I would never pay full price for this game. But even with all these downsides, it is still a borderlands game, and it is still fun.TLDR: The game isn't worth full price. Wait till it goes on sale for 20$. It is nowhere close to the godliness of BL2, but it is kind of fun. Also the low gravity feature makes the game worth 20$ (if you get bored, just ♥♥♥♥ around with double jumping xD)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												First I got to say:Accents - 10/10This game has the best accents ever heard in video game history. It is a monument to the beauty of the English language. You've got your americans, your brits and of course 20 different flavours of Australian (since the game's setting basically is space Australia), all delivered perfectly by top-notch voice actors and equalized to perfection. So, for all this game's flaws, the accents make it worthwhile to pick up anyway.Otherwise, the maps are under-utilised and empty, the story is simply "go to next place, push trigger, repeat" - while somehow helping Handsome Jack rise in power - and the enemies dull and uninteresting (Shugguraths are cool tho).The guns are the same as in Borderlands 2 with the addition of laser weapons because, you know, space, so if you liked the guns in that game you'll like 'em here. Gameplay is the same (shoot things 'til they die), but some♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥has opened the console and lowered the gravity. The writing is contrived and mostly focuses on trying to create memes and failing. For example; you know how Mr. Torgue being a feminist was kinda fun? Well, they run that into the ground until it's not fun anymore.But still; them accents tho. 10/10 would eargasm from the Skipper's voice again.

												Oh hey, Borderlands 2 got an expansion. Wait, it's a full priced game? With it's own Season pass to boot!? But the game adds nearly nothing into the Borderlands formula, except for zero-g jumping and (nearly pointless) oxygen tanks. The jumping is a great addition and I hope that they keep that in the future games, but besides that, I don't think this game does anything better than Borderlands 2.I didn't find it to be quite as funny, except for a few missions. There are no stakes in the story because it's a prequel so you know what will happen.Most of the time they are merely filling in some blanks, or retconing the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of things. Also, Claptrap is able to go up stairs, which is simply wrong. The game is also far shorter than BL2. They did have a pretty nice variety of different locations, but even that pales in comparison to BL2.This game is NOT worth a full price release. It should have been a 30€ at best. Gearbox is simply getting too greedy at this point. Still, even with all of it's faults, I did have a pretty good time playing through this game in co-op. If you like the Borderlands games, you will most likely enjoy this one too. If you don't, this game will do nothing to change your mind. I can't comment on the quality of the dlc's(those have been really good in the past) because I have not played them, and I'm not exactly eager to buy a season pass to something that propably should have been a standalone dlc in the first place!

If you want to get punched in the face and kicked in the balls by your fellow neighbors, this is the perfect choice for you! Feel the endless solitude in your hearts as no one accepts your high-five request!

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												This will be a simple review for people who already know the franchise but are on the fence about this game. Kidding, it is a little lenghty, but there is a TL\DR on the bottom as well as a part you can choose to skip literally right under this sentence, so read up! ^_^So, a little backstory. (You can skip to the next paragraph indicated by a space if you don't care to know where this opinion is coming from).First off, most of my playtime was on console, sorry.I bought Borderlands 1 about a month after release and thought it was heaven-sent. I couldn't have loved a video game more and I replayed the heck out of it.When the Doomsday trailer released for Borderlands 2, I am sure my happiness caused an earthquake on the other side of the world. I watched and rewatched and rewatched that trailer over and over and over again and I am sure I lost some friends simply by being annoying with wanting them to watch it with me while gushing over the IP. The game released and I disliked the first part in the snow, but once we went to find Roland, it was absolutely amazing after that. The story and characters blew away any and all expectations. I was again in love. That is until the end game where I realised everyone pretty much had the same gear, which I felt was a stark contrast to the first game (where blues and purples were always still viable), especially with the broken and unbalanced UVHM. I soon went back to the first borderlands. I say soon, but it was still several hundred hours later.When the Borderlands game released on mobile and that it was a strategy game too, I once again jumed for joy, and some country on the other side of the world was cursing me for cusing yet another earthquake. I quickly realised it was trash though, and disposed of it.Then Borderlands PreSequel was announced. The trailer made me feel it was trying to copy the hype Doomsday set but the premise seemed interesting enough. I got it day one with cautious optimism. Here'show I feel/felt...Borderlands the PreSequel does some interesting things, such as having alternate dialog for your New Game+ playthroughs, introducing the Cryo element (which I felt was soooooo much more fun and useful than the Slag element), double jumping and boot gliding and butt stomps, shattering frozen enemies, beautiful skyboxes, verticality, playable Cl4p-Tp (Claptrap) and just some overall freshness. However, the story is absolute garbage. Devs went on to say things like how you learn why Handsome Jack hates Claptrap units amongst other fun tidbits, but that's not there. Literally a claptrap dies and Jack is already like "Sweet." There's a couple other moments like that but none of it really builds up, he just hates Claptrap units from the get-go and we don't really see all that much of a transformation from jack. It is like all the dialog is simply the bare minimum there, as far as story stuff goes, that it needs to tick a checkbox. The end leaves some decent ideas though so it wasn't all bad, and the military AI part was actually okay too.The humor also isn't as good either. Maybe it is Australian humor (no offense) but I just didn't dig most of it. I like dry humor, I like sarcasm, sucky jokes, dirty jokes, and many other types, but I felt a large part of the humor was laid out in a way that wasn not funny. Take for example the Deadpool commercial where D says something like "that guy has the right idea, he's wearing the brown pants." If it was in the PreSequel, it would be "Hey that guy is wearing brown pants, which is fitting because he might just poop himself" *que pause to hear laughter, only to hear awkward silence*A lot of guns were copy-pasted from Borderlands 2, there was an even worse post-game (unless you enjoyed cryo as much as I did) and it overall just felt like a cash grab. A decent cash grab, but one that left that taste in my mouth regardless, slightly better than the cash grab a lot of people were thinking it would be especially since it was originally going to be DLC, but then was expanded into a full game.TL/DRAll of that said, even though I have some hate towards this game for how it was handled, I still find this game to be quite fun if you are a fan of the Borderlands series. I would maybe wait to get it for $15 or so and yes, the DLC characters are worth it. (I love Aurellia or however it is spelled).
