												Well it's Borderlands, and the gameplay is exactly what you've come to expect from the genre: it will make you happy.What completely and utterly ♥♥♥♥s this game in the zero-G♥♥♥♥♥♥ is that some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ thought it would be a GREAT idea to have it voiced over largely by the most ocker Australian 'voice actors' they could find.SON OF A TAINT!It's sickening, and as an Aussie, it's embarrassing and nothing short of groan-worthy.It's sad because you're in it not just for the loot, but the clever dialogue of the previous games - which I've not seen as yet - and the delivery in those accents (See: Stever Irwin, Noni Hazelhurst and Paul Hogan) honestly make me want to stab myself in the ear with a rusty digeridoo... no really... the death throws of a syphilitic, acid-tripping, deep-throating dropbear digging crusty crabs out of Tony Abbott's budgie smugglers would be a more pleasant sound.Yep.

number of helpful: 21 of 41 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Disappointing. The quality of supporting characters is poor (Pickle = the Jar Jar of borderlands), the dialogue is unengaging at best, jimmy rustling at worst. The player characters are well made dialogue wise, skill wise, etc. (except claptrap.), and the plot isn't terrible.Jacks "character development" is shaky, as he just seems to go from 0-60 evulz past the first level, and the continuity of the series is stretched a bit, particularly in Lilliths, Rolands and Moxxis involvement in the story, which would logically affect how jack treats them in bl2, however in bl2 he treats them as minor annoyances. Equally, how Lillith treats jack in pre sequel is completely counter to how she does in bl2.Weapons are mediocre, being exactly the same manufacturers (they even didn't change the word "Bandit" to "scav" in the game files), lasers are badly balanced, cryo is pretty much just a rehash of slag with a little immobility added, and oz kits are just relics but with a timer that counts down to you dying. There are two vehicles in the game, one is a reskin of the Runner from bl2, and the other is just the Manta from UT3. The only difference is that the Manta from UT3 is actually elegant wheras its copied counterpart handles stupidly and its own jump and butt-slam gimick is clumsy and ineffective.The sexuality of the characters was very, very forced. I started to take shots every time Janey Springs announced she was a lesbian, just in case we'd forgotten. On the subject of gender politics, male characters were shown to be homophobes, lonely creeps, or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s more often than not. When compared to the female characters who are shown in a much, much better light, it leaves a little bad taste in your mouth, which didn't help me to overlook the previous flaws.Finally, as the game starts from the end of BL2, it's impossible to play either game in any order, without getting spoilers for the other game, so anyone deciding to play in chronological order (Borderlands, Borderlands Pre-Sequel, Borderlands 2) is gonna have spoilers for BL2, and anyone playing in release order (Borderlands, Borderlands 2, Borderlands Pre-Sequel) is gonna have spoilers for Pre-Sequel.Best aspect of this game? The mapping for Helios Station was incredibly refreshing, the interior and exterior aspects.Worst aspect of this game? The first boss. It tries to go with a "So bad it's good" vibe "(Kill this guy ^)", but it's just lame.

content:

												I really wanted to like this game but unfortunately after playing it some time it ceases to be enjoyable. The story falls short of expectations and is a bit dull and unrealistic character developtment. Quests become repetitive and grindy straight away in a smaller area than previous Borderlands games makes for stale action. Especially when you've become stronger than enemies in any given area. If you get to a new quest hub and get a load of underleveled quests (which has happened several times) it doesn't become enjoyable. The new characters and skills seem solid but the action becomes slow paced and boring quickly. Zero gravity doesn't really add anything groundbreaking to the franchise. It feels like it is missing the fun story of Borderlands 2 and the enjoyable gameplay of Borderlands. Also even though this was made by a small studio a little QA goes far and the game is really buggy, with enemies disappearing through walls and jumping issues and things going mental for no reason. All I can say really is give it a miss.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Low-gravity jumps, butt-slams, airborne vehicles (somewhat), grinder, characters finally alive (with their own dialogue and interactions), skill points from level 3, loot caves, pop culture references, Claptrap, GOODD.Little content, missions becoming tedious (run from point A to C - collect stuff X - go to point B - go back to point A to solve some crap issues - go to point B again etc), non-respawnable bosses, areas not staying blacked-out when you haven't discovered them (bad for Steam cheevos), lackadaisical raid bosses, used humor, BADDD.All in all, Borderlands TPS can be considered as a huge expansion to Borderlands 2, rather than being a strong individual sequel to the series. I do not recommend it to players due to its pricing, but it is nevertheless a good game that Borderlands fans should pick up. For the rest? Pick it up during a sale; Steam does it so often that you probably don't have to wait long anyway.

number of helpful: 62 of 123 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												All the maps are new, albeit they contain many, many recognisable items from BL2. There are a few new items, but they tend to look a little out of place and not finished with the same artistic flair that made BL2 such a visual treat. Same with the creatures and weapons. The new ones tend to look a little amateurish and in general most have just had a paint-job. Voice acting is pretty diabolical. Lol. Gameplay has undoubtedly improved, but the battles are still very unbalanced. It’s more balanced than in BL2, but they have made the sniper critical hits too effective now. Why is it they never seem to be able to get this right?As per usual, the enemy have far more health than you. While it may take dozens of shots to beat them, they can cause immense damage to you with just one shot. This makes for very frustrating play. I am amazed that Gearbox never sorted out the terrible game mechanics. The new weapons are fun, but I do think they should have re-worked all the weapons.  Much of the excitement of the game is looting weapons, and too many of them are exactly the same as in BL2.  They did, however, rework the skills, class mods, and various boosts, adding some nice touches in the way of purchasable boosts.  Most of the new maps aren't too well designed. Some having no way back to “sanctuary”. One of the nice features of the original games is that in almost all circumstances you could get back to safe territory relatively easily, should you need to re-supply or level up to defeat a boss. Not the case in this game – it can be very difficult indeed to retrace your steps and consequently much harder than it should be to defeat some bosses if you happen turn up to the fight at too low level or with the wrong equipment. I managed to get one character stuck because it’s level was too low compared to the enemy and had no ammo or appropriate guns, with few options to get back to a safe haven to re-equip or level up. Play is overall easy. I was able to complete most of the game five or six levels below the enemy. With the exception of one, that was true of the bosses too....most are very easy. The final boss just takes time, but having said that, it is good fun. Even in raid mode it's easy, but still good fun.Don’t forget that despite all my criticisms Borderlands is hilarious fun and it remains one of the best coop team games out there. That fact alone is enough for a very large number of people to buy this game. All of the new characters are good, claptrap has been very well implemented - especially his special skills which are pretty hilarious. Should you buy it? I think people will have very mixed views. The game is good, but it's not really different to BL2 and it's way, way too short for the money. I'm going to say no, becuase I can't say maybe! Whatever, but if you do buy it then at least wait until the price comes down.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												TL;DR: The game is like a stripped down BL2; it's worth the asking price but don't expect another home run.Don't let all of the hype and advertising persuade you, the Pre-Sequel is not an evolution of Borderlands 2. It is a sort of horizontal upgrade; while you get the new Cryo element, double jumping, and an all new story, this is at the expense of Slag and a worthwile endgame boss, and the whole affiar is half the length of Borderlands 2. Borderlands the Pre Sequel is extremely samey to Borderlands 2, so if you enjoyed that game then you're in good shape. However, the story is a little weaker, the humor a little more forced and the level designs are linear and drab (except for one particular area which is extremely vertical, leading to a lot of confusion when trying to navigate). However many of the parts of Borderlands 2 that were important to endgame play like boss farming have been stripped down or outright removed. Many side quest bosses are killable only once, however it is impossible to cap out without completeing at least a few of them, so those drops are lost. some legendaries simply have no drop location, so the only way to get them is from the new grinder system in Concordia, where you can insert easily farmed legendaries to get new ones. This leads to some irritation when farming for new gear, as you'll just be sitting there farming Iwajira for thingies and sitting in front of the grinder. Moreover, most of the legndaries are recycled from Borderlands 2. So the loot system's kinda silly at the moment. But hey, lasers are cool.Past that, the game on the whole is far too easy. Every character has their own special way to totally break the game, and the endgame raid boss is an absolute joke. you'll burn through both playthroughs with relative ease with only one or two difficulty spkes during the story. the story itself is pretty satisfying and slots in between Borderlands 1 and 2 quite nicely, and even gives some closure to the Borderlands 2 story as well. Moral of the story, should you buy the game? yes. But adjust your expectations first. It's not as good as Borderlands 2, not by a long shot. However, it's more borderlands. If you're into the shoot and loot gameplay of Borderlands 2, the Borderlands the Pre Sequel will hold you over nicely until Borderlands 3.7.5/10

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												So much negativity out there.tl;dr: If you haven't played Borderlands 2 and/or cannot appreciate attention to detail, go back to playing CoD or whatever lackluster shooter you wile your life away with.I loved the hell out of this game. Not so much because it's new and original and different from BL2, because in large part it isn't. In fact, it not being something completely new and original and different from BL2 was part of the hook. As far as gameplay, why fix what isn't broken? And hell, add some lazers and BUTT SLAMS. But as far as the story goes? Anybody who thinks it's lacking wasn't paying attention at some point in their Borderlands career. Likewise, it is NOT something you can just go and read about online if you want to catch the small details and nuances demonstrate how BL2 came to life. It isn't just about how Jack came to power; it's about how Jack stole the reins to Hyperion and flipped EVERYTHING upside down; it's a play-by-play of the deterioration of his humanity; it's a narrative of how his alliances and rivalries were forged; it's a testament to his ingenuity and how he used Hyperion to seize Pandora. That said, it isn't a game to simply try to breeze through, shooting for the best loot. It's a novelty. A "(Re)Making of Pandora" which you get to play a pivotal role in.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
*DISCLAIMER* It is very easy to hate this game when you compare it to Borderlands 2, aside from a few rehashed legendary weapons, this is a different enough game that you can enjoy it. That said, having bought it for 59.99$ I feel that I might have spent a bit too much on it. This doesn't make it a bad game, but I encourage anyone who is looking to play it to seek a 40$ or below pricetag. Maybe buy the season pass as well, but for now none of the DLC is high enough quality to warrant purchase (aside from Handsome Jack, we'll talk more about that), While I do recommend this game, it's not perfect and isn't going to be fun for everyone.Pros:-Oz Kits are awesome, easily the most useful and fun mechanic added-Characters are (mostly) all balanced to be playable both solo and co-op-Characters converse with eachother, both on Elpis and Pandora. This adds a great degree of depth.-LASERS, easily some of the best weapons in this game-Action Oriented Tutorial, no more walking through a frozen tundra listening to Claptrap.-The Grinder. Save your loot, you can always trade it up to be better. You can even "craft" legendary weapons.Cons:-Non replayable. As far as I know, none of the DLC has added the ability to redo your TVHM playthrough. Yet.-Poor farming mechanics. For some people, this game is fun when they farm. A great deal fo enemies only appear once and happen to be the only way to acquire some legendaries apart from grinding.-Vehicle control. Borderlands has never been known to have terrific vehicles, but the moon buggy happens to control the worst yet.-LASERS, yes they're great but they also happen to overshadow a lot of other weapon types. -Handsome Jack. This is more of a personal issue. Easily the best character in the game now, taking the spot as soon as he was released. Being Jack makes the game easymode.-The Raid Boss... There isn't really one, some prefer to call it The "Raid Boss" as it's simply a beefed up version of the final bossThis is a fun game, if you liked previous Borderlands games this one is sure to keep your attention for a little while. After you complete your first and second playthrough however, there isn't much to do unless you find excitement in endless Alt+f4 to not lose your chance at farming legendaries. Legendary farming is an issue, as mentioned a lot of the enemies that drop legendary weapons only spawn once. Literally the very first boss you fight has a chance to drop a legendary weapon and you can only fight him once per playthrough.I can't stress enough, while I personally enjoy this game and would recommend it, it's really not a perfect game. At the very least you should be able to keep the fun around for the first two playthroughs. Any time after that is only as fun as you can make it, whether you're farming some loot or hooking up with friends to level new characters. I'd say the game is a solid 7/10. It's definitely worth playing, but not worth the full price.

Posted: April 5, 2015
												10/10 Definitely not a DLC- Includes completely 4 new characters- The story behind the story (in BL2)- Hours worth of new voice acting- Completely new maps- Completely new play mechanics (Low Grav/Low Oxygen/Oxy Jump)- Butt Slams- Completely new elemental damage type (Cryo/No Slag Weapons)- Completely new weapon builds including new burst types (Laser/Probably Others)- Classic BL charm- Classic BL attitudeMy only complaint is there isn't more gameplay & story based DLCs.For full experience recommend not playing as Wilhelm unless you plan to go solo all the way. Wilhelm is badass but has the personality of a brick. Unlike Brick who is badass and has the personality of a badass. Also Wolf steals allies revive kills.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												If you are going to get this game, get the Claptrap DLC, as you will be disappointed in the vanilla ending, but the DLC will help you with your anger. Other than that, every character (apart from the ones from the previous games) has an Australian accent, and there are some recycled jokes from the other games. Added to that, some places seem to literally have recycled textures from the other games, and the level design does have some flaws in some places.However if you take it as a game apart from the rest of the series, then it can supply some good gameplay and overall is an enjoyable experience (again, not just the base game but with the Claptastic Voyage DLC incl.).

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												It has its ups and downs. All in all - if you like BL games, you will like BL:PS. The charm and the uniqueness is still there. It doesn't offer much interesting new content besides laser weapons (which are mostly terrible, but a select few are overpowered), but overall, it's still fun and I had a good time. Only thing I did not have a good time with was what happens after level 50 (max level is 70). XP rate is fine up until 50, but then, someone had a GENIUS idea to cut the XP gain rate by about 90% or some♥♥♥♥♥♥ It went from you "kill a badass, and your XP bar fills up a little" to "you kill 100 badasses, and your XP bar fills up so little you can't even notice it". Just why? Story mission XP is still scaled properly, why not monsters XP? All this does is force the player who wants to get from 50-70 to repeatedly speed-run select portions of the story, which is MIND-NUMBINGLY BORING, and made me quit the game. Where's the satisfaction of the reaching max level? The satisfaction of end-game gear farming? End game builds? Well, unless you cheat, those are not things you will achieve in a reasonable amount of time witih this game. P.S. Relationship spoilers  Jamey x Athena is literally the cutest thing ever, though...<33
